def min(self) -> pandas.core.series.Series: 
49    def min(self)-> pd.Series:
50        """Computes minimum value per column.
51
52        Returns
53        --------
54        pd.Series
55            A pandas Series
56
57        Example
58        --------
59        >>>  Statistics(df).min()
60        """
61        return self.df.min()

Computes minimum value per column.

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Example

>>>  Statistics(df).min()
def range(self) -> pandas.core.series.Series: 
63    def range(self)-> pd.Series:
64        """
65        Computes range of a column.
66
67        Returns
68        --------
69        pd.Series
70            A pandas Series
71
72        Example
73        --------
74        >>>  Statistics(df).range()
75        """
76        range = Statistics(self.df).max() - Statistics(self.df).min()
77
78        return range

Computes range of a column.

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Example

>>>  Statistics(df).range()
def mean(self) -> pandas.core.series.Series: 
80    def mean(self) -> pd.Series:
81        """
82        Computes the mean (Average).
83
84        Returns
85        --------
86        pd.Series
87            A pandas Series
88
89        Example
90        --------
91        >>>  Statistics(df).mean()   
92        """
93        return self.df[self.columns].mean()

Computes the mean (Average).

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Example

>>>  Statistics(df).mean()
def median(self) -> pandas.core.series.Series: 
 95    def median(self)-> pd.Series:
 96        """
 97        Computes the median (middle value).
 98
 99        Returns
100        --------
101        pd.Series
102            A pandas Series
103
104        Example
105        --------
106        >>>  Statistics(df).median()   
107        """
108        return self.df[self.columns].median()

Computes the median (middle value).

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Example

>>>  Statistics(df).median()
def standard_deviation(self) -> pandas.core.series.Series: 
110    def standard_deviation(self)-> pd.Series:
111        """
112        Computes the standard deviation.
113
114        Returns
115        --------
116        pd.Series
117            A pandas Series
118
119        Example
120        --------
121        >>>  Statistics(df).standard_deviation()  
122        """
123        return self.df[self.columns].std()

Computes the standard deviation.

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Example

>>>  Statistics(df).standard_deviation()
def quantiles(self, quantile: int | float, **kwargs) -> pandas.core.series.Series: 
125    def quantiles(self, quantile:int|float, **kwargs)-> pd.Series:
126        """
127        Computes the quantiles.
128
129        Returns
130        --------
131        pd.Series
132            A pandas Series
133
134        Example
135        --------
136        >>>  Statistics(df).quantiles(0.75)  
137        """
138        if not isinstance(quantile, (float, int)):
139            raise TypeError(f'quantile must be float or int, got {type(quantile).__name__}')
140
141        return self.df.quantile(q=quantile, **kwargs)

Computes the quantiles.

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Example

>>>  Statistics(df).quantiles(0.75)
def iqr(self) -> pandas.core.series.Series: 
143    def iqr(self)-> pd.Series:
144        """
145        Computes the IQR (Inter-Quartile Range).
146
147        Returns
148        --------
149        pd.Series
150            A pandas Series
151
152        Example
153        --------
154        >>> Statistics(df).iqr()
155        """
156        Q1 = Statistics(self.df).quantiles(0.25)
157        Q3 = Statistics(self.df).quantiles(0.75)
158
159        IQR = Q3 - Q1 
160
161        return IQR

Computes the IQR (Inter-Quartile Range).

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Example

>>> Statistics(df).iqr()
def variance(self, method: str = 'sample') -> pandas.core.series.Series: 
163    def variance(self, method:str ='sample')-> pd.Series:
164
165        """Computes variance.
166        
167        Returns
168        -------
169        pd.Series 
170            A pandas Series
171
172        Example
173        --------
174        >>> Statistics(df).variance('sample')
175
176        >>> Statistics(df).variance('population')
177        """
178        if not isinstance(method, str):
179            raise TypeError(f'method must be a string, got {type(method).__name__}')
180        
181        if method not in ['sample', 'population']:
182            raise ValueError(f"method must either be 'sample' or 'population', got {method}")
183
184        n = len(self.df)
185                
186        if method == 'sample':
187
188            return ((self.df - self.df.mean())**2).sum()/(n-1)
189
190        elif method == 'population':
191
192            return ((self.df - self.df.mean())**2).sum()/(n)

Computes variance.

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Example

>>> Statistics(df).variance('sample')

>>> Statistics(df).variance('population')
def median_absolute_deviation(self) -> pandas.core.series.Series: 
194    def median_absolute_deviation(self) -> pd.Series :
195        """
196        Computes the MAD (Median Absolute Deviation).
197
198        Returns
199        --------
200        pd.Series
201            A pandas Series
202
203        Example
204        --------
205        >>> Statistics(df).median_absolute_deviation()
206        """
207        median = self.df.median()
208
209        # subtracting median value from the values
210        return (self.df.sub(median)).abs().median()

Computes the MAD (Median Absolute Deviation).

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Example

>>> Statistics(df).median_absolute_deviation()
def scaled_median_absolute_deviation(self) -> pandas.core.series.Series: 
212    def scaled_median_absolute_deviation(self)-> pd.Series:
213        """
214        Computes the scaled MAD (Median Absolute Deviation), which is ~1.4826 * median_absolute_deviation().
215
216        Returns
217        --------
218        pd.Series
219            A pandas Series
220
221        Example
222        --------
223        >>> Statistics(df).scaled_median_absolute_deviation()
224        """
225        return 1.4826 * Statistics(self.df).median_absolute_deviation()

Computes the scaled MAD (Median Absolute Deviation), which is ~1.4826 * median_absolute_deviation().

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Example

>>> Statistics(df).scaled_median_absolute_deviation()
class Distribution(datalab.tabular.computations.Computation.Computation): 
  9class Distribution(Computation):
 10    """
 11        Initializing Distribution Computation.
 12
 13        Parameters
 14        -----------
 15        df: pd.DataFrame
 16            A pandas DataFrame
 17
 18        columns: list, optional
 19            A list of columns you wish to compute distribution in, default is None.
 20    """
 21
 22    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None):
 23
 24        import pandas as pd
 25
 26        super().__init__(df, columns)
 27
 28        self.df = df
 29
 30        if columns is None:
 31            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
 32        else:
 33            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns] 
 34    
 35    def compute_histogram(self, n_bins: int =30, density: bool =False, df_axis: int=1) -> pd.DataFrame:
 36        """
 37        Pre-Computes a histogram.
 38
 39        Parameters
 40        -----------
 41        n_bins : int, optional
 42            Number of bins to use in the histogram, by default 30.
 43
 44        df_axis: int, optional
 45            Whether you wish to see a concatenated dataframe column wise or row wise, default is 1.
 46
 47            Available options:
 48
 49            - 0 : Shows a concatenated dataframe row wise.
 50            - 1 : Shows a concatenated dataframe column wise (default).
 51        
 52        density :bool, optional 
 53            Density is used when we want to see histogram in terms of proabability distributions like normal, exponential or uniform and all, by default False.
 54            
 55            If False, 
 56                It usually shows how many values fall in each bin
 57                
 58            If True, 
 59                It usually shows how likely values are to fill within each range - i.e., the probability density.
 60                The total area under the histogram equals to 1.
 61
 62        Returns
 63        --------
 64        pd.DataFrame
 65            A pandas DataFrame 
 66    
 67        Usage Recommendation
 68        --------------------
 69            Use this function if you want a pre-computed histogram for calculations.
 70        
 71        Considerations
 72        ---------------
 73            This function returns a Concatenated DataFrame of counts, bin_edges and bin_centers of a histogram.
 74
 75        Example
 76        ---------
 77        >>> Distribution(df).compute_histogram(n_bins=50) 
 78
 79        >>> Distribution(df).compute_histogram(density=True)
 80        """ 
 81
 82        if not isinstance(n_bins, int):
 83            raise TypeError(f'n_bins (number of bins) must be an int, got {type(n_bins).__name__}')
 84
 85        if not isinstance(density, bool):
 86            raise TypeError(f'density must be a bool, got {type(density).__name__}')
 87
 88        if not isinstance(df_axis, int):
 89            raise TypeError(f'df_axis must be a bool, got {type(df_axis).__name__}')
 90
 91        if df_axis not in [0, 1]:
 92            raise ValueError(f"df_axis must either be 0 (for combining df row-wise) or 1 (for combining df column-wise), got {df_axis}")
 93
 94        import numpy as np
 95
 96        counts_dict = {}
 97        bin_edges_dict = {}
 98        bin_centers_dict = {}
 99
100        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
101            
102            # computing counts and bin edges
103            counts, bin_edges = np.histogram(self.df[col], bins = n_bins, density=density)
104
105            # computing bin centers
106            bin_centers = 0.5 * (bin_edges[1:] + bin_edges[:-1])
107
108            counts_dict[col] = counts
109            bin_edges_dict[col] = bin_edges
110            bin_centers_dict[col] = bin_centers
111
112        counts_df = pd.DataFrame(counts_dict)
113        bin_edges_df = pd.DataFrame(bin_edges_dict)
114        bin_centers_df = pd.DataFrame(bin_centers_dict)
115
116        # returning a concatenated df
117        histogram_df = pd.concat({"counts": counts_df, "bin_edges" : bin_edges_df, "bin_centers" : bin_centers_df}, axis=df_axis, ignore_index=False)
118
119        return histogram_df
120
121    def raw_kurtosis(self) -> pd.DataFrame :
122        """
123        Computes the raw kurtosis for each numerical column of your DataFrame.
124
125        Raw Kurtosis:
126
127            1. It measures how the tails or peaks of a distribution differ from a normal distribution (bell-curve)
128            2. It observes whether the data has more or fewer outliers (extreme values) than a normal distribution.
129            3. For a normal distribution, kurtosis value is very close to 3
130
131            - kurtosis > 3 means the data has heavy tails (more outliers).
132            - kurtosis ~ 3 means the data is close to normal.
133            - kurtosis < 3 means the data has light tails (fewer outliers).
134
135        Formula
136        --------
137            raw_kurtosis = (average of (x - mean)^4) / (variance^2)
138
139        Returns
140        --------
141        pd.Series
142            A pandas Series
143
144        Usage Recommendation
145        ---------------------
146            1. Use raw kurtosis if you are comparing several distributions mathematically.
147            2. Use excess kurtosis if you are comparing to a normal distribution
148
149        Example
150        ---------
151        >>> Distribution(df).raw_kurtosis()
152        """ 
153        n = len(self.df)
154
155        mean = Statistics(self.df).mean()
156        std_dev = Statistics(self.df).standard_deviation()
157
158        fourth_central_moment = (((self.df - mean)**4).sum())/n
159
160        raw_kurtosis = fourth_central_moment / ((std_dev)**4)
161
162        return raw_kurtosis.to_frame(name='raw_kurtosis')
163
164    def excess_kurtosis(self) -> pd.DataFrame :
165        """
166        Computes the excess kurtosis for each numerical column of your DataFrame.
167
168        Excess Kurtosis:
169
170            1. It measures how the tails or peaks of a distribution differ from a normal distribution (bell-curve)
171            2. It observes whether your data has many outliers (extreme values).
172            3. For a normal distribution, excess kurtosis value is very close to 0
173
174            - kurtosis > 0 means the data has heavy tails (more outliers).
175            - kurtosis ~ 0 means the data is close to normal.
176            - kurtosis < 0 means the data has light tails (fewer outliers).
177
178        Formula
179        --------
180            excess kurtosis = raw kurtosis - 3
181
182        Returns
183        --------
184        pd.Series
185            A pandas Series
186
187        Usage Recommendation
188        ---------------------
189            1. Use excess kurtosis if you are comparing to a normal distribution
190            2. Use raw kurtosis if you are comparing several distributions mathematically.
191        
192        Example
193        ---------
194        >>> Distribution(df).excess_kurtosis()
195        """
196
197        raw_kurtosis = Distribution(self.df).raw_kurtosis()
198
199        excess_kurtosis = raw_kurtosis['raw_kurtosis'] - 3
200
201        return excess_kurtosis.to_frame(name='excess_kurtosis')
202
203    def compute_kde(self, bandwidth_method:str ='silverman',n_bins: int =30, density: bool =False)-> pd.DataFrame:
204
205        import numpy as np
206        import pandas as pd
207        from scipy.signal import fftconvolve
208        """
209        Computes the KDE (Kernel Density Estimation).
210
211        KDE is just a smoothened histogram where bars are converted into curves
212        Instead of showing counts per bin, KDE uses a smooth kernel (a bell-shaped curve) to estimate the probability distribution.
213
214        Formula
215        --------
216            K(x)= e^(-x^2/2(h^2)) , where h is the Bandwidth that controls how wide the bump should be
217
218        Parameters
219        -----------
220        bandwidth_method: str, optional
221            Bandwidth method decides how wide each bump is when smoothing data for KDE, default is 'silverman'.
222
223            Bandwidth methods available:
224
225            For Normal Distribution
226
227            - 'silverman' : 1.06 * std * (n ** (-1/5)) 
228            - 'scott':  std * (n ** (-1/5)) , same as silverman without the optimized constant 1.06
229
230            For Skewed Distribution
231
232            - 'robust': (IQR/1.349) * (n ** (-1/5)) , uses IQR instead of standard deviation
233
234        n_bins : int, optional
235            Number of bins to use in the histogram, by default 30.
236        
237        density :bool, optional 
238            Density is used when we want to see histogram in terms of probability instead of raw counts, by default False.
239            
240            If False, 
241                It usually shows count of values that fall in each bin
242                
243            If True, 
244                It usually shows how likely values are to fill within each range - i.e., the probability density.
245                The total area under the histogram equals to 1.
246
247        Returns
248        --------
249        pd.DataFrame
250            A pandas DataFrame 
251
252        Usage Recommendation
253        --------------------
254            1. Use this function when you want to compute KDE values, for visualization or analysis
255            2. Use 'silverman' or 'scott' as bandwidth method if your data has normal distribution.
256            3. Use 'robust' if your data has skewed distribution.
257
258        Considerations
259        ---------------
260            This function calculates bandwidth (width of bump) separately for each column, which is why it is a bit slower.
261        
262        Example
263        -------
264        >>> Distribution(df).compute_kde()
265
266        >>> Distribution(df).compute_kde('scott', n_bins = 50)
267        """
268        from .Statistics import Statistics
269
270        n = len(self.df)
271
272        std_dev =Statistics(self.df).standard_deviation()
273
274        IQR = Statistics(self.df).iqr()
275
276        histogram = Distribution(self.df).compute_histogram(n_bins=n_bins, density=density)
277        
278        KDE_dict = {}
279
280        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
281
282            if bandwidth_method == 'scott':
283
284                bandwidth = std_dev[column] * (n ** (-1/5))
285                
286            elif bandwidth_method == 'silverman':
287
288                bandwidth = 1.06 * std_dev[column] * (n ** (-1/5))
289
290            else:
291                # robust scott, uses IQR instead of standard deviation
292                bandwidth = (IQR[column]/1.349) * (n ** (-1/5))
293
294            bw = float(bandwidth)
295
296            if not np.isfinite(bw) or bw<=0:
297                raise ValueError(f'Invalid bandwidth for column {column}: {bw}')
298
299            # importing the Distrubution computation and using bin centers to compute KDE since it is easier that way
300            bin_centers = histogram['bin_centers'][column].dropna()
301            counts = histogram['counts'][column].dropna()
302            
303            # calculating grid size using bin_centers 
304            grid_size = len(bin_centers)
305
306            # creating an artifical axis around zero, for kernel
307            x_axis = np.linspace(-3 * bw, 3 * bw, grid_size)
308
309            x_axis = np.asarray(x_axis, dtype=float)
310            
311            # creating kernel for making the curve
312            kernel = np.exp((-x_axis**2)/(2 * bw**2))
313            
314            # making sure all values add up to 1
315            kernel/=kernel.sum()
316
317            # Using Fourier's for convolution (sliding across histogram like in neural nets)
318            KDE = fftconvolve(counts, kernel, mode='same')
319
320            KDE_dict[column] = KDE
321
322        return pd.DataFrame(KDE_dict)

Initializing Distribution Computation.

Parameters

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

columns: list, optional A list of columns you wish to compute distribution in, default is None.

Distribution(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None) 
22    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None):
23
24        import pandas as pd
25
26        super().__init__(df, columns)
27
28        self.df = df
29
30        if columns is None:
31            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
32        else:
33            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
df
def compute_histogram( self, n_bins: int = 30, density: bool = False, df_axis: int = 1) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
 35    def compute_histogram(self, n_bins: int =30, density: bool =False, df_axis: int=1) -> pd.DataFrame:
 36        """
 37        Pre-Computes a histogram.
 38
 39        Parameters
 40        -----------
 41        n_bins : int, optional
 42            Number of bins to use in the histogram, by default 30.
 43
 44        df_axis: int, optional
 45            Whether you wish to see a concatenated dataframe column wise or row wise, default is 1.
 46
 47            Available options:
 48
 49            - 0 : Shows a concatenated dataframe row wise.
 50            - 1 : Shows a concatenated dataframe column wise (default).
 51        
 52        density :bool, optional 
 53            Density is used when we want to see histogram in terms of proabability distributions like normal, exponential or uniform and all, by default False.
 54            
 55            If False, 
 56                It usually shows how many values fall in each bin
 57                
 58            If True, 
 59                It usually shows how likely values are to fill within each range - i.e., the probability density.
 60                The total area under the histogram equals to 1.
 61
 62        Returns
 63        --------
 64        pd.DataFrame
 65            A pandas DataFrame 
 66    
 67        Usage Recommendation
 68        --------------------
 69            Use this function if you want a pre-computed histogram for calculations.
 70        
 71        Considerations
 72        ---------------
 73            This function returns a Concatenated DataFrame of counts, bin_edges and bin_centers of a histogram.
 74
 75        Example
 76        ---------
 77        >>> Distribution(df).compute_histogram(n_bins=50) 
 78
 79        >>> Distribution(df).compute_histogram(density=True)
 80        """ 
 81
 82        if not isinstance(n_bins, int):
 83            raise TypeError(f'n_bins (number of bins) must be an int, got {type(n_bins).__name__}')
 84
 85        if not isinstance(density, bool):
 86            raise TypeError(f'density must be a bool, got {type(density).__name__}')
 87
 88        if not isinstance(df_axis, int):
 89            raise TypeError(f'df_axis must be a bool, got {type(df_axis).__name__}')
 90
 91        if df_axis not in [0, 1]:
 92            raise ValueError(f"df_axis must either be 0 (for combining df row-wise) or 1 (for combining df column-wise), got {df_axis}")
 93
 94        import numpy as np
 95
 96        counts_dict = {}
 97        bin_edges_dict = {}
 98        bin_centers_dict = {}
 99
100        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
101            
102            # computing counts and bin edges
103            counts, bin_edges = np.histogram(self.df[col], bins = n_bins, density=density)
104
105            # computing bin centers
106            bin_centers = 0.5 * (bin_edges[1:] + bin_edges[:-1])
107
108            counts_dict[col] = counts
109            bin_edges_dict[col] = bin_edges
110            bin_centers_dict[col] = bin_centers
111
112        counts_df = pd.DataFrame(counts_dict)
113        bin_edges_df = pd.DataFrame(bin_edges_dict)
114        bin_centers_df = pd.DataFrame(bin_centers_dict)
115
116        # returning a concatenated df
117        histogram_df = pd.concat({"counts": counts_df, "bin_edges" : bin_edges_df, "bin_centers" : bin_centers_df}, axis=df_axis, ignore_index=False)
118
119        return histogram_df

Pre-Computes a histogram.

Parameters

n_bins : int, optional Number of bins to use in the histogram, by default 30.

df_axis: int, optional Whether you wish to see a concatenated dataframe column wise or row wise, default is 1.

Available options:

- 0 : Shows a concatenated dataframe row wise.
- 1 : Shows a concatenated dataframe column wise (default).

density :bool, optional Density is used when we want to see histogram in terms of proabability distributions like normal, exponential or uniform and all, by default False.

If False, 
    It usually shows how many values fall in each bin

If True, 
    It usually shows how likely values are to fill within each range - i.e., the probability density.
    The total area under the histogram equals to 1.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use this function if you want a pre-computed histogram for calculations.

Considerations

This function returns a Concatenated DataFrame of counts, bin_edges and bin_centers of a histogram.

Example

>>> Distribution(df).compute_histogram(n_bins=50) 

>>> Distribution(df).compute_histogram(density=True)
def raw_kurtosis(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
121    def raw_kurtosis(self) -> pd.DataFrame :
122        """
123        Computes the raw kurtosis for each numerical column of your DataFrame.
124
125        Raw Kurtosis:
126
127            1. It measures how the tails or peaks of a distribution differ from a normal distribution (bell-curve)
128            2. It observes whether the data has more or fewer outliers (extreme values) than a normal distribution.
129            3. For a normal distribution, kurtosis value is very close to 3
130
131            - kurtosis > 3 means the data has heavy tails (more outliers).
132            - kurtosis ~ 3 means the data is close to normal.
133            - kurtosis < 3 means the data has light tails (fewer outliers).
134
135        Formula
136        --------
137            raw_kurtosis = (average of (x - mean)^4) / (variance^2)
138
139        Returns
140        --------
141        pd.Series
142            A pandas Series
143
144        Usage Recommendation
145        ---------------------
146            1. Use raw kurtosis if you are comparing several distributions mathematically.
147            2. Use excess kurtosis if you are comparing to a normal distribution
148
149        Example
150        ---------
151        >>> Distribution(df).raw_kurtosis()
152        """ 
153        n = len(self.df)
154
155        mean = Statistics(self.df).mean()
156        std_dev = Statistics(self.df).standard_deviation()
157
158        fourth_central_moment = (((self.df - mean)**4).sum())/n
159
160        raw_kurtosis = fourth_central_moment / ((std_dev)**4)
161
162        return raw_kurtosis.to_frame(name='raw_kurtosis')

Computes the raw kurtosis for each numerical column of your DataFrame.

Raw Kurtosis:

1. It measures how the tails or peaks of a distribution differ from a normal distribution (bell-curve)
2. It observes whether the data has more or fewer outliers (extreme values) than a normal distribution.
3. For a normal distribution, kurtosis value is very close to 3

- kurtosis > 3 means the data has heavy tails (more outliers).
- kurtosis ~ 3 means the data is close to normal.
- kurtosis < 3 means the data has light tails (fewer outliers).

Formula

raw_kurtosis = (average of (x - mean)^4) / (variance^2)

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Usage Recommendation

1. Use raw kurtosis if you are comparing several distributions mathematically.
2. Use excess kurtosis if you are comparing to a normal distribution

Example

>>> Distribution(df).raw_kurtosis()
def excess_kurtosis(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
164    def excess_kurtosis(self) -> pd.DataFrame :
165        """
166        Computes the excess kurtosis for each numerical column of your DataFrame.
167
168        Excess Kurtosis:
169
170            1. It measures how the tails or peaks of a distribution differ from a normal distribution (bell-curve)
171            2. It observes whether your data has many outliers (extreme values).
172            3. For a normal distribution, excess kurtosis value is very close to 0
173
174            - kurtosis > 0 means the data has heavy tails (more outliers).
175            - kurtosis ~ 0 means the data is close to normal.
176            - kurtosis < 0 means the data has light tails (fewer outliers).
177
178        Formula
179        --------
180            excess kurtosis = raw kurtosis - 3
181
182        Returns
183        --------
184        pd.Series
185            A pandas Series
186
187        Usage Recommendation
188        ---------------------
189            1. Use excess kurtosis if you are comparing to a normal distribution
190            2. Use raw kurtosis if you are comparing several distributions mathematically.
191        
192        Example
193        ---------
194        >>> Distribution(df).excess_kurtosis()
195        """
196
197        raw_kurtosis = Distribution(self.df).raw_kurtosis()
198
199        excess_kurtosis = raw_kurtosis['raw_kurtosis'] - 3
200
201        return excess_kurtosis.to_frame(name='excess_kurtosis')

Computes the excess kurtosis for each numerical column of your DataFrame.

Excess Kurtosis:

1. It measures how the tails or peaks of a distribution differ from a normal distribution (bell-curve)
2. It observes whether your data has many outliers (extreme values).
3. For a normal distribution, excess kurtosis value is very close to 0

- kurtosis > 0 means the data has heavy tails (more outliers).
- kurtosis ~ 0 means the data is close to normal.
- kurtosis < 0 means the data has light tails (fewer outliers).

Formula

excess kurtosis = raw kurtosis - 3

Returns

pd.Series A pandas Series

Usage Recommendation

1. Use excess kurtosis if you are comparing to a normal distribution
2. Use raw kurtosis if you are comparing several distributions mathematically.

Example

>>> Distribution(df).excess_kurtosis()
def compute_kde( self, bandwidth_method: str = 'silverman', n_bins: int = 30, density: bool = False) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
203    def compute_kde(self, bandwidth_method:str ='silverman',n_bins: int =30, density: bool =False)-> pd.DataFrame:
204
205        import numpy as np
206        import pandas as pd
207        from scipy.signal import fftconvolve
208        """
209        Computes the KDE (Kernel Density Estimation).
210
211        KDE is just a smoothened histogram where bars are converted into curves
212        Instead of showing counts per bin, KDE uses a smooth kernel (a bell-shaped curve) to estimate the probability distribution.
213
214        Formula
215        --------
216            K(x)= e^(-x^2/2(h^2)) , where h is the Bandwidth that controls how wide the bump should be
217
218        Parameters
219        -----------
220        bandwidth_method: str, optional
221            Bandwidth method decides how wide each bump is when smoothing data for KDE, default is 'silverman'.
222
223            Bandwidth methods available:
224
225            For Normal Distribution
226
227            - 'silverman' : 1.06 * std * (n ** (-1/5)) 
228            - 'scott':  std * (n ** (-1/5)) , same as silverman without the optimized constant 1.06
229
230            For Skewed Distribution
231
232            - 'robust': (IQR/1.349) * (n ** (-1/5)) , uses IQR instead of standard deviation
233
234        n_bins : int, optional
235            Number of bins to use in the histogram, by default 30.
236        
237        density :bool, optional 
238            Density is used when we want to see histogram in terms of probability instead of raw counts, by default False.
239            
240            If False, 
241                It usually shows count of values that fall in each bin
242                
243            If True, 
244                It usually shows how likely values are to fill within each range - i.e., the probability density.
245                The total area under the histogram equals to 1.
246
247        Returns
248        --------
249        pd.DataFrame
250            A pandas DataFrame 
251
252        Usage Recommendation
253        --------------------
254            1. Use this function when you want to compute KDE values, for visualization or analysis
255            2. Use 'silverman' or 'scott' as bandwidth method if your data has normal distribution.
256            3. Use 'robust' if your data has skewed distribution.
257
258        Considerations
259        ---------------
260            This function calculates bandwidth (width of bump) separately for each column, which is why it is a bit slower.
261        
262        Example
263        -------
264        >>> Distribution(df).compute_kde()
265
266        >>> Distribution(df).compute_kde('scott', n_bins = 50)
267        """
268        from .Statistics import Statistics
269
270        n = len(self.df)
271
272        std_dev =Statistics(self.df).standard_deviation()
273
274        IQR = Statistics(self.df).iqr()
275
276        histogram = Distribution(self.df).compute_histogram(n_bins=n_bins, density=density)
277        
278        KDE_dict = {}
279
280        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
281
282            if bandwidth_method == 'scott':
283
284                bandwidth = std_dev[column] * (n ** (-1/5))
285                
286            elif bandwidth_method == 'silverman':
287
288                bandwidth = 1.06 * std_dev[column] * (n ** (-1/5))
289
290            else:
291                # robust scott, uses IQR instead of standard deviation
292                bandwidth = (IQR[column]/1.349) * (n ** (-1/5))
293
294            bw = float(bandwidth)
295
296            if not np.isfinite(bw) or bw<=0:
297                raise ValueError(f'Invalid bandwidth for column {column}: {bw}')
298
299            # importing the Distrubution computation and using bin centers to compute KDE since it is easier that way
300            bin_centers = histogram['bin_centers'][column].dropna()
301            counts = histogram['counts'][column].dropna()
302            
303            # calculating grid size using bin_centers 
304            grid_size = len(bin_centers)
305
306            # creating an artifical axis around zero, for kernel
307            x_axis = np.linspace(-3 * bw, 3 * bw, grid_size)
308
309            x_axis = np.asarray(x_axis, dtype=float)
310            
311            # creating kernel for making the curve
312            kernel = np.exp((-x_axis**2)/(2 * bw**2))
313            
314            # making sure all values add up to 1
315            kernel/=kernel.sum()
316
317            # Using Fourier's for convolution (sliding across histogram like in neural nets)
318            KDE = fftconvolve(counts, kernel, mode='same')
319
320            KDE_dict[column] = KDE
321
322        return pd.DataFrame(KDE_dict)
class Outliers(datalab.tabular.computations.Computation.Computation): 
  7class Outliers(Computation):
  8    """
  9    Initializing Outliers Computation.
 10        
 11    Parameters
 12    -----------
 13    df: pd.DataFrame
 14        A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose.
 15
 16    columns: list, optional
 17        A list of columns you wish to detect outliers in, default is None.
 18    """
 19    
 20    def __init__(self, df:pd.DataFrame, columns:list=None):
 21
 22        import pandas as pd
 23        import numpy as np
 24
 25        super().__init__(df, columns)
 26
 27        self.df = df
 28
 29        if columns is None:
 30            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
 31        else:
 32            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 33
 34    def zscore_outliers(self, zscore_threshold: int|float = 3)-> pd.DataFrame:
 35        """
 36        Computes outliers in a column using the Z-score method.
 37
 38        Parameters
 39        ----------
 40        zscore_threshold : int or float, optional
 41            z-score value above which a value is flagged as an outlier, default is 3.
 42
 43        Returns
 44        -------
 45        pd.DataFrame
 46            A pandas DataFrame
 47
 48        Usage Recommendation
 49        --------------------
 50            Use when data is roughly normal and you want to flag values far from the overall mean(average).
 51        
 52        Considerations
 53        --------------
 54            1. This method keeps rows with values that are not outliers and they automatically convert to NaN.
 55            2. However, those rows remain preserved since this method is just meant purely for computation.
 56            3. Typically, values with |Z-score| > 3 are considered outliers.
 57
 58        Example
 59        -------
 60        >>> Outliers(df).zscore_outliers()
 61        >>> Outliers(df).zscore_outliers(zscore_threshold=3)
 62        """
 63
 64        if not isinstance(zscore_threshold, (int,float)):
 65            raise TypeError(f'threshold must be an integer, got {type(zscore_threshold).__name__}')
 66
 67        zscore = (self.df - self.df.mean())/self.df.std()
 68
 69        # In practice, anything over a z_score of over +3 or less than -3 is considered an outlier.
 70        zscore_outliers = self.df[(zscore.abs()) > zscore_threshold]
 71
 72        return zscore_outliers
 73
 74    def iqr_outliers(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
 75        """
 76        Computes outliers in a column using the IQR (Inter-Quartile Range) method.
 77
 78        Returns
 79        -------
 80        pd.DataFrame
 81            A pandas DataFrame
 82
 83        Usage Recommendation
 84        --------------------
 85            Use for skewed data or unknown distributions to detect values outside the typical range.
 86
 87        Considerations
 88        --------------
 89            1. This method keeps rows with values that are not outliers and they automatically convert to NaN.
 90            2. However, those rows remain preserved since this method is just meant purely for computation.
 91            3. Outliers are those below (q1 - 1.5 x IQR) or above (q3 + 1.5 x IQR).
 92
 93        Example
 94        -------
 95        >>> Outliers(df).iqr_outliers()
 96        """
 97        # calculating 25th and 75th percentiles
 98
 99        q1 = self.df.quantile(0.25)               # 1st quartile
100        q3 = self.df.quantile(0.75)               # 3rd quartile
101
102        # calculating IQR.
103        IQR = q3 - q1
104
105        # setting lower and upper boundaries.
106        lower_boundary = q1 - (1.5 * IQR)
107        upper_boundary = q3 + (1.5 * IQR)
108
109        # outliers are values that are lower than lower boundary or higher than higher boundary.
110        iqr_outliers = self.df[(self.df < lower_boundary) | (self.df > upper_boundary)]
111
112        return iqr_outliers
113
114    def quantile_outliers(self, lower_quantile: int|float|None = None , upper_quantile: int|float|None = None) -> pd.DataFrame:
115        """
116        Computes outliers in a column using the user-defined quantiles.
117
118        Parameters
119        ----------
120        lower_quantile: int or float, optional
121            percentile below which a value is flagged as an outlier, default is 0.01.
122
123        upper_quantile: int or float, optional
124            percentile above which a value is flagged as an outlier, default is 0.99.
125
126        Returns
127        -------
128        pd.DataFrame
129            A pandas DataFrame
130
131        Usage Recommendation
132        --------------------
133            Use when you have domain knowledge or want custom thresholds for outliers.
134
135        Considerations
136        --------------
137            1. This method keeps rows with values that are not outliers and they automatically convert to NaN.
138            2. However, those rows remain preserved since this method is just meant purely for computation.
139            3. Values below the 10th percentile or above the 99th percentile.
140
141        Example
142        -------
143        >>> Outliers(df).quantile_outliers()
144
145        >>> Outliers(df).quantile_outliers(0.02, 0.98)
146        """
147        if not isinstance(lower_quantile, (int, float, type(None))):
148            raise TypeError(f'lower quantile must be an int or float, got {type(lower_quantile).__name__}')
149
150        if not isinstance(upper_quantile, (int, float, type(None))):
151            raise TypeError(f'upper quantile must be an int or float, got {type(upper_quantile).__name__}')
152
153        if lower_quantile is None:
154            lower_quantile = 0.01  # 1st percentile
155        if upper_quantile is None:
156            upper_quantile = 0.99  # 99th percentile
157
158        # lower boundary would be any quantile passed in by the user.
159        lower_boundary = self.df.quantile(q=lower_quantile)
160        
161        # upper boundary would be any quantile passed in by the user.
162        upper_boundary = self.df.quantile(q=upper_quantile)
163
164        # outliers are values that are lower than lower boundary or higher than higher boundary.
165        quantile_outliers = self.df[(self.df < lower_boundary) | (self.df > upper_boundary)]
166
167        return quantile_outliers

Initializing Outliers Computation.

Parameters

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose.

columns: list, optional A list of columns you wish to detect outliers in, default is None.

Outliers(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None) 
20    def __init__(self, df:pd.DataFrame, columns:list=None):
21
22        import pandas as pd
23        import numpy as np
24
25        super().__init__(df, columns)
26
27        self.df = df
28
29        if columns is None:
30            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
31        else:
32            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
df
def zscore_outliers(self, zscore_threshold: int | float = 3) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
34    def zscore_outliers(self, zscore_threshold: int|float = 3)-> pd.DataFrame:
35        """
36        Computes outliers in a column using the Z-score method.
37
38        Parameters
39        ----------
40        zscore_threshold : int or float, optional
41            z-score value above which a value is flagged as an outlier, default is 3.
42
43        Returns
44        -------
45        pd.DataFrame
46            A pandas DataFrame
47
48        Usage Recommendation
49        --------------------
50            Use when data is roughly normal and you want to flag values far from the overall mean(average).
51        
52        Considerations
53        --------------
54            1. This method keeps rows with values that are not outliers and they automatically convert to NaN.
55            2. However, those rows remain preserved since this method is just meant purely for computation.
56            3. Typically, values with |Z-score| > 3 are considered outliers.
57
58        Example
59        -------
60        >>> Outliers(df).zscore_outliers()
61        >>> Outliers(df).zscore_outliers(zscore_threshold=3)
62        """
63
64        if not isinstance(zscore_threshold, (int,float)):
65            raise TypeError(f'threshold must be an integer, got {type(zscore_threshold).__name__}')
66
67        zscore = (self.df - self.df.mean())/self.df.std()
68
69        # In practice, anything over a z_score of over +3 or less than -3 is considered an outlier.
70        zscore_outliers = self.df[(zscore.abs()) > zscore_threshold]
71
72        return zscore_outliers

Computes outliers in a column using the Z-score method.

Parameters

zscore_threshold : int or float, optional z-score value above which a value is flagged as an outlier, default is 3.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use when data is roughly normal and you want to flag values far from the overall mean(average).

Considerations

1. This method keeps rows with values that are not outliers and they automatically convert to NaN.
2. However, those rows remain preserved since this method is just meant purely for computation.
3. Typically, values with |Z-score| > 3 are considered outliers.

Example

>>> Outliers(df).zscore_outliers()
>>> Outliers(df).zscore_outliers(zscore_threshold=3)
def iqr_outliers(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
 74    def iqr_outliers(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
 75        """
 76        Computes outliers in a column using the IQR (Inter-Quartile Range) method.
 77
 78        Returns
 79        -------
 80        pd.DataFrame
 81            A pandas DataFrame
 82
 83        Usage Recommendation
 84        --------------------
 85            Use for skewed data or unknown distributions to detect values outside the typical range.
 86
 87        Considerations
 88        --------------
 89            1. This method keeps rows with values that are not outliers and they automatically convert to NaN.
 90            2. However, those rows remain preserved since this method is just meant purely for computation.
 91            3. Outliers are those below (q1 - 1.5 x IQR) or above (q3 + 1.5 x IQR).
 92
 93        Example
 94        -------
 95        >>> Outliers(df).iqr_outliers()
 96        """
 97        # calculating 25th and 75th percentiles
 98
 99        q1 = self.df.quantile(0.25)               # 1st quartile
100        q3 = self.df.quantile(0.75)               # 3rd quartile
101
102        # calculating IQR.
103        IQR = q3 - q1
104
105        # setting lower and upper boundaries.
106        lower_boundary = q1 - (1.5 * IQR)
107        upper_boundary = q3 + (1.5 * IQR)
108
109        # outliers are values that are lower than lower boundary or higher than higher boundary.
110        iqr_outliers = self.df[(self.df < lower_boundary) | (self.df > upper_boundary)]
111
112        return iqr_outliers

Computes outliers in a column using the IQR (Inter-Quartile Range) method.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use for skewed data or unknown distributions to detect values outside the typical range.

Considerations

1. This method keeps rows with values that are not outliers and they automatically convert to NaN.
2. However, those rows remain preserved since this method is just meant purely for computation.
3. Outliers are those below (q1 - 1.5 x IQR) or above (q3 + 1.5 x IQR).

Example

>>> Outliers(df).iqr_outliers()
def quantile_outliers( self, lower_quantile: int | float | None = None, upper_quantile: int | float | None = None) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
114    def quantile_outliers(self, lower_quantile: int|float|None = None , upper_quantile: int|float|None = None) -> pd.DataFrame:
115        """
116        Computes outliers in a column using the user-defined quantiles.
117
118        Parameters
119        ----------
120        lower_quantile: int or float, optional
121            percentile below which a value is flagged as an outlier, default is 0.01.
122
123        upper_quantile: int or float, optional
124            percentile above which a value is flagged as an outlier, default is 0.99.
125
126        Returns
127        -------
128        pd.DataFrame
129            A pandas DataFrame
130
131        Usage Recommendation
132        --------------------
133            Use when you have domain knowledge or want custom thresholds for outliers.
134
135        Considerations
136        --------------
137            1. This method keeps rows with values that are not outliers and they automatically convert to NaN.
138            2. However, those rows remain preserved since this method is just meant purely for computation.
139            3. Values below the 10th percentile or above the 99th percentile.
140
141        Example
142        -------
143        >>> Outliers(df).quantile_outliers()
144
145        >>> Outliers(df).quantile_outliers(0.02, 0.98)
146        """
147        if not isinstance(lower_quantile, (int, float, type(None))):
148            raise TypeError(f'lower quantile must be an int or float, got {type(lower_quantile).__name__}')
149
150        if not isinstance(upper_quantile, (int, float, type(None))):
151            raise TypeError(f'upper quantile must be an int or float, got {type(upper_quantile).__name__}')
152
153        if lower_quantile is None:
154            lower_quantile = 0.01  # 1st percentile
155        if upper_quantile is None:
156            upper_quantile = 0.99  # 99th percentile
157
158        # lower boundary would be any quantile passed in by the user.
159        lower_boundary = self.df.quantile(q=lower_quantile)
160        
161        # upper boundary would be any quantile passed in by the user.
162        upper_boundary = self.df.quantile(q=upper_quantile)
163
164        # outliers are values that are lower than lower boundary or higher than higher boundary.
165        quantile_outliers = self.df[(self.df < lower_boundary) | (self.df > upper_boundary)]
166
167        return quantile_outliers

Computes outliers in a column using the user-defined quantiles.

Parameters

lower_quantile: int or float, optional percentile below which a value is flagged as an outlier, default is 0.01.

upper_quantile: int or float, optional percentile above which a value is flagged as an outlier, default is 0.99.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use when you have domain knowledge or want custom thresholds for outliers.

Considerations

1. This method keeps rows with values that are not outliers and they automatically convert to NaN.
2. However, those rows remain preserved since this method is just meant purely for computation.
3. Values below the 10th percentile or above the 99th percentile.

Example

>>> Outliers(df).quantile_outliers()

>>> Outliers(df).quantile_outliers(0.02, 0.98)
class Correlation(datalab.tabular.computations.Computation.Computation): 
11class Correlation(Computation):
12    """
13    Initializing the Correlation Computation .
14
15    Parameters
16    -----------
17    df: pd.DataFrame
18        A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose.
19
20    columns: list, optional
21        A list of columns you wish to check correlation for, by default None.
22    """
23
24    def __init__(self, df:pd.DataFrame, columns:list=None):
25
26        super().__init__(df, columns)
27
28        self.df = df
29        
30        if columns is None:
31            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
32        else:
33            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
34
35        logger.info(f'Correlation initialized.')
36
37    def covariance(self):
38        """
39        Computes the covariance matrix of a pandas DataFrame.
40
41        Covariance shows how two columns (variables) change together:
42
43        - Positive -> both increase together
44        - Negative -> one increases while the other decreases
45        - Zero -> mostly independent
46
47        Returns
48        -------
49        pd.DataFrame
50            A pandas DataFrame
51
52        Example
53        -------
54        >>> Correlation(df).covariance()
55        """
56        return self.df.cov()
57        
58    def correlation(self, method:str = 'pearson'):
59        """
60        Computes the correlation matrix of a pandas DataFrame.
61
62        Pearson correlation measures how strongly two variables are linearly related:
63
64        - +1 -> perfectly positively correlated
65        - -1 -> perfectly negatively correlated
66        - 0  -> no linear correlation
67
68        Parameters
69        -----------
70            method: str, optional
71                Method using which you would like to calculate correlation, default is 'pearson'.
72
73                Available methods:
74
75                - 'pearson': measures how much two columns go up or down together in a straight-line.
76                - 'spearman': measures how much two columns move together based on their ranking order.
77                - 'kendall': measures how often two columns move in the same direction when comparing all pairs.
78
79        Returns
80        -------
81        pd.DataFrame
82            A pandas DataFrame
83
84        Example
85        -------
86        >>> Correlation(df).correlation()
87        >>> Correlation(df).correlation('spearman')
88        >>> Correlation(df).correlation('kendall')
89        """
90
91        if not isinstance(method, str):
92            raise TypeError(f'method must be a string, got {type(method).__name__}')
93
94        if method not in ['pearson', 'spearman', 'kendall']:
95            raise ValueError(f"Available methods are: 'pearson', 'spearman', 'kendall'")
96
97        logger.info(f'Computing corrrelation using {method} method.')
98
99        return self.df.corr(method = method)

Initializing the Correlation Computation .

Parameters

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose.

columns: list, optional A list of columns you wish to check correlation for, by default None.

Correlation(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None) 
24    def __init__(self, df:pd.DataFrame, columns:list=None):
25
26        super().__init__(df, columns)
27
28        self.df = df
29        
30        if columns is None:
31            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
32        else:
33            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
34
35        logger.info(f'Correlation initialized.')
df
def covariance(self): 
37    def covariance(self):
38        """
39        Computes the covariance matrix of a pandas DataFrame.
40
41        Covariance shows how two columns (variables) change together:
42
43        - Positive -> both increase together
44        - Negative -> one increases while the other decreases
45        - Zero -> mostly independent
46
47        Returns
48        -------
49        pd.DataFrame
50            A pandas DataFrame
51
52        Example
53        -------
54        >>> Correlation(df).covariance()
55        """
56        return self.df.cov()

Computes the covariance matrix of a pandas DataFrame.

Covariance shows how two columns (variables) change together:

  • Positive -> both increase together
  • Negative -> one increases while the other decreases
  • Zero -> mostly independent

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Example

>>> Correlation(df).covariance()
def correlation(self, method: str = 'pearson'): 
58    def correlation(self, method:str = 'pearson'):
59        """
60        Computes the correlation matrix of a pandas DataFrame.
61
62        Pearson correlation measures how strongly two variables are linearly related:
63
64        - +1 -> perfectly positively correlated
65        - -1 -> perfectly negatively correlated
66        - 0  -> no linear correlation
67
68        Parameters
69        -----------
70            method: str, optional
71                Method using which you would like to calculate correlation, default is 'pearson'.
72
73                Available methods:
74
75                - 'pearson': measures how much two columns go up or down together in a straight-line.
76                - 'spearman': measures how much two columns move together based on their ranking order.
77                - 'kendall': measures how often two columns move in the same direction when comparing all pairs.
78
79        Returns
80        -------
81        pd.DataFrame
82            A pandas DataFrame
83
84        Example
85        -------
86        >>> Correlation(df).correlation()
87        >>> Correlation(df).correlation('spearman')
88        >>> Correlation(df).correlation('kendall')
89        """
90
91        if not isinstance(method, str):
92            raise TypeError(f'method must be a string, got {type(method).__name__}')
93
94        if method not in ['pearson', 'spearman', 'kendall']:
95            raise ValueError(f"Available methods are: 'pearson', 'spearman', 'kendall'")
96
97        logger.info(f'Computing corrrelation using {method} method.')
98
99        return self.df.corr(method = method)

Computes the correlation matrix of a pandas DataFrame.

Pearson correlation measures how strongly two variables are linearly related:

  • +1 -> perfectly positively correlated
  • -1 -> perfectly negatively correlated
  • 0 -> no linear correlation

Parameters

method: str, optional
    Method using which you would like to calculate correlation, default is 'pearson'.

    Available methods:

    - 'pearson': measures how much two columns go up or down together in a straight-line.
    - 'spearman': measures how much two columns move together based on their ranking order.
    - 'kendall': measures how often two columns move in the same direction when comparing all pairs.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Example

>>> Correlation(df).correlation()
>>> Correlation(df).correlation('spearman')
>>> Correlation(df).correlation('kendall')
class Diagnosis: 
 15class Diagnosis:
 16    """Initializing the Diagnosis.
 17
 18    Parameters
 19    -----------
 20    df: pd.DataFrame
 21        A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose
 22
 23    columns: list, optional
 24        A list of columns you wish to diagnose, by default None.
 25    """
 26
 27    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None):
 28
 29        # making sure that the passed df is a pandas DataFrame
 30        if not isinstance(df, pd.DataFrame):
 31            raise TypeError(f'df must be a pandas DataFrame, got {type(df).__name__}')
 32
 33        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
 34            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list of column names, got {type(columns).__name__}')
 35
 36        self.df = df
 37
 38        if columns is None:
 39            self.columns = df.columns.to_list()
 40        else:
 41            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 42
 43        logger.info(f'Data Diagnosis initialized with columns: {self.columns}')
 44
 45    def data_preview(self, number_of_rows=10)-> pd.DataFrame:
 46        """Shows a preview of N rows of your DataFrame.
 47
 48        Parameters
 49        ----------
 50        number_of_rows : int (default is 10)
 51            N numbers of rows you would like to see 
 52
 53        Returns
 54        --------
 55            pd.DataFrame
 56                A pandas DataFrame of N number of rows. 
 57        
 58        Usage Recommendation
 59        ---------------------
 60            1. Use this function when you want a preview of your data during diagnosis 
 61
 62        Considerations
 63        ---------------
 64            1. This function uses df.head() under the hood.
 65
 66        Example
 67        --------
 68        >>>     Diagnosis(df).data_preview(5)
 69        """
 70        return self.df.head(number_of_rows)
 71
 72    def data_summary(self)-> dict[str]:
 73        """Shows a summary of your DataFrame.
 74
 75        Returns
 76        --------
 77            dict
 78                A dictionary of summary types
 79        
 80        Usage Recommendation
 81        ---------------------
 82            1. Use this function when you want to see shape, columns, dtypes and index of your DataFrame
 83
 84        Example
 85        --------
 86        >>>     Diagnosis(df).data_summary()
 87        """
 88        summary = {
 89            'shape'        : self.df.shape,
 90            'columns'      : self.columns,
 91            'dtypes'       : self.df.dtypes,
 92            'index'        : self.df.index
 93        }
 94
 95        return summary
 96
 97    def show_memory_usage(self, usage_by='total')-> pd.Series:
 98        """Shows memory being used by your DataFrame.
 99
100        Parameters
101        ----------
102        usage_by: str (default is 'total')
103            Shows memory usage of a DataFrame
104
105            Supported methods:
106
107            - 'total': Shows memory usage by whole DataFrame
108            - 'separate' : Shows memory usage per column
109        """
110        if usage_by == 'total':
111
112            total_usage = self.df.memory_usage(deep=True).sum()/(1024**2)
113            print(f'Total Memory Usage: {self.df.memory_usage(deep=True).sum()/(1024**2):.2f} MB')
114            return total_usage
115        
116        elif usage_by == 'separate':
117
118            separate_usage = self.df.memory_usage(deep=True)/(1024**2)
119            print('Data Usage in MB:\n')
120            return separate_usage
121
122    def detect_column_types(self) -> dict [str, list[str]]:
123        """Detect the column types (Categorical, Numerical, Datetime) for one
124        or multiple columns of a DataFrame.
125
126        Returns
127        --------
128        dict
129            Return a dictionary with list of column types.
130
131            Supported column datatypes:
132
133            - Numerical  : List of Numerical type columns
134            - Datetime   : List of Datetime type columns
135            - Categorical: List of Categorical or object type columns
136
137        Usage Recommendation
138        ---------------------
139            1. Use this function to check whether a column is categorized as 'Categorical or text', 'Numerical', or Datetime.
140            2. Use 'ColumnConverter' to change column types if column type is not detected correctly.
141        """
142        self.column_types = {'Numerical': [], 'Datetime' :[], 'Categorical':[]}
143
144        for col in self.df.columns:
145            if pd.api.types.is_numeric_dtype(self.df[col]):
146                self.column_types['Numerical'].append(col)
147
148            elif pd.api.types.is_datetime64_any_dtype(self.df[col]):
149                self.column_types['Datetime'].append(col)
150
151            elif pd.api.types.is_object_dtype(self.df[col]) or pd.api.types.is_categorical_dtype(self.df[col]):
152                self.column_types['Categorical'].append(col)
153
154        return self.column_types 
155
156    def show_unique_values(self) -> dict[list[str]]:
157        """Shows a list of unique values present in each column of the
158        DataFrame.
159
160        Returns
161        --------
162            dict
163                A dictionary of key, value pairs of column and unique values present in that column
164
165        Usage Recommendation
166        ----------------------
167            Use this function when you want to see what unique values are present in a column.
168
169        Example
170        --------
171        
172        >>>   Diagnosis(df).show_unique_values()
173
174            Output: 
175
176                {
177                'gender': ['Female', 'Male', nan, 'unknown', 'Other'],
178                 'country': ['US', nan, 'DE', 'UK', 'IN', 'FR', 'UNK'],
179                 'device_type': ['desktop', 'mobile', 'tablet', nan, 'unknown'],
180                 'email': ['user@example.com', nan],
181                 'notes': ['?', nan, 'OK', "{'free_text': 'call later'}", "['list']"],
182                'phone_number': ['123-456-7890', '-999', nan],
183                'is_active': [False, True, nan]
184                }
185        """
186        unique_values = {}
187
188        for column in self.df.columns:
189
190            unique_values[f'{column}'] = self.df[column].unique().astype('object').tolist()
191
192        return unique_values  
193
194    def show_cardinality(self)-> dict[str, int]:
195        """Shows the number of unique values that exist in one or multiple
196        columns of the DataFrame.
197
198        Returns
199        --------
200        dict
201            A python dictionary of column names and cardinality values
202
203        Usage Recommendation
204        ---------------------
205            1. Use this function when you want to see how many unique values exist before using encoding your Categorical data.
206
207        Example
208        --------
209            Diagnosis(df).show_cardinality()
210        """
211        # using a dictionary to store values for each column
212        cardinality={}
213
214        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
215            # checking how many unique values exist
216            cardinality[column] = len(self.df[column].unique())
217
218        return cardinality
219
220    def show_duplicates(self, in_columns=None) -> pd.DataFrame:
221        """Shows duplicate values in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
222
223        Returns
224        -------
225        pd.DataFrame
226            A pandas DataFrame of duplicate values
227        """
228
229        return self.df[self.df[self.columns].duplicated(subset=in_columns)]
230
231    def count_duplicates(self, in_columns=None)-> int:
232        """Counts duplicate values in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
233
234        Returns
235        -------
236        int
237            Number of duplicate values
238        """
239        return self.df[self.columns].duplicated(subset=in_columns).sum()
240    
241    def get_numerical_columns(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
242        """Separates Numerical (numbers) columns from rest of the DataFrame.
243
244        Returns
245        -------
246        pd.DataFrame
247            A pandas DataFrame of Numerical columns.
248        
249        Usage Recommendation
250        ---------------------
251            1. Use this function when you want to work specifically on Numerical data, not overall DataFrame (including Categorical, Datetime).
252            2. Use this function if you wish to follow DataLab guided workflow for diagnosis, cleaning and preprocessing of Numerical data.
253
254        Example
255        --------
256        >>> Diagnosis(df).get_numerical_columns()
257        """
258
259        return self.df.select_dtypes(include='number')
260
261    def get_categorical_columns(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
262        """Separates Categorical (text or category) columns from rest of the
263        DataFrame.
264
265        Returns
266        -------
267        pd.DataFrame
268            A pandas DataFrame of Categorical columns.
269        
270        Usage Recommendation
271        ---------------------
272            1. Use this function when you want to work specifically on Categorical data, not overall DataFrame (including Numerical, Datetime).
273            2. Use this function if you wish to follow DataLab guided workflow for diagnosis, cleaning and preprocessing of Categorical data.
274
275        Example
276        --------
277        
278        >>> Diagnosis(df).get_categorical_columns()
279        """
280        return self.df.select_dtypes(include=['object', 'string', 'category'])
281
282    def get_datetime_columns(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
283        """Separates Datetime (dates or timestamps) columns from rest of the
284        DataFrame.
285
286        Returns
287        -------
288        pd.DataFrame
289            A pandas DataFrame of Datetime columns.
290        
291        Usage Recommendation
292        ---------------------
293            1. Use this function when you want to work specifically on Date and Time columns, not overall DataFrame (including Numerical, Datetime).
294            2. Use this function if you wish to follow DataLab guided workflow for diagnosis, cleaning and preprocessing of Datetime data.
295
296        Example
297        --------
298        
299        >>> Diagnosis(df).get_datetime_columns()
300        """
301
302        return self.df.select_dtypes(include = ['datetime'])

Initializing the Diagnosis.

Parameters

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose

columns: list, optional A list of columns you wish to diagnose, by default None.

Diagnosis(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None) 
27    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None):
28
29        # making sure that the passed df is a pandas DataFrame
30        if not isinstance(df, pd.DataFrame):
31            raise TypeError(f'df must be a pandas DataFrame, got {type(df).__name__}')
32
33        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
34            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list of column names, got {type(columns).__name__}')
35
36        self.df = df
37
38        if columns is None:
39            self.columns = df.columns.to_list()
40        else:
41            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
42
43        logger.info(f'Data Diagnosis initialized with columns: {self.columns}')
df
def data_preview(self, number_of_rows=10) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
45    def data_preview(self, number_of_rows=10)-> pd.DataFrame:
46        """Shows a preview of N rows of your DataFrame.
47
48        Parameters
49        ----------
50        number_of_rows : int (default is 10)
51            N numbers of rows you would like to see 
52
53        Returns
54        --------
55            pd.DataFrame
56                A pandas DataFrame of N number of rows. 
57        
58        Usage Recommendation
59        ---------------------
60            1. Use this function when you want a preview of your data during diagnosis 
61
62        Considerations
63        ---------------
64            1. This function uses df.head() under the hood.
65
66        Example
67        --------
68        >>>     Diagnosis(df).data_preview(5)
69        """
70        return self.df.head(number_of_rows)

Returns

    A pandas DataFrame of N number of rows.

Considerations

1. This function uses df.head() under the hood.

Example

>>>     Diagnosis(df).data_preview(5)
def data_summary(self) -> dict[str]: 
72    def data_summary(self)-> dict[str]:
73        """Shows a summary of your DataFrame.
74
75        Returns
76        --------
77            dict
78                A dictionary of summary types
79        
80        Usage Recommendation
81        ---------------------
82            1. Use this function when you want to see shape, columns, dtypes and index of your DataFrame
83
84        Example
85        --------
86        >>>     Diagnosis(df).data_summary()
87        """
88        summary = {
89            'shape'        : self.df.shape,
90            'columns'      : self.columns,
91            'dtypes'       : self.df.dtypes,
92            'index'        : self.df.index
93        }
94
95        return summary

    A dictionary of summary types

Usage Recommendation

Example

def show_memory_usage(self, usage_by='total') -> pandas.core.series.Series: 
 97    def show_memory_usage(self, usage_by='total')-> pd.Series:
 98        """Shows memory being used by your DataFrame.
 99
100        Parameters
101        ----------
102        usage_by: str (default is 'total')
103            Shows memory usage of a DataFrame
104
105            Supported methods:
106
107            - 'total': Shows memory usage by whole DataFrame
108            - 'separate' : Shows memory usage per column
109        """
110        if usage_by == 'total':
111
112            total_usage = self.df.memory_usage(deep=True).sum()/(1024**2)
113            print(f'Total Memory Usage: {self.df.memory_usage(deep=True).sum()/(1024**2):.2f} MB')
114            return total_usage
115        
116        elif usage_by == 'separate':
117
118            separate_usage = self.df.memory_usage(deep=True)/(1024**2)
119            print('Data Usage in MB:\n')
120            return separate_usage

Shows memory being used by your DataFrame.

Parameters

usage_by: str (default is 'total') Shows memory usage of a DataFrame

Supported methods:

- 'total': Shows memory usage by whole DataFrame
- 'separate' : Shows memory usage per column
def detect_column_types(self) -> dict[str, list[str]]: 
122    def detect_column_types(self) -> dict [str, list[str]]:
123        """Detect the column types (Categorical, Numerical, Datetime) for one
124        or multiple columns of a DataFrame.
125
126        Returns
127        --------
128        dict
129            Return a dictionary with list of column types.
130
131            Supported column datatypes:
132
133            - Numerical  : List of Numerical type columns
134            - Datetime   : List of Datetime type columns
135            - Categorical: List of Categorical or object type columns
136
137        Usage Recommendation
138        ---------------------
139            1. Use this function to check whether a column is categorized as 'Categorical or text', 'Numerical', or Datetime.
140            2. Use 'ColumnConverter' to change column types if column type is not detected correctly.
141        """
142        self.column_types = {'Numerical': [], 'Datetime' :[], 'Categorical':[]}
143
144        for col in self.df.columns:
145            if pd.api.types.is_numeric_dtype(self.df[col]):
146                self.column_types['Numerical'].append(col)
147
148            elif pd.api.types.is_datetime64_any_dtype(self.df[col]):
149                self.column_types['Datetime'].append(col)
150
151            elif pd.api.types.is_object_dtype(self.df[col]) or pd.api.types.is_categorical_dtype(self.df[col]):
152                self.column_types['Categorical'].append(col)
153
154        return self.column_types

Detect the column types (Categorical, Numerical, Datetime) for one or multiple columns of a DataFrame.

Returns

dict Return a dictionary with list of column types.

Supported column datatypes:

- Numerical  : List of Numerical type columns
- Datetime   : List of Datetime type columns
- Categorical: List of Categorical or object type columns

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function to check whether a column is categorized as 'Categorical or text', 'Numerical', or Datetime.
2. Use 'ColumnConverter' to change column types if column type is not detected correctly.
def show_unique_values(self) -> dict[list[str]]: 
156    def show_unique_values(self) -> dict[list[str]]:
157        """Shows a list of unique values present in each column of the
158        DataFrame.
159
160        Returns
161        --------
162            dict
163                A dictionary of key, value pairs of column and unique values present in that column
164
165        Usage Recommendation
166        ----------------------
167            Use this function when you want to see what unique values are present in a column.
168
169        Example
170        --------
171        
172        >>>   Diagnosis(df).show_unique_values()
173
174            Output: 
175
176                {
177                'gender': ['Female', 'Male', nan, 'unknown', 'Other'],
178                 'country': ['US', nan, 'DE', 'UK', 'IN', 'FR', 'UNK'],
179                 'device_type': ['desktop', 'mobile', 'tablet', nan, 'unknown'],
180                 'email': ['user@example.com', nan],
181                 'notes': ['?', nan, 'OK', "{'free_text': 'call later'}", "['list']"],
182                'phone_number': ['123-456-7890', '-999', nan],
183                'is_active': [False, True, nan]
184                }
185        """
186        unique_values = {}
187
188        for column in self.df.columns:
189
190            unique_values[f'{column}'] = self.df[column].unique().astype('object').tolist()
191
192        return unique_values

Shows a list of unique values present in each column of the DataFrame.

Returns

dict
    A dictionary of key, value pairs of column and unique values present in that column

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when you want to see what unique values are present in a column.

Example

>>>   Diagnosis(df).show_unique_values()

Output: 

    {
    'gender': ['Female', 'Male', nan, 'unknown', 'Other'],
     'country': ['US', nan, 'DE', 'UK', 'IN', 'FR', 'UNK'],
     'device_type': ['desktop', 'mobile', 'tablet', nan, 'unknown'],
     'email': ['user@example.com', nan],
     'notes': ['?', nan, 'OK', "{'free_text': 'call later'}", "['list']"],
    'phone_number': ['123-456-7890', '-999', nan],
    'is_active': [False, True, nan]
    }
def show_cardinality(self) -> dict[str, int]: 
194    def show_cardinality(self)-> dict[str, int]:
195        """Shows the number of unique values that exist in one or multiple
196        columns of the DataFrame.
197
198        Returns
199        --------
200        dict
201            A python dictionary of column names and cardinality values
202
203        Usage Recommendation
204        ---------------------
205            1. Use this function when you want to see how many unique values exist before using encoding your Categorical data.
206
207        Example
208        --------
209            Diagnosis(df).show_cardinality()
210        """
211        # using a dictionary to store values for each column
212        cardinality={}
213
214        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
215            # checking how many unique values exist
216            cardinality[column] = len(self.df[column].unique())
217
218        return cardinality

Shows the number of unique values that exist in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.

Returns

dict A python dictionary of column names and cardinality values

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to see how many unique values exist before using encoding your Categorical data.

Example

Diagnosis(df).show_cardinality()
def show_duplicates(self, in_columns=None) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
220    def show_duplicates(self, in_columns=None) -> pd.DataFrame:
221        """Shows duplicate values in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
222
223        Returns
224        -------
225        pd.DataFrame
226            A pandas DataFrame of duplicate values
227        """
228
229        return self.df[self.df[self.columns].duplicated(subset=in_columns)]

Shows duplicate values in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame of duplicate values

def count_duplicates(self, in_columns=None) -> int: 
231    def count_duplicates(self, in_columns=None)-> int:
232        """Counts duplicate values in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
233
234        Returns
235        -------
236        int
237            Number of duplicate values
238        """
239        return self.df[self.columns].duplicated(subset=in_columns).sum()

Counts duplicate values in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.

Returns

int Number of duplicate values

def get_numerical_columns(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
241    def get_numerical_columns(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
242        """Separates Numerical (numbers) columns from rest of the DataFrame.
243

252            2. Use this function if you wish to follow DataLab guided workflow for diagnosis, cleaning and preprocessing of Numerical data.
253
254        Example
255        --------
256        >>> Diagnosis(df).get_numerical_columns()
257        """
258
259        return self.df.select_dtypes(include='number')

def get_datetime_columns(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame:

class MissingnessDiagnosis: 
 13class MissingnessDiagnosis:
 14    """
 15    Initialize the Missingness Diagnosis.
 16
 17    Parameters
 18    -----------
 19    df: pd.DataFrame
 20        A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose.
 21
 22    columns: list, optional
 23        A list of columns you wish to apply numerical cleaning on, by default None
 24
 25    extra_placeholders: list, optional
 26        A list of extra placeholders considered as missing values depending on the domain, by default None
 27    """
 28
 29    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None, extra_placeholders:list|type(None)=None):
 30        import pandas as pd
 31        import numpy as np
 32
 33        # making sure that the passed df is a pandas DataFrame
 34        if not isinstance(df, pd.DataFrame):
 35            raise TypeError(f'df must be a pandas DataFrame, got {type(df).__name__}')
 36        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
 37            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list of column names, got {type(columns).__name__}')
 38        if not isinstance(extra_placeholders, (list, type(None))):
 39            raise TypeError(f'extra_placeholders must be a list of strings, got {type(extra_placeholders).__name__}')
 40
 41        self.df = df
 42
 43        if columns is None:
 44            self.columns = df.columns.to_list()
 45        else:
 46            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 47
 48        # keeping extra placeholders to be an empty list if None, otherwise creating a mask of placeholders would not be able to find something to iterate over.
 49        if extra_placeholders is None:
 50            self.extra_placeholders = []
 51        else:
 52            self.extra_placeholders = extra_placeholders
 53
 54        logger.info(f'Missingness Diagnosis initialized.')
 55
 56    def detect_missing_types(self)-> dict[str, dict[str, list]]:
 57        """Detects the types of missing values in each column of the DataFrame.
 58
 59        Returns
 60        --------
 61        dict
 62            A dictionary of columns and the types of missing values in a Numerical DataFrame.
 63
 64        Usage Recommendation
 65        ---------------------
 66            1. Use this function when you want to detect what kind of missing data exists in your data.
 67        """
 68        # keeping a dictionary of missing values
 69        missing_values = {}
 70
