 71        # creating a mask of pandas considering missing values
 72        pandas_mask = self.df.isna()
 73
 74        # creating a mask for extra placeholders user wants to detect in their missing data
 75        placeholders_mask = self.df.isin(self.extra_placeholders)
 76
 77        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
 78
 79            # converting to object type, otherwise .unique() returned a lot of unnecessary categorical information
 80            pandas_missing = self.df.loc[pandas_mask[column], column].astype('object').unique().tolist()
 81
 82            # getting those values that are missing
 83            place_holder_missing = self.df.loc[placeholders_mask[column], column].astype('object').unique().tolist()
 84            
 85            # if either of the values exist, show the results
 86            if pandas_missing or place_holder_missing:
 87                missing_values[column] = {
 88                    'pandas_missing': pandas_missing,
 89                    'placeholder_missing': place_holder_missing
 90                }
 91
 92        return missing_values      
 93    
 94    def show_missing_rows_in_categorical_columns(self)-> dict[str, pd.DataFrame]:
 95        """Shows the rows where data is missing in Categorical columns of the DataFrame.
 96
 97        Returns
 98        --------
 99        dict
100            A dictionary of Categorical columns with rows containing missing values (pandas or placeholder).
101
102        Usage Recommendation
103        ---------------------
104            Use this function to see missing values in categorical columns before deciding how to clean or handle them.
105        """
106        # selecting only the categorical or text data 
107        missing_categorical_data = {}
108
109        if self.columns is None:
110            categorical_columns = self.df.select_dtypes(include = ["object", "string", "category"]).columns
111        else:
112            categorical_columns = self.columns
113
114        for column in categorical_columns:
115        
116            # creating a true false mask of pandas missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
117            pandas_mask = self.df[column].isna()
118
119            # creating a true false mask of placeholder missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
120            placeholders_mask = self.df[column].isin(self.extra_placeholders)
121
122            # if pandas or placeholder missing values exist, show either of the data
123            missing_mask = pandas_mask | placeholders_mask
124
125            # Only including a column in the output if it actually has missing values.
126            if missing_mask.any():
127                missing_categorical_data[column] = self.df.loc[missing_mask]
128        
129        return missing_categorical_data
130
131    def show_missing_rows_in_numerical_columns(self)-> dict[str, pd.DataFrame]:
132        """Shows the rows where data is missing in Numerical columns of the DataFrame.
133
134        Returns
135        --------
136        dict
137            A dictionary of Numerical columns with rows containing missing values (pandas or placeholder).
138
139        Usage Recommendation
140        ---------------------
141            Use this function to see missing values in numerical columns before deciding how to clean or handle them.
142        """
143        missing_numerical_data = {}
144        
145        if self.columns is None:
146            # selecting only the numerical data 
147            numerical_columns = self.df.select_dtypes(include = ['number']).columns
148        else:
149            numerical_columns = self.columns
150
151        for column in numerical_columns:
152
153            # creating a true false mask of pandas missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
154            pandas_mask = self.df[column].isna()
155
156            # creating a true false mask of placeholder missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
157            placeholders_mask = self.df[column].isin(self.extra_placeholders)
158
159            # if pandas or placeholder missing values exist, show both data (using OR)
160            missing_mask = pandas_mask | placeholders_mask
161
162            # Only including a column in the output if it actually has missing values.
163            if missing_mask.any():
164                missing_numerical_data[column] = self.df.loc[missing_mask]
165
166        return missing_numerical_data
167
168    def show_missing_rows_in_datetime_columns(self)-> dict[str, pd.DataFrame]:
169        """Shows the rows where data is missing in Date or Time columns of the DataFrame.
170
171        Returns
172        --------
173        dict
174            A dictionary of DateTime columns with rows containing missing values (pandas or placeholder).
175
176        Usage Recommendation
177        ---------------------
178            Use this function to see missing values in date or time columns before deciding how to clean or handle them.
179        """
180        missing_datetime_data = {}
181        
182        if self.columns is None:
183            datetime_columns = self.df.select_dtypes(include = ['datetime']).columns
184        else:
185            datetime_columns = self.columns
186
187        for column in datetime_columns:
188
189            # creating a true false mask of pandas missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
190            pandas_mask = self.df[column].isna()
191
192            # creating a true false mask of placeholder missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
193            placeholders_mask = self.df[column].isin(self.extra_placeholders)
194
195            # if pandas or placeholder missing values exist, show both data (using OR)
196            missing_mask = pandas_mask | placeholders_mask
197
198            # Only including a column in the output if it actually has missing values.
199            if missing_mask.any():
200                missing_datetime_data[column] = self.df.loc[missing_mask]
201                
202        return missing_datetime_data
203
204    def missing_data_summary(self, method='count')-> dict[str, int]:
205        """Shows the number of rows with missing values present in each column, irrespective of column type (Categorical, Numerical or Datetime)
206
207        Parameters
208        -----------
209        method : str (default is 'count')
210
211            How you would like to show the total of missing values.
212
213                - 'count'    : Shows a count of rows with missing values per column
214                - 'percent': Shows the percentage of rows with missing values per column
215
216        Returns
217        --------
218        dict
219            A dictionary of counts or percentages of missing values per column
220
221        Usage Recommendation
222        ---------------------
223            Use this function when you want to see a count or percentage of missing values before deciding whether to drop or fill missing values.
224        """
225        # a mask of pandas missing values to get pandas missing types
226        pandas_mask = self.df.isna()
227        
228        # a mask of placeholder missing types 
229        placeholders_mask = self.df.isin(self.extra_placeholders)
230
231        # an empty to dictionary of missing_data_summary
232        missing_data_summary = {}
233        
234        # to ensure pandas or placeholder types are both picked
235        mask = pandas_mask | placeholders_mask
236
237        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
238
239            # if missing values are present in any column 
240            if mask[col].any():
241
242                # to ensure user can get a count of rows where values are missing
243                if method == 'count':
244
245                    missing_data_summary[col] = len(self.df.loc[mask[col]])
246
247                # if user wants to see percentage
248                elif method == 'percent':
249
250                    missing_data_summary[col] = (len(self.df.loc[mask[col]])/ len(self.df)) * 100
251
252                # only sum and percent are acceptable types
253                else:
254                    raise ValueError(f"method must be 'count' or 'percent', got {method}")
255
256        # rounding off values to 2 decimal places
257        missing_data_summary = {col: round(value, 2) for col, value in missing_data_summary.items()}
258
259        return missing_data_summary
260        
261    def rows_with_all_columns_missing(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
262        """Detects and shows all the rows where all the columns are missing values together in a DataFrame.
263
264        Returns
265        --------
266        pd.DataFrame
267            A pandas dataframe of all rows where data is missing together in all the columns.
268
269        Usage Recommendation
270        ---------------------
271            Use this function when you want to see data where all columns have values missing.
272        """
273        # creating a mask of pandas missing values
274        pandas_mask = self.df.isna()
275
276        # creating a mask of placeholder missing values
277        placeholder_mask = self.df.isin(self.extra_placeholders)
278
279        # accepting both values
280        missing_mask = pandas_mask | placeholder_mask
281
282        # this is the main part where we check rows where all columns are missing values 
283        missing_data = missing_mask.all(axis=1)
284
285        # getting only the data of rows where all columns are missing values
286        all_columns_missing_data = self.df.loc[missing_data]
287
288        return all_columns_missing_data
289
290    def rows_with_specific_columns_missing(self, extra_placeholders=None)-> pd.DataFrame:
291        """Detects and shows all the rows where only specific columns are missing valeues together in a DataFrame.
292
293        Returns
294        -------
295        pd.DataFrame
296            A pandas dataframe of all rows where data is missing together in only the columns decided by user.
297
298        Usage Recommendation
299        ---------------------
300            Use this function when you want to see data where only your decided columns have values missing.
301        """    
302        # creating a mask of pandas missing values
303        pandas_mask = self.df[self.columns].isna()
304        
305        # creating a mask of placeholder missing values
306        placeholder_mask = self.df[self.columns].isin(self.extra_placeholders)
307
308        # accepting both values
309        missing_mask = pandas_mask | placeholder_mask
310
311        # this is the main part where we check rows where only specific columns are missing values
312        missing_data = missing_mask.all(axis=1)
313
314        # getting only the data of rows where specific columns are missing values
315        missing_data_in_specific_columns = self.df[self.columns].loc[missing_data]
316
317        return missing_data_in_specific_columns

Initialize the Missingness Diagnosis.

Parameters

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose.

columns: list, optional A list of columns you wish to apply numerical cleaning on, by default None

extra_placeholders: list, optional A list of extra placeholders considered as missing values depending on the domain, by default None

MissingnessDiagnosis( df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None, extra_placeholders: list | None = None) 
29    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None, extra_placeholders:list|type(None)=None):
30        import pandas as pd
31        import numpy as np
32
33        # making sure that the passed df is a pandas DataFrame
34        if not isinstance(df, pd.DataFrame):
35            raise TypeError(f'df must be a pandas DataFrame, got {type(df).__name__}')
36        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
37            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list of column names, got {type(columns).__name__}')
38        if not isinstance(extra_placeholders, (list, type(None))):
39            raise TypeError(f'extra_placeholders must be a list of strings, got {type(extra_placeholders).__name__}')
40
41        self.df = df
42
43        if columns is None:
44            self.columns = df.columns.to_list()
45        else:
46            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
47
48        # keeping extra placeholders to be an empty list if None, otherwise creating a mask of placeholders would not be able to find something to iterate over.
49        if extra_placeholders is None:
50            self.extra_placeholders = []
51        else:
52            self.extra_placeholders = extra_placeholders
53
54        logger.info(f'Missingness Diagnosis initialized.')
df
def detect_missing_types(self) -> dict[str, dict[str, list]]: 
56    def detect_missing_types(self)-> dict[str, dict[str, list]]:
57        """Detects the types of missing values in each column of the DataFrame.
58
59        Returns
60        --------
61        dict
62            A dictionary of columns and the types of missing values in a Numerical DataFrame.
63
64        Usage Recommendation
65        ---------------------
66            1. Use this function when you want to detect what kind of missing data exists in your data.
67        """
68        # keeping a dictionary of missing values
69        missing_values = {}
70
71        # creating a mask of pandas considering missing values
72        pandas_mask = self.df.isna()
73
74        # creating a mask for extra placeholders user wants to detect in their missing data
75        placeholders_mask = self.df.isin(self.extra_placeholders)
76
77        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
78
79            # converting to object type, otherwise .unique() returned a lot of unnecessary categorical information
80            pandas_missing = self.df.loc[pandas_mask[column], column].astype('object').unique().tolist()
81
82            # getting those values that are missing
83            place_holder_missing = self.df.loc[placeholders_mask[column], column].astype('object').unique().tolist()
84            
85            # if either of the values exist, show the results
86            if pandas_missing or place_holder_missing:
87                missing_values[column] = {
88                    'pandas_missing': pandas_missing,
89                    'placeholder_missing': place_holder_missing
90                }
91
92        return missing_values

Detects the types of missing values in each column of the DataFrame.

Returns

dict A dictionary of columns and the types of missing values in a Numerical DataFrame.

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to detect what kind of missing data exists in your data.
def show_missing_rows_in_categorical_columns(self) -> dict[str, pandas.core.frame.DataFrame]: 
 94    def show_missing_rows_in_categorical_columns(self)-> dict[str, pd.DataFrame]:
 95        """Shows the rows where data is missing in Categorical columns of the DataFrame.
 96
 97        Returns
 98        --------
 99        dict
100            A dictionary of Categorical columns with rows containing missing values (pandas or placeholder).
101
102        Usage Recommendation
103        ---------------------
104            Use this function to see missing values in categorical columns before deciding how to clean or handle them.
105        """
106        # selecting only the categorical or text data 
107        missing_categorical_data = {}
108
109        if self.columns is None:
110            categorical_columns = self.df.select_dtypes(include = ["object", "string", "category"]).columns
111        else:
112            categorical_columns = self.columns
113
114        for column in categorical_columns:
115        
116            # creating a true false mask of pandas missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
117            pandas_mask = self.df[column].isna()
118
119            # creating a true false mask of placeholder missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
120            placeholders_mask = self.df[column].isin(self.extra_placeholders)
121
122            # if pandas or placeholder missing values exist, show either of the data
123            missing_mask = pandas_mask | placeholders_mask
124
125            # Only including a column in the output if it actually has missing values.
126            if missing_mask.any():
127                missing_categorical_data[column] = self.df.loc[missing_mask]
128        
129        return missing_categorical_data

Shows the rows where data is missing in Categorical columns of the DataFrame.

Returns

dict A dictionary of Categorical columns with rows containing missing values (pandas or placeholder).

Usage Recommendation

Use this function to see missing values in categorical columns before deciding how to clean or handle them.
def show_missing_rows_in_numerical_columns(self) -> dict[str, pandas.core.frame.DataFrame]: 
131    def show_missing_rows_in_numerical_columns(self)-> dict[str, pd.DataFrame]:
132        """Shows the rows where data is missing in Numerical columns of the DataFrame.
133
134        Returns
135        --------
136        dict
137            A dictionary of Numerical columns with rows containing missing values (pandas or placeholder).
138
139        Usage Recommendation
140        ---------------------
141            Use this function to see missing values in numerical columns before deciding how to clean or handle them.
142        """
143        missing_numerical_data = {}
144        
145        if self.columns is None:
146            # selecting only the numerical data 
147            numerical_columns = self.df.select_dtypes(include = ['number']).columns
148        else:
149            numerical_columns = self.columns
150
151        for column in numerical_columns:
152
153            # creating a true false mask of pandas missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
154            pandas_mask = self.df[column].isna()
155
156            # creating a true false mask of placeholder missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
157            placeholders_mask = self.df[column].isin(self.extra_placeholders)
158
159            # if pandas or placeholder missing values exist, show both data (using OR)
160            missing_mask = pandas_mask | placeholders_mask
161
162            # Only including a column in the output if it actually has missing values.
163            if missing_mask.any():
164                missing_numerical_data[column] = self.df.loc[missing_mask]
165
166        return missing_numerical_data

Shows the rows where data is missing in Numerical columns of the DataFrame.

Returns

dict A dictionary of Numerical columns with rows containing missing values (pandas or placeholder).

Usage Recommendation

Use this function to see missing values in numerical columns before deciding how to clean or handle them.
def show_missing_rows_in_datetime_columns(self) -> dict[str, pandas.core.frame.DataFrame]: 
168    def show_missing_rows_in_datetime_columns(self)-> dict[str, pd.DataFrame]:
169        """Shows the rows where data is missing in Date or Time columns of the DataFrame.
170
171        Returns
172        --------
173        dict
174            A dictionary of DateTime columns with rows containing missing values (pandas or placeholder).
175
176        Usage Recommendation
177        ---------------------
178            Use this function to see missing values in date or time columns before deciding how to clean or handle them.
179        """
180        missing_datetime_data = {}
181        
182        if self.columns is None:
183            datetime_columns = self.df.select_dtypes(include = ['datetime']).columns
184        else:
185            datetime_columns = self.columns
186
187        for column in datetime_columns:
188
189            # creating a true false mask of pandas missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
190            pandas_mask = self.df[column].isna()
191
192            # creating a true false mask of placeholder missing types if missing returns true otherwise false
193            placeholders_mask = self.df[column].isin(self.extra_placeholders)
194
195            # if pandas or placeholder missing values exist, show both data (using OR)
196            missing_mask = pandas_mask | placeholders_mask
197
198            # Only including a column in the output if it actually has missing values.
199            if missing_mask.any():
200                missing_datetime_data[column] = self.df.loc[missing_mask]
201                
202        return missing_datetime_data

Shows the rows where data is missing in Date or Time columns of the DataFrame.

Returns

dict A dictionary of DateTime columns with rows containing missing values (pandas or placeholder).

Usage Recommendation

Use this function to see missing values in date or time columns before deciding how to clean or handle them.
def missing_data_summary(self, method='count') -> dict[str, int]: 
204    def missing_data_summary(self, method='count')-> dict[str, int]:
205        """Shows the number of rows with missing values present in each column, irrespective of column type (Categorical, Numerical or Datetime)
206
207        Parameters
208        -----------
209        method : str (default is 'count')
210
211            How you would like to show the total of missing values.
212
213                - 'count'    : Shows a count of rows with missing values per column
214                - 'percent': Shows the percentage of rows with missing values per column
215
216        Returns
217        --------
218        dict
219            A dictionary of counts or percentages of missing values per column
220
221        Usage Recommendation
222        ---------------------
223            Use this function when you want to see a count or percentage of missing values before deciding whether to drop or fill missing values.
224        """
225        # a mask of pandas missing values to get pandas missing types
226        pandas_mask = self.df.isna()
227        
228        # a mask of placeholder missing types 
229        placeholders_mask = self.df.isin(self.extra_placeholders)
230
231        # an empty to dictionary of missing_data_summary
232        missing_data_summary = {}
233        
234        # to ensure pandas or placeholder types are both picked
235        mask = pandas_mask | placeholders_mask
236
237        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
238
239            # if missing values are present in any column 
240            if mask[col].any():
241
242                # to ensure user can get a count of rows where values are missing
243                if method == 'count':
244
245                    missing_data_summary[col] = len(self.df.loc[mask[col]])
246
247                # if user wants to see percentage
248                elif method == 'percent':
249
250                    missing_data_summary[col] = (len(self.df.loc[mask[col]])/ len(self.df)) * 100
251
252                # only sum and percent are acceptable types
253                else:
254                    raise ValueError(f"method must be 'count' or 'percent', got {method}")
255
256        # rounding off values to 2 decimal places
257        missing_data_summary = {col: round(value, 2) for col, value in missing_data_summary.items()}
258
259        return missing_data_summary

Shows the number of rows with missing values present in each column, irrespective of column type (Categorical, Numerical or Datetime)

Parameters

method : str (default is 'count')

How you would like to show the total of missing values.

    - 'count'    : Shows a count of rows with missing values per column
    - 'percent': Shows the percentage of rows with missing values per column

Returns

dict A dictionary of counts or percentages of missing values per column

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when you want to see a count or percentage of missing values before deciding whether to drop or fill missing values.
def rows_with_all_columns_missing(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
261    def rows_with_all_columns_missing(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
262        """Detects and shows all the rows where all the columns are missing values together in a DataFrame.
263
264        Returns
265        --------
266        pd.DataFrame
267            A pandas dataframe of all rows where data is missing together in all the columns.
268
269        Usage Recommendation
270        ---------------------
271            Use this function when you want to see data where all columns have values missing.
272        """
273        # creating a mask of pandas missing values
274        pandas_mask = self.df.isna()
275
276        # creating a mask of placeholder missing values
277        placeholder_mask = self.df.isin(self.extra_placeholders)
278
279        # accepting both values
280        missing_mask = pandas_mask | placeholder_mask
281
282        # this is the main part where we check rows where all columns are missing values 
283        missing_data = missing_mask.all(axis=1)
284
285        # getting only the data of rows where all columns are missing values
286        all_columns_missing_data = self.df.loc[missing_data]
287
288        return all_columns_missing_data

Detects and shows all the rows where all the columns are missing values together in a DataFrame.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas dataframe of all rows where data is missing together in all the columns.

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when you want to see data where all columns have values missing.
def rows_with_specific_columns_missing(self, extra_placeholders=None) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
290    def rows_with_specific_columns_missing(self, extra_placeholders=None)-> pd.DataFrame:
291        """Detects and shows all the rows where only specific columns are missing valeues together in a DataFrame.
292
293        Returns
294        -------
295        pd.DataFrame
296            A pandas dataframe of all rows where data is missing together in only the columns decided by user.
297
298        Usage Recommendation
299        ---------------------
300            Use this function when you want to see data where only your decided columns have values missing.
301        """    
302        # creating a mask of pandas missing values
303        pandas_mask = self.df[self.columns].isna()
304        
305        # creating a mask of placeholder missing values
306        placeholder_mask = self.df[self.columns].isin(self.extra_placeholders)
307
308        # accepting both values
309        missing_mask = pandas_mask | placeholder_mask
310
311        # this is the main part where we check rows where only specific columns are missing values
312        missing_data = missing_mask.all(axis=1)
313
314        # getting only the data of rows where specific columns are missing values
315        missing_data_in_specific_columns = self.df[self.columns].loc[missing_data]
316
317        return missing_data_in_specific_columns

Detects and shows all the rows where only specific columns are missing valeues together in a DataFrame.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas dataframe of all rows where data is missing together in only the columns decided by user.

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when you want to see data where only your decided columns have values missing.
class NumericalDiagnosis: 
 11class NumericalDiagnosis:
 12    """
 13    Initializing the Numerical Diagnosis.
 14
 15    Parameters
 16    -----------
 17
 18    df: pd.DataFrame
 19        A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose.
 20
 21    columns: list, optional
 22        A list of columns you wish to apply numerical diagnosis on, by default None.
 23    """
 24
 25    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None):
 26
 27
 28        if not isinstance(df, pd.DataFrame):
 29            raise TypeError(f'df must be a pandas DataFrame, got {type(df).__name__}')
 30
 31        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
 32            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list of column names, got {type(columns).__name__}')
 33
 34        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include='number')
 35
 36        if columns is None:
 37            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
 38        else:
 39            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 40
 41        logger.info('Numerical Diagnosis initialized.')
 42            
 43    def check_sparsity(self, value: int|float = 0) -> dict[str, float]:
 44        """
 45        Checks the ratio of occurrence of a specific number (usually 0).
 46
 47        Parameters
 48        -----------
 49        value: int or float, optional
 50            An integer or a decimal number, by default 0.
 51
 52        Returns
 53        --------
 54        dict[str, float]
 55            A dictionary of column names and percentage of occurrence of a particular number.
 56            
 57        Usage Recommendation
 58        --------------------
 59            1. Use this function only for Exploratory Data Analysis.  
 60            2. Mostly used to check how many values are 0 in a certain column. However, you can also use integers like 3 or floats like 5.888.
 61            3. This function is intended to help you get an overview of which column may and may not contribute meaningfully to the analysis or ML.
 62
 63        Considerations
 64        --------------
 65            Pass numeric values after converting datatypes to int or float, instead of using strings.
 66            
 67        Example
 68        --------
 69        >>> NumericalCleaner(df).check_sparsity()
 70        >>> NumericalCleaner(df).check_sparsity(5)
 71        """
 72        sparsity_dict = {
 73            col: round(float((((self.df[col] == 0).sum())/len(self.df[col]))* 100), 2)
 74            for col in self.df[self.columns]}
 75
 76        # Shows occurence of each value in percentage
 77        logger.info(f'Occurrence of {value} in each column of the dataframe (in %)')
 78        
 79        return sparsity_dict
 80
 81    def detect_outliers(self, method: str ='IQR')-> dict[str, pd.Series]:
 82        """
 83        Detects outliers in one or multiple Numerical columns of the DataFrame.
 84
 85        Parameters
 86        -----------
 87        method : str (default is 'IQR')
 88            Method using which you wish to detect outliers.
 89
 90            Supports:
 91            
 92            - IQR
 93            - z-score
 94
 95        Returns
 96        -------
 97        dict[str, pd.Series]
 98            A pandas Series of columns with outliers.
 99            
100        Usage Recommendation
101        --------------------
102            1. Use this function when you want to check if there are any outliers in your data.
103            2. Use this function only for Numerical data (numbers).
104
105        Example
106        -------- 
107        >>> NumericalDiagnosis(df).detect_outliers()
108        """
109        from datalab import Outliers
110
111        outliers_dict  = {}
112
113        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
114            
115            if method == 'IQR':
116                
117                outliers_dict[col] = Outliers(self.df).iqr_outliers()[col]
118
119            elif method == 'z_score':
120
121                outliers_dict[col] = Outliers(self.df).zscore_outliers()[col]
122            
123        return outliers_dict
124
125    def check_skewness(self)-> dict[str, float]:
126        """
127        Checks the skewness in each column of the DataFrame.
128
129        Returns
130        --------
131        dict[str, float]
132
133            A dictionary of all columns of the DataFrame with skewness values.
134            
135        Usage Recommendation
136        ---------------------
137            1. Use this function when you want to check how unevenly data is distributed around the mean (skewness).
138            2. Use only for numerical columns.
139
140        Example
141        ------- 
142        >>> Diagnosis(df).check_skewness()
143        """
144        from ..computations.Distribution import Distribution
145
146        skewness = Distribution(self.df).skewness()
147
148        skewness_dict = {col: round(float(skewness[col]), 4)for col in self.df[self.columns]}
149
150        return skewness_dict
151
152    def check_kurtosis(self, kurtosis_type='raw')-> dict[str, float]:
153        """
154        Checks the kurtosis value in each column of the DataFrame.
155
156        Parameters
157        ----------
158        kurtosis_type : str, optional
159            The type of kurtosis you would like to compute, default is 'raw'.
160
161            Types supported:
162            
163            - 'raw'
164            - 'excess'
165
166        Returns
167        --------
168        dict[str, float]
169            A dictionary of all columns of the DataFrame with skewness values.
170            
171        Usage Recommendation
172        ---------------------
173            1. Use this function when you want to check how unevenly data is distributed around the mean (skewness).
174            2. Use only for numerical columns.
175
176        Example
177        ------- 
178        >>> Diagnosis(df).check_skewness()
179        """ 
180        if not isinstance(kurtosis_type, str):
181            raise TypeError(f'kurtosis type must be a string, got {type(kurtosis_type).__name__}')
182
183        if kurtosis_type not in ['raw', 'excess']:
184            raise ValueError("Available kurtosis types: 'raw' or 'excess'.")
185
186        from ..computations import Distribution
187
188        raw_kurtosis = Distribution(self.df).raw_kurtosis()
189        excess_kurtosis = Distribution(self.df).excess_kurtosis()
190
191        if kurtosis_type == 'raw':
192            kurtosis_dict = {col: round(float(raw_kurtosis[col]), 4)for col in self.df[self.columns]}
193
194        if kurtosis_type == 'excess':
195            kurtosis_dict = {col: round(float(excess_kurtosis[col]), 4)for col in self.df[self.columns]}
196
197        return kurtosis_dict
198
199    def check_zero_variance(self)-> dict[str, float]:
200        """
201        Checks if the variance of a column is 0.
202
203        Returns
204        --------
205        dict[str, float]
206
207            A dictionary of all columns of the DataFrame with their variance
208            
209        Usage Recommendation
210        ---------------------
211            1. Use this function when you want to check if all the values in a column are exactly the same.
212            2. Use only for numerical columns.
213
214        Example
215        ------- 
216        >>> Diagnosis(df).check_zero_variance()
217        """
218        from ..computations.Statistics import Statistics
219        
220        zero_variance_dict = {}
221
222        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
223
224            variance = Statistics(self.df).variance()[col]
225
226            if (variance == 0):
227                zero_variance_dict[col] = variance
228            else:
229                zero_variance_dict[col] = round(float(variance), 3)
230
231        return zero_variance_dict
232
233    def check_distribution(self, skewness_threshold:int|float=1, kurtosis_threshold: int|float=2)-> dict[str, str]:
234        """
235        Classifies whether the distribution of data is normal or non-normal, based on skewness and kurtosis values.
236
237        Parameters
238        ----------
239        skewness_threshold : int or float, optional
240            Threshold of skewnes values above which distribution would be considered Non-Normal, default is |1|.
241
242        kurtosis_threshold : int or float, optional
243            Threshold of kurtosis values above which distribution would be considered Non-Normal, default is |2|.
244
245        Returns
246        --------
247        dict[str, str]
248            A dictionary of all columns with their classification as Normal or Non-Normal Distribution.
249            
250        Usage Recommendation
251        ---------------------
252            1. Use this function when you want to check which columns follow a Normal-Distribution and which ones follow a Non-Normal Distribution.
253            2. Use this function explicitly for EDA (Exploratory Data Analysis).
254            2. Use only for numerical columns.
255
256        Example
257        ------- 
258        >>> NumericalDiagnosis(df).check_distribution()
259        """ 
260        if not isinstance(skewness_threshold, (int, float)):
261            raise TypeError(f'skewness threshold must be an int or float, got {type(skewness_threshold).__name__}')
262
263        if not isinstance(kurtosis_threshold, (int, float)):
264            raise TypeError(f'skewness threshold must be an int or float, got {type(skewness_threshold).__name__}')
265
266        from ..computations.Distribution import Distribution
267
268        distribution_dict = {}
269        
270        skewness = Distribution(self.df).skewness()
271        kurtosis = Distribution(self.df).excess_kurtosis()
272
273        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
274            if (skewness.abs()[col] > skewness_threshold) & (kurtosis.abs()[col] > kurtosis_threshold):
275                distribution_dict[col] = 'Non-Normal Distribution'
276            else:
277                distribution_dict[col] = 'Normal Distribution'
278
279        return distribution_dict

Initializing the Numerical Diagnosis.

Parameters

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose.

columns: list, optional A list of columns you wish to apply numerical diagnosis on, by default None.

NumericalDiagnosis(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None) 
25    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None):
26
27
28        if not isinstance(df, pd.DataFrame):
29            raise TypeError(f'df must be a pandas DataFrame, got {type(df).__name__}')
30
31        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
32            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list of column names, got {type(columns).__name__}')
33
34        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include='number')
35
36        if columns is None:
37            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
38        else:
39            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
40
41        logger.info('Numerical Diagnosis initialized.')
df
def check_sparsity(self, value: int | float = 0) -> dict[str, float]: 
43    def check_sparsity(self, value: int|float = 0) -> dict[str, float]:
44        """
45        Checks the ratio of occurrence of a specific number (usually 0).
46
47        Parameters
48        -----------
49        value: int or float, optional
50            An integer or a decimal number, by default 0.
51
52        Returns
53        --------
54        dict[str, float]
55            A dictionary of column names and percentage of occurrence of a particular number.
56            
57        Usage Recommendation
58        --------------------
59            1. Use this function only for Exploratory Data Analysis.  
60            2. Mostly used to check how many values are 0 in a certain column. However, you can also use integers like 3 or floats like 5.888.
61            3. This function is intended to help you get an overview of which column may and may not contribute meaningfully to the analysis or ML.
62
63        Considerations
64        --------------
65            Pass numeric values after converting datatypes to int or float, instead of using strings.
66            
67        Example
68        --------
69        >>> NumericalCleaner(df).check_sparsity()
70        >>> NumericalCleaner(df).check_sparsity(5)
71        """
72        sparsity_dict = {
73            col: round(float((((self.df[col] == 0).sum())/len(self.df[col]))* 100), 2)
74            for col in self.df[self.columns]}
75
76        # Shows occurence of each value in percentage
77        logger.info(f'Occurrence of {value} in each column of the dataframe (in %)')
78        
79        return sparsity_dict

Checks the ratio of occurrence of a specific number (usually 0).

Parameters

value: int or float, optional An integer or a decimal number, by default 0.

Returns

dict[str, float] A dictionary of column names and percentage of occurrence of a particular number.

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function only for Exploratory Data Analysis.  
2. Mostly used to check how many values are 0 in a certain column. However, you can also use integers like 3 or floats like 5.888.
3. This function is intended to help you get an overview of which column may and may not contribute meaningfully to the analysis or ML.

Considerations

Pass numeric values after converting datatypes to int or float, instead of using strings.

Example

>>> NumericalCleaner(df).check_sparsity()
>>> NumericalCleaner(df).check_sparsity(5)
def detect_outliers(self, method: str = 'IQR') -> dict[str, pandas.core.series.Series]: 
 81    def detect_outliers(self, method: str ='IQR')-> dict[str, pd.Series]:
 82        """
 83        Detects outliers in one or multiple Numerical columns of the DataFrame.
 84
 85        Parameters
 86        -----------
 87        method : str (default is 'IQR')
 88            Method using which you wish to detect outliers.
 89
 90            Supports:
 91            
 92            - IQR
 93            - z-score
 94
 95        Returns
 96        -------
 97        dict[str, pd.Series]
 98            A pandas Series of columns with outliers.
 99            
100        Usage Recommendation
101        --------------------
102            1. Use this function when you want to check if there are any outliers in your data.
103            2. Use this function only for Numerical data (numbers).
104
105        Example
106        -------- 
107        >>> NumericalDiagnosis(df).detect_outliers()
108        """
109        from datalab import Outliers
110
111        outliers_dict  = {}
112
113        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
114            
115            if method == 'IQR':
116                
117                outliers_dict[col] = Outliers(self.df).iqr_outliers()[col]
118
119            elif method == 'z_score':
120
121                outliers_dict[col] = Outliers(self.df).zscore_outliers()[col]
122            
123        return outliers_dict

Detects outliers in one or multiple Numerical columns of the DataFrame.

Parameters

method : str (default is 'IQR') Method using which you wish to detect outliers.

Supports:

- IQR
- z-score

Returns

dict[str, pd.Series] A pandas Series of columns with outliers.

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to check if there are any outliers in your data.
2. Use this function only for Numerical data (numbers).

Example

>>> NumericalDiagnosis(df).detect_outliers()
def check_skewness(self) -> dict[str, float]: 
125    def check_skewness(self)-> dict[str, float]:
126        """
127        Checks the skewness in each column of the DataFrame.
128
129        Returns
130        --------
131        dict[str, float]
132
133            A dictionary of all columns of the DataFrame with skewness values.
134            
135        Usage Recommendation
136        ---------------------
137            1. Use this function when you want to check how unevenly data is distributed around the mean (skewness).
138            2. Use only for numerical columns.
139
140        Example
141        ------- 
142        >>> Diagnosis(df).check_skewness()
143        """
144        from ..computations.Distribution import Distribution
145
146        skewness = Distribution(self.df).skewness()
147
148        skewness_dict = {col: round(float(skewness[col]), 4)for col in self.df[self.columns]}
149
150        return skewness_dict

Checks the skewness in each column of the DataFrame.

Returns

dict[str, float]

A dictionary of all columns of the DataFrame with skewness values.

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to check how unevenly data is distributed around the mean (skewness).
2. Use only for numerical columns.

Example

>>> Diagnosis(df).check_skewness()
def check_kurtosis(self, kurtosis_type='raw') -> dict[str, float]: 
152    def check_kurtosis(self, kurtosis_type='raw')-> dict[str, float]:
153        """
154        Checks the kurtosis value in each column of the DataFrame.
155
156        Parameters
157        ----------
158        kurtosis_type : str, optional
159            The type of kurtosis you would like to compute, default is 'raw'.
160
161            Types supported:
162            
163            - 'raw'
164            - 'excess'
165
166        Returns
167        --------
168        dict[str, float]
169            A dictionary of all columns of the DataFrame with skewness values.
170            
171        Usage Recommendation
172        ---------------------
173            1. Use this function when you want to check how unevenly data is distributed around the mean (skewness).
174            2. Use only for numerical columns.
175
176        Example
177        ------- 
178        >>> Diagnosis(df).check_skewness()
179        """ 
180        if not isinstance(kurtosis_type, str):
181            raise TypeError(f'kurtosis type must be a string, got {type(kurtosis_type).__name__}')
182
183        if kurtosis_type not in ['raw', 'excess']:
184            raise ValueError("Available kurtosis types: 'raw' or 'excess'.")
185
186        from ..computations import Distribution
187
188        raw_kurtosis = Distribution(self.df).raw_kurtosis()
189        excess_kurtosis = Distribution(self.df).excess_kurtosis()
190
191        if kurtosis_type == 'raw':
192            kurtosis_dict = {col: round(float(raw_kurtosis[col]), 4)for col in self.df[self.columns]}
193
194        if kurtosis_type == 'excess':
195            kurtosis_dict = {col: round(float(excess_kurtosis[col]), 4)for col in self.df[self.columns]}
196
197        return kurtosis_dict

Checks the kurtosis value in each column of the DataFrame.

Parameters

kurtosis_type : str, optional The type of kurtosis you would like to compute, default is 'raw'.

Types supported:

- 'raw'
- 'excess'

Returns

dict[str, float] A dictionary of all columns of the DataFrame with skewness values.

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to check how unevenly data is distributed around the mean (skewness).
2. Use only for numerical columns.

Example

>>> Diagnosis(df).check_skewness()
def check_zero_variance(self) -> dict[str, float]: 
199    def check_zero_variance(self)-> dict[str, float]:
200        """
201        Checks if the variance of a column is 0.
202
203        Returns
204        --------
205        dict[str, float]
206
207            A dictionary of all columns of the DataFrame with their variance
208            
209        Usage Recommendation
210        ---------------------
211            1. Use this function when you want to check if all the values in a column are exactly the same.
212            2. Use only for numerical columns.
213
214        Example
215        ------- 
216        >>> Diagnosis(df).check_zero_variance()
217        """
218        from ..computations.Statistics import Statistics
219        
220        zero_variance_dict = {}
221
222        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
223
224            variance = Statistics(self.df).variance()[col]
225
226            if (variance == 0):
227                zero_variance_dict[col] = variance
228            else:
229                zero_variance_dict[col] = round(float(variance), 3)
230
231        return zero_variance_dict

Checks if the variance of a column is 0.

Returns

dict[str, float]

A dictionary of all columns of the DataFrame with their variance

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to check if all the values in a column are exactly the same.
2. Use only for numerical columns.

Example

>>> Diagnosis(df).check_zero_variance()
def check_distribution( self, skewness_threshold: int | float = 1, kurtosis_threshold: int | float = 2) -> dict[str, str]: 
233    def check_distribution(self, skewness_threshold:int|float=1, kurtosis_threshold: int|float=2)-> dict[str, str]:
234        """
235        Classifies whether the distribution of data is normal or non-normal, based on skewness and kurtosis values.
236
237        Parameters
238        ----------
239        skewness_threshold : int or float, optional
240            Threshold of skewnes values above which distribution would be considered Non-Normal, default is |1|.
241
242        kurtosis_threshold : int or float, optional
243            Threshold of kurtosis values above which distribution would be considered Non-Normal, default is |2|.
244
245        Returns
246        --------
247        dict[str, str]
248            A dictionary of all columns with their classification as Normal or Non-Normal Distribution.
249            
250        Usage Recommendation
251        ---------------------
252            1. Use this function when you want to check which columns follow a Normal-Distribution and which ones follow a Non-Normal Distribution.
253            2. Use this function explicitly for EDA (Exploratory Data Analysis).
254            2. Use only for numerical columns.
255
256        Example
257        ------- 
258        >>> NumericalDiagnosis(df).check_distribution()
259        """ 
260        if not isinstance(skewness_threshold, (int, float)):
261            raise TypeError(f'skewness threshold must be an int or float, got {type(skewness_threshold).__name__}')
262
263        if not isinstance(kurtosis_threshold, (int, float)):
264            raise TypeError(f'skewness threshold must be an int or float, got {type(skewness_threshold).__name__}')
265
266        from ..computations.Distribution import Distribution
267
268        distribution_dict = {}
269        
270        skewness = Distribution(self.df).skewness()
271        kurtosis = Distribution(self.df).excess_kurtosis()
272
273        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
274            if (skewness.abs()[col] > skewness_threshold) & (kurtosis.abs()[col] > kurtosis_threshold):
275                distribution_dict[col] = 'Non-Normal Distribution'
276            else:
277                distribution_dict[col] = 'Normal Distribution'
278
279        return distribution_dict

Classifies whether the distribution of data is normal or non-normal, based on skewness and kurtosis values.

Parameters

skewness_threshold : int or float, optional Threshold of skewnes values above which distribution would be considered Non-Normal, default is |1|.

kurtosis_threshold : int or float, optional Threshold of kurtosis values above which distribution would be considered Non-Normal, default is |2|.

Returns

dict[str, str] A dictionary of all columns with their classification as Normal or Non-Normal Distribution.

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to check which columns follow a Normal-Distribution and which ones follow a Non-Normal Distribution.
2. Use this function explicitly for EDA (Exploratory Data Analysis).
2. Use only for numerical columns.

Example

>>> NumericalDiagnosis(df).check_distribution()
class TextDiagnosis: 
 13class TextDiagnosis:
 14    """
 15    Initializing Text Diagnosis.
 16
 17    Parameters:
 18    -----------
 19    df: pd.DataFrame
 20        A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose.
 21
 22    columns: list, optional
 23        A list of columns you wish to diagnose text in, by default None.
 24        
 25    """
 26
 27    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None):
 28
 29        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include = ['string', 'object', 'category'])
 30
 31        if columns is not None:
 32            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 33        else:
 34            self.columns = self.df.columns
 35
 36        logger.info(f'Text Diagnosis Initialized.')
 37    
 38    def detect_empty_string(self) -> dict[str, pd.DataFrame]:
 39        """
 40        Filters rows with empty strings for each column of Text DataFrame (string, object or category type columns).
 41
 42        Returns
 43        --------
 44        dict[str, pd.DataFrame]
 45            A dictionary of columns names with rows of DataFrame containing empty strings as text
 46
 47        Usage Recommendation
 48        ---------------------
 49            Use this function when you want to diagnose rows with empty strings during text diagnosis.
 50
 51        Considerations
 52        ---------------
 53            This function uses polars's filter method to filter out rows where value is an empty string ("").
 54
 55        Example:
 56        --------
 57        >>> TextDiagnosis(df).detect_empty_string()
 58        
 59        """
 60        empty_strings_dict = {}
 61
 62        # generating index as a column
 63        self.df = self.df.reset_index()
 64
 65        # converting pandas -> polars with the index column, to preserve rows
 66        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df).pandas_to_polars()
 67
 68        columns_to_diagnose = [column for column in polars_df.columns if column!='index']
 69        
 70        for column in columns_to_diagnose:
 71            # ensuring that length of string should be equal to 0
 72            series_mask = (polars_df[column].str.len_chars() == 0)
 73            
 74            result_df = BackendConverter(polars_df.filter(series_mask)).polars_to_pandas()
 75
 76            result_df.set_index('index', inplace=True)
 77
 78            empty_strings_dict[column] = result_df
 79
 80        return empty_strings_dict
 81
 82    def detect_splitters(self, splitters:list = None)-> dict[str, pd.DataFrame]:
 83        """
 84        Filters rows with splitters for one or multiple columns of Text DataFrame.
 85
 86        Parameters
 87        ----------
 88        splitters: list
 89            A list of splitters that may be present in your text, default is ','
 90
 91        Returns
 92        --------
 93        dict[str, pd.DataFrame]
 94            A dictionary of columns names with rows of DataFrame containing splitters in text
 95
 96        Usage Recommendation
 97        ---------------------
 98            Use this function when you want to diagnose rows of text where values are split.
 99
100        Considerations
101        ---------------
102            This function uses polars's filter method to filter out rows where values have a splitter.
103
104        Example:
105        --------
106        >>> TextDiagnosis(df).detect_splitters()
107        
108        """
109
110        if not isinstance(splitters, (list, type(None))):
111            raise TypeError(f'splitters must be a list of strings, got {type(splitters).__name__}')
112
113        if splitters is None:
114            splitters = [","]
115        
116        splitters_dict = {}
117
118        self.df = self.df.reset_index()
119
120        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df).pandas_to_polars()
121
122        columns_to_diagnose = [column for column in polars_df.columns if column!='index']
123
124        # joining splitters to convert them into a regex pattern for detecting splitters
125        joined_splitters=f'[{"".join(splitters)}]+'
126
127        # filtering rowx where text contains splitters passed in by the user
128        for column in columns_to_diagnose:
129            series_mask = (polars_df[column].str.contains(joined_splitters))
130            
131            result_df = BackendConverter(polars_df.filter(series_mask)).polars_to_pandas()
132            # setting 'index' as index of pandas DataFrame
133            result_df.set_index('index', inplace=True)
134
135            splitters_dict[column] = result_df
136
137        return splitters_dict

Initializing Text Diagnosis.

Parameters:

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose.

columns: list, optional A list of columns you wish to diagnose text in, by default None.

TextDiagnosis(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None) 
27    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None):
28
29        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include = ['string', 'object', 'category'])
30
31        if columns is not None:
32            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
33        else:
34            self.columns = self.df.columns
35
36        logger.info(f'Text Diagnosis Initialized.')
df
def detect_empty_string(self) -> dict[str, pandas.core.frame.DataFrame]: 
38    def detect_empty_string(self) -> dict[str, pd.DataFrame]:
39        """
40        Filters rows with empty strings for each column of Text DataFrame (string, object or category type columns).
41
42        Returns
43        --------
44        dict[str, pd.DataFrame]
45            A dictionary of columns names with rows of DataFrame containing empty strings as text
46
47        Usage Recommendation
48        ---------------------
49            Use this function when you want to diagnose rows with empty strings during text diagnosis.
50
51        Considerations
52        ---------------
53            This function uses polars's filter method to filter out rows where value is an empty string ("").
54
55        Example:
56        --------
57        >>> TextDiagnosis(df).detect_empty_string()
58        
59        """
60        empty_strings_dict = {}
61
62        # generating index as a column
63        self.df = self.df.reset_index()
64
65        # converting pandas -> polars with the index column, to preserve rows
66        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df).pandas_to_polars()
67
68        columns_to_diagnose = [column for column in polars_df.columns if column!='index']
69        
70        for column in columns_to_diagnose:
71            # ensuring that length of string should be equal to 0
72            series_mask = (polars_df[column].str.len_chars() == 0)
73            
74            result_df = BackendConverter(polars_df.filter(series_mask)).polars_to_pandas()
75
76            result_df.set_index('index', inplace=True)
77
78            empty_strings_dict[column] = result_df
79
80        return empty_strings_dict

Filters rows with empty strings for each column of Text DataFrame (string, object or category type columns).

Returns

dict[str, pd.DataFrame] A dictionary of columns names with rows of DataFrame containing empty strings as text

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when you want to diagnose rows with empty strings during text diagnosis.

Considerations

This function uses polars's filter method to filter out rows where value is an empty string ("").

Example:

>>> TextDiagnosis(df).detect_empty_string()
def detect_splitters(self, splitters: list = None) -> dict[str, pandas.core.frame.DataFrame]: 
 82    def detect_splitters(self, splitters:list = None)-> dict[str, pd.DataFrame]:
 83        """
 84        Filters rows with splitters for one or multiple columns of Text DataFrame.
 85
 86        Parameters
 87        ----------
 88        splitters: list
 89            A list of splitters that may be present in your text, default is ','
 90
 91        Returns
 92        --------
 93        dict[str, pd.DataFrame]
 94            A dictionary of columns names with rows of DataFrame containing splitters in text
 95
 96        Usage Recommendation
 97        ---------------------
 98            Use this function when you want to diagnose rows of text where values are split.
 99
100        Considerations
101        ---------------
102            This function uses polars's filter method to filter out rows where values have a splitter.
103
104        Example:
105        --------
106        >>> TextDiagnosis(df).detect_splitters()
107        
108        """
109
110        if not isinstance(splitters, (list, type(None))):
111            raise TypeError(f'splitters must be a list of strings, got {type(splitters).__name__}')
112
113        if splitters is None:
114            splitters = [","]
115        
116        splitters_dict = {}
117
118        self.df = self.df.reset_index()
119
120        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df).pandas_to_polars()
121
122        columns_to_diagnose = [column for column in polars_df.columns if column!='index']
123
124        # joining splitters to convert them into a regex pattern for detecting splitters
125        joined_splitters=f'[{"".join(splitters)}]+'
126
127        # filtering rowx where text contains splitters passed in by the user
128        for column in columns_to_diagnose:
129            series_mask = (polars_df[column].str.contains(joined_splitters))
130            
131            result_df = BackendConverter(polars_df.filter(series_mask)).polars_to_pandas()
132            # setting 'index' as index of pandas DataFrame
133            result_df.set_index('index', inplace=True)
134
135            splitters_dict[column] = result_df
136
137        return splitters_dict

Filters rows with splitters for one or multiple columns of Text DataFrame.

Parameters

splitters: list A list of splitters that may be present in your text, default is ','

Returns

dict[str, pd.DataFrame] A dictionary of columns names with rows of DataFrame containing splitters in text

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when you want to diagnose rows of text where values are split.

Considerations

This function uses polars's filter method to filter out rows where values have a splitter.

Example:

>>> TextDiagnosis(df).detect_splitters()
class CategoricalDiagnosis: 
11class CategoricalDiagnosis():
12    """
13    Initializing Categorical Diagnosis.
14
15    Parameters
16    -----------
17    df: pd.DataFrame
18        A pandas DataFrame.
19
20    columns : list, optional
21        A list of column names you want to apply diagnosis on, by default None.
22    """
23
24    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns: list|type(None) = None):
25
26        if not isinstance(df, pd.DataFrame):
27            raise TypeError(f'df must be a pandas DataFrame, got {type(df).__name__}')
28
29        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
30            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list of column names, got {type(columns).__name__}')
31
32        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include=['object', 'string', 'category'])
33
34        if columns is None:
35            self.columns = self.df.columns.to_list()
36        else:
37            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
38
39        logger.info(f'Categorical Diagnosis initialized.')
40
41    def count_unique_categories(self):
42        """Shows count of unique categories in one or multiple columns of DataFrame.
43
44        Returns
45        --------
46        dict
47            A dictionary of count of unique categories in each column
48        """
49        
50        unique_categories = {}
51
52        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
53            unique_categories[column]=len(self.df[column].unique())
54
55        return unique_categories
56
57    def show_frequency(self, method='count'):
58        """Shows frequency ('count' or 'percent') of categories in one or multiple columns of DataFrame.
59
60        Parameters
61        -----------
62        method : str 
63            Whether frequency should be a count or a percentage.
64
65            Available methods:
66
67            - 'count': Counts the number of unique values in each category (default).
68            - 'percent': Calculates the percentage of values in each category.
69        """
70        # using a dictionary for storing frequency of category values
71        frequency_count = {}
72
73        # getting the percentage
74        # renaming as frequency count and rounding off to 2 places 
75        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
76            
77            if method == 'count':
78                frequency_count[column]=self.df[column].value_counts().rename(f'Frequency Count')
79
80            elif method == 'percent':
81                frequency_count[column]=self.df[column].value_counts(normalize=True).rename(f'Frequency Percentage').round(2)
82
83            else:
84                raise ValueError("Unknown method. Valid methods: 'sum' (default) or 'percent'")
85        # returning the dictionary of frequency percentage
86        
87        return frequency_count

Initializing Categorical Diagnosis.

Parameters

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame.

columns : list, optional A list of column names you want to apply diagnosis on, by default None.

CategoricalDiagnosis(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list | None = None) 
24    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns: list|type(None) = None):
25
26        if not isinstance(df, pd.DataFrame):
27            raise TypeError(f'df must be a pandas DataFrame, got {type(df).__name__}')
28
29        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
30            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list of column names, got {type(columns).__name__}')
31
32        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include=['object', 'string', 'category'])
33
34        if columns is None:
35            self.columns = self.df.columns.to_list()
36        else:
37            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
38
39        logger.info(f'Categorical Diagnosis initialized.')
df
def count_unique_categories(self): 
41    def count_unique_categories(self):
42        """Shows count of unique categories in one or multiple columns of DataFrame.
43
44        Returns
45        --------
46        dict
47            A dictionary of count of unique categories in each column
48        """
49        
50        unique_categories = {}
51
52        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
53            unique_categories[column]=len(self.df[column].unique())
54
55        return unique_categories

Shows count of unique categories in one or multiple columns of DataFrame.

Returns

dict A dictionary of count of unique categories in each column

def show_frequency(self, method='count'): 
57    def show_frequency(self, method='count'):
58        """Shows frequency ('count' or 'percent') of categories in one or multiple columns of DataFrame.
59
60        Parameters
61        -----------
62        method : str 
63            Whether frequency should be a count or a percentage.
64
65            Available methods:
66
67            - 'count': Counts the number of unique values in each category (default).
68            - 'percent': Calculates the percentage of values in each category.
69        """
70        # using a dictionary for storing frequency of category values
71        frequency_count = {}
72
73        # getting the percentage
74        # renaming as frequency count and rounding off to 2 places 
75        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
76            
77            if method == 'count':
78                frequency_count[column]=self.df[column].value_counts().rename(f'Frequency Count')
79
80            elif method == 'percent':
81                frequency_count[column]=self.df[column].value_counts(normalize=True).rename(f'Frequency Percentage').round(2)
82
83            else:
84                raise ValueError("Unknown method. Valid methods: 'sum' (default) or 'percent'")
85        # returning the dictionary of frequency percentage
86        
87        return frequency_count

Shows frequency ('count' or 'percent') of categories in one or multiple columns of DataFrame.

Parameters

method : str Whether frequency should be a count or a percentage.

Available methods:

- 'count': Counts the number of unique values in each category (default).
- 'percent': Calculates the percentage of values in each category.
class DirtyDataDiagnosis: 
 10class DirtyDataDiagnosis:
 11    """
 12    Initialize the DirtyDataDiagnosis class.
 13
 14    Parameters
 15    -----------
 16    df: pd.DataFrame
 17        A pandas dataframe you wish to diagnose.
 18
 19    columns: list, optional
 20        A list of columns you wish to diagnose, by default None.
 21
 22    array_type: str, optional
 23        The backend you wish to work with in pandas: 'numpy' or 'pyarrow', by default 'auto'.
 24
 25    conversion_threshold: int, optional
 26        The number of rows upon which backend automatically switches to 'pyarrow' in pandas, by default 100000.
 27    """
 28
 29    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns: list = None, array_type='auto', conversion_threshold: int= None):
 30     
 31        if not isinstance(df, pd.DataFrame):
 32            raise TypeError(f'df must be a pandas DataFrame, got {type(df).__name__}')
 33
 34        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
 35            raise TypeError(f'columns must be list of strings or type None, got {type(columns).__name__}')
 36
 37        if not isinstance(array_type, str):
 38            raise TypeError(f'array type must be a string, got {type(array_type).__name__}')
 39
 40        if not isinstance(conversion_threshold, (int, type(None))):
 41            raise TypeError(f'conversion threshold must be an integer or type None, got {type(conversion_threshold).__name__}')
 42
 43        self.df = df
 44     
 45        if columns is None:
 46            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
 47        else:
 48            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 49
 50        self.array_type= array_type
 51        self.conversion_threshold = conversion_threshold
 52
 53        logger.info(f'Dirty Data Diagnosis initialized with {self.array_type} backend.')
 54
 55    def diagnose_numbers(self, show_available_methods: bool=False)-> dict[str, dict[str, pd.DataFrame]]:
 56        """Detects patterns and common formatting issues in numbers in each column of the DataFrame.
 57
 58        The following diagnostics are computed per column:
 59
 60        - is_valid:                Values containing only valid integers or decimals (e.g: 1000, -10.048)
 61        - is_text:                 Values containing alphabetic characters and spaces ('unknown', 'error', 'missing', what)
 62        - is_dirty:                Values that are not strictly numeric (e.g: approx 1000, $100,00CD#44)
 63        - is_missing:              Values that are null or missing values (pandas missing types- NA or NaN)
 64        - is_scientific_notation:  Numbers expressed in scientific notation (e.g: 1.06E+1)
 65        - has_commas:              Numbers that contain commas (e.g: 10,000 or 1,000,000)
 66        - has_decimals:            Numbers that contain decimal points (e.g: -1.62, 1000.44)
 67        - has_units:               Numbers that are suffixed with alphabetical units (e.g: '10kg', '100cm')
 68        - has_symbols:             Numbers containing non-alphanumeric or special symbols (e.g: '?', '/' , '.')
 69        - has_currency:            Numbers containing currency symbols (prefix or suffix) (e.g. $10 or 10$)
 70        - has_spaces:              Numbers that contain leading or trailing spaces (e.g: '  missing', '1.066 ', '1.34    ')
 71        - has_multiple_decimals:     Numbers that contain double decimals (e.g: 1.34.567, 1.4444.0000)
 72        - has_multiple_commas:     Numbers that contain more than one commas (e.g: '9,628,62' or '1234,56')
 73
 74        Parameters
 75        -----------
 76        show_available_methods : bool (default is False)
 77            Shows diagnostic options that are available in diagnose_numbers() method.
 78
 79        Returns
 80        --------
 81        dict[str, dict[str, pd.DataFrame]]
 82            A nested dictionary of diagnostic results per column.
 83
 84        Usage Recommendation
 85        ---------------------
 86            1. Use this function when you want to see what kind of issues exist in columns that contain numbers in your DataFrame
 87
 88        Considerations
 89        ---------------
 90            1. This method adds a default **index** column by resetting the DataFrame's index.
 91            2. This is necessary to preserve original row IDs during conversion to Polars and back.
 92            3. The index column DOES NOT AFFECT your transformations and are automatically restored in all returned DataFrames
 93            4. This method also uses Polars regex under the hood for pattern matching
 94            5. This method is intended for diagnostic purposes, not data mutation.
 95
 96        Example
 97        --------
 98        >>>     diagnostics = DirtyDataDiagnosis(df).diagnose_numbers()
 99
100        >>>     diagnostics['price']['has_currency'].head()
101        """
102        from ..utils.BackendConverter import BackendConverter
103        
104        # resetting index to ensure index is turned into a new column 'index' in pandas dataframe
105        self.df = self.df.reset_index()   
106
107        # passing dataframe including the new column 'index'
108        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df).pandas_to_polars()
109
110        numeric_diagnosis = {}
111
112        # patterns is a dictionary of available methods and regex patterns to detect them 
113        PATTERNS = {
114            'is_valid': r'^[+-]?\d+(\.\d+)?$',
115            'is_dirty': r'^[+-]?\d+(\.\d+)?$',  # keeping the same as 'is_valid' since everything that is not valid will be dirty
116            'is_text': r'^[A-Za-z ]+$',
117            'is_symbol': r'^[^A-Za-z0-9]$',
118            'is_missing': None,
119            'is_scientific_notation': r'^[+-]?\d+(?:[.,]\d+)?[eE][+-]?\d*$',
120            'has_units': r'^[+-]?\d+(?:[,.]\d+)?\s*[A-Za-z]+$',
121            'has_symbols': r"[^\d\s\p{Sc}\p{L},.+-]\d+|\d+[^\d\s\p{Sc}\p{L},.+-]",
122            'has_commas': r'^\d*,\d*$',
123            'has_currency': r'^[\p{Sc}]\s*\d[\d,]*(\.\d+)?$|^\d[\d,]*(\.\d+)?\s*[\p{Sc}]$',
124            'has_multiple_decimals': r'^[+-]?\d*(?:\.\d+){2,}$',
125            'has_multiple_commas': r'^[+-]?\d*(?:,\d+){2,}$',
126            'has_spaces': r'^\s+[+-]?\d+(?:\.\d+)?$|^[+-]?\d+(?:\.\d+)?\s+$|^\s+[+-]?\d+(?:\.\d+)?\s+$',
127            'has_decimals': r'^[+-]?\d*\.\d+$',
128            'has_text': r'(?i)(?:[A-Za-z]+.*\d+|\d+.*[A-Za-z])'
129            }
130
131        # excluding index column so that it is not involved in diagnosis 
132        columns_to_diagnose = [column for column in polars_df.columns if column != 'index']
133
134        for col in columns_to_diagnose:
135            
136            numeric_diagnosis[col] = {}
137            series = polars_df[col]
138
139            for method, pattern in PATTERNS.items():
140                
141                if method == 'is_missing':
142                    pattern_mask = series.is_null()
143
144                elif method == 'is_dirty':
145
146                    pattern_mask = ~series.str.contains(PATTERNS['is_valid'])
147
148                elif method == 'has_text':
149                    # ensuring that only text that is not units or scientific notation is detected
150                    pattern_mask = (series.str.contains(PATTERNS['has_text'])
151                     & ~series.str.contains(PATTERNS['has_units'])
152                     & ~series.str.contains(PATTERNS['is_scientific_notation']))
153
154                else:
155                    pattern_mask = series.str.contains(pattern)
156                
157                # filtering pattern masks out of the polars dataframe 
158                result_df = BackendConverter(polars_df.filter(pattern_mask)).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold = self.conversion_threshold)
159
160                # setting default index to be 'index'
161                result_df.set_index('index', inplace=True)
162
163                numeric_diagnosis[col][method] = result_df
164                
165        if show_available_methods:
166            logger.info(f'Available diagnostic methods: {list(numeric_diagnosis[col].keys())}')
167
168        return numeric_diagnosis
169
170    def diagnose_text(self, show_available_methods=False)-> dict[str, dict[str, pd.DataFrame]]:
171        """Detects patterns and common formatting issues in text in each column of the DataFrame.
172
173        The following diagnostics are computed per column:
174        
175        - is_symbol:    Values containing only symbols.
176        - is_valid:     Values containing alphabetic characters and spaces
177        - is_dirty:     Values that are not strictly text
178        - is_empty:     Values that are empty strings
179        - has_symbols:  Values containing non-alphanumeric or special symbols
180        - is_missing:      Values that are null or missing values.
181        - has_numbers:  Values that contain numbers in text.
182        - has_spaces:   Values that contain leading or trailing spaces 
183
184        Parameters
185        -----------
186        show_available_methods : bool (default is False)
187            Shows diagnostic options that are available in diagnose_numbers() method.
188
189        Returns
190        --------
191        dict[str, dict[str, pd.DataFrame]]
192            A nested dictionary of diagnostic results per column.
193
194        Usage Recommendation
195        ---------------------
196            1. Use this function when you want to see what kind of issues exist in columns that contain text in your DataFrame
197
198        Considerations
199        ---------------
200            1. This method adds a default **index** column by resetting the DataFrame's index.
201            2. This is necessary to preserve original row IDs during conversion to Polars and back.
202            3. The index column DOES NOT AFFECT your transformations and are automatically restored in all returned DataFrames
203            4. This method also uses Polars regex under the hood for pattern matching
204            5. This method is intended for diagnostic purposes, not data mutation.
205
206        Example
207        --------
208        >>>     diagnostics = DirtyDataDiagnosis(df).diagnose_text()
209
210        >>>     diagnostics['user_id']['is_dirty'].head()
211        """
212        from ..utils.BackendConverter import BackendConverter
213
214        self.df = self.df.reset_index()
215        
216        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df).pandas_to_polars()
217
218        columns_to_diagnose = [column for column in polars_df.columns if column!= 'index']
219
220        text_diagnosis = {}
221
222        PATTERNS = {
223                'is_dirty': r'^[^A-Za-z ]+$',
224                'is_symbol': r'^[^\p{L}]+$',
225                'is_empty': r'^$',
226                'has_symbols': r'\p{L}.*[^\p{L}]|[^\p{L}].*\p{L}',
227                'is_valid': r'^[A-Za-z ]+$',
228                'is_missing': None,
229                'has_spaces': r'^\s|\s$',
230                'has_numbers': r'\p{N}'
231            }
232
233        for col in columns_to_diagnose:
234
235            text_diagnosis[col] = {}
236
237            series = polars_df[col]
238
239            for method, pattern in PATTERNS.items():
240                
241                if method == 'is_null': 
242                    pattern_mask = series.is_null()
243
244                elif method == 'is_dirty':
245                    pattern_mask = series.str.contains(PATTERNS['is_dirty'])
246
247                else:
248                    pattern_mask = series.str.contains(pattern)
249
250                # ensuring by default, pyarrow is used for datasets over 100000 rows
251                
252                result_df = BackendConverter(polars_df.filter(pattern_mask)).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold = self.conversion_threshold)
253
254                result_df.set_index('index', inplace=True)
255
256                text_diagnosis[col][method] = result_df
257
258        if show_available_methods:
