155            self.track_not_cleaned(col = col, method= 'remove_spaces', before = before, mask = mask, after = after)
156        
157        if self.inplace:
158            self.df[self.columns] = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
159            logger.info(f'Removed leading or trailing spaces in place.')
160            return None    
161        else:
162            df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
163            logger.info(f'Removed leading or trailing spaces.')
164            return df

Removes leading or trailing spaces in numerical data.

Returns

pd.DataFrame
    A pandas DataFrame with removed trailing or leading spaces.

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to remove leading or trailing spaces in numbers.

Considerations

1. Use this method only on numerical data.
2. This method keeps a track of values that cannot be cleaned.

Example

>>>    NumericalCleaner(df).remove_spaces()
def remove_units(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
166    def remove_units(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
167        """Detects units (like cm or kg) appearing after numbers and removes them.
168
169        Returns
170        --------
171            pd.DataFrame
172                A pandas DataFrame
173
174        Usage Recommendation
175        ---------------------
176            1. Use this function when you want to clean numbers that contain units or text appearing after numbers.
177        
178        Considerations
179        ---------------
180            1. Use this method only on numerical data.
181            2. This method keeps a track of values that cannot be cleaned.
182
183        Example:
184        --------
185        >>>    NumericalCleaner(df).remove_units()
186        """
187        # pattern for detecting rows containing units
188        UNITS_PATTERN = r'^[+-]?\d+(?:[,.]\d+)?\s*[A-Za-z]+$'
189
190        # pattern for detecting only text, so we can use this to replace the units
191        units = r'\s*[A-Za-z]+$'
192        
193        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
194
195        for col in polars_df.columns:
196
197            before = polars_df.select(pl.col(col)).to_series()
198            mask = polars_df.select(pl.col(col).str.contains(UNITS_PATTERN)).to_series()
199            polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(
200                pl.when(pl.col(col).str.contains(UNITS_PATTERN))
201                .then(pl.col(col).str.replace_all(units, ""))
202                .otherwise(pl.col(col))
203                )
204            after = polars_df.select(pl.col(col)).to_series()
205        
206            self.track_not_cleaned(col = col, method= 'remove_units', before = before, mask = mask, after = after)
207
208        if self.inplace:
209            self.df[self.columns] = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
210            logger.info(f'Removed units in place.')
211            return None    
212        else:
213            df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
214            logger.info(f'Removed units.')
215            return df

Detects units (like cm or kg) appearing after numbers and removes them.

Returns

pd.DataFrame
    A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to clean numbers that contain units or text appearing after numbers.

Considerations

1. Use this method only on numerical data.
2. This method keeps a track of values that cannot be cleaned.

Example:

>>>    NumericalCleaner(df).remove_units()
def remove_currency_symbols(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
217    def remove_currency_symbols(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
218        """
219        Removes currency symbols appearing before or after numbers.
220
221        Returns
222        --------
223        pd.DataFrame
224            A pandas DataFrame
225
226        Usage Recommendation
227        ---------------------
228            1. Use this function when you want to remove currency symbols like $.
229
230        Considerations
231        ---------------
232            1. Use this method only on numerical data.
233            2. This method keeps a track of values that cannot be cleaned.
234
235        Example:
236        ---------
237        >>>    NumericalCleaner(df).remove_currency_symbols()
238        """
239        # ensuring that currency is detected at beginning or end of string
240        CURRENCY_SYMBOLS_PATTERN = r'^[$]\s*\d[\d,]*(.\d+)?$|^\d[\d,]*(.\d+)?s*[$]$'
241
242        CURRENCY_SYMBOLS = r'^[$]\s*|\s*[$]$'
243        
244        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
245
246        for col in polars_df.columns:
247            before = polars_df.select(pl.col(col)).to_series()
248            mask = polars_df.select(pl.col(col).str.contains(CURRENCY_SYMBOLS_PATTERN)).to_series()
249            
250            polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(
251                pl.when(pl.col(col).str.contains(CURRENCY_SYMBOLS_PATTERN))
252                .then(pl.col(col).str.replace_all(CURRENCY_SYMBOLS_PATTERN, ""))
253                .otherwise(pl.col(col))
254            )
255            after = polars_df.select(pl.col(col)).to_series()
256        
257            self.track_not_cleaned(col = col, method= 'remove_currency_symbols', before = before, mask = mask, after = after)
258
259        if self.inplace:
260            self.df[self.columns] = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
261            logger.info(f'Removed currency symbols in place.')
262            return None    
263        else:
264            df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
265            logger.info(f'Removed currency symbols.')
266            return df

Removes currency symbols appearing before or after numbers.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to remove currency symbols like $.

Considerations

1. Use this method only on numerical data.
2. This method keeps a track of values that cannot be cleaned.

Example:

>>>    NumericalCleaner(df).remove_currency_symbols()
def replace_commas(self, replacement: str = None): 
268    def replace_commas(self, replacement: str=None):
269        """
270        Replaces commas (,) that are used as decimal replacements, with decimals (.) or any other value.
271
272        Parameters
273        -----------
274        replacement: str, optional
275            Value you wish to replace commas with, by default None
276
277        Returns
278        --------
279        pd.DataFrame
280            A pandas DataFrame
281
282        Usage Recommendation
283        ---------------------
284            1. Use this function when you want to replace commas with decimal values during numerical cleaning.
285        
286        Considerations
287        ---------------
288            1. Use this method only on numerical data.
289            2. This method keeps a track of values that cannot be cleaned.
290
291        Example
292        ---------
293        >>>    NumericalCleaner(df).replace_commas(replacement = "")
294
295        >>>    NumericalCleaner(df).replace_commas(replacement = '.', inplace=True)
296        """
297        from ..utils.BackendConverter import BackendConverter
298
299        if not isinstance(replacement, (str, type(None))):
300            raise TypeError(f'replacement must be a string, got {type(replacement).__name__}')
301
302        if replacement is None:
303            replacement = ','
304
305        PATTERN = r'^\d*,\d*$'
306
307        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
308
309        for col in polars_df.columns:
310            before = polars_df.select(pl.col(col)).to_series()
311            mask = polars_df.select(pl.col(col).str.contains(PATTERN)).to_series()
312            
313            polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(
314                pl.when(pl.col(col).str.contains(PATTERN))
315                .then(pl.col(col).str.replace_all(',', replacement))
316                .otherwise(pl.col(col))
317            )
318            after = polars_df.select(pl.col(col)).to_series()
319            self.track_not_cleaned(col=col, method='replace_commas', mask=mask, before=before, after=after)
320
321        if self.inplace:
322            self.df[self.columns] = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
323            logger.info(f"Replaced commas with '{replacement}', inplace.")
324            return None
325        else:
326            df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
327            logger.info(f"Replaced commas with '{replacement}'.")
328            return df

Replaces commas (,) that are used as decimal replacements, with decimals (.) or any other value.

Parameters

replacement: str, optional Value you wish to replace commas with, by default None

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to replace commas with decimal values during numerical cleaning.

Considerations

1. Use this method only on numerical data.
2. This method keeps a track of values that cannot be cleaned.

Example

>>>    NumericalCleaner(df).replace_commas(replacement = "")

>>>    NumericalCleaner(df).replace_commas(replacement = '.', inplace=True)
def convert_scientific_notation_to_numbers(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
330    def convert_scientific_notation_to_numbers(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
331        """
332        Converts scientific notation like (4.67e01 or 4,67e01 or 1.04e+05) to readable numbers like 104000.
333            
334        Returns
335        --------
336        pd.DataFrame
337            A pandas DataFrame
338
339        Usage Recommendation
340        ---------------------
341            1. Use this method to convert scientific notation into numbers, during numerical cleaning.
342
343        Considerations
344        ---------------
345            1. Use this method only on numerical data.
346            2. This method keeps a track of values that cannot be cleaned.
347
348        Example
349        --------
350        >>>    NumericalCleaner(df).convert_scientific_notation_into_numbers()
351        """
352        from decimal import Decimal
353
354        SCIENTIFIC_NOTATION_PATTERN = r'^[+-]?\d+(?:[.,]\d+)?[eE][+-]?\d*$'
355        
356        scientific_notation_dict = {}
357
358        def scientific_notation_to_number(text):
359            text = text.strip().replace(',', '.').replace('E', 'e')
360            try:
361                return format(Decimal(text), 'f')
362            except:
363                return text
364
365        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
366        
367        for col in polars_df.columns:
368            before = polars_df.select(pl.col(col)).to_series()
369            mask = polars_df.select(pl.col(col).str.contains(SCIENTIFIC_NOTATION_PATTERN)).to_series()
370            polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(
371                pl.when(pl.col(col).str.contains(SCIENTIFIC_NOTATION_PATTERN))
372                .then(pl.col(col).map_elements(scientific_notation_to_number))
373                .otherwise(pl.col(col))
374            )
375            after = polars_df.select(pl.col(col)).to_series()
376            self.track_not_cleaned(col=col, method='convert_scientific_notation_to_numbers',mask=mask, before=before, after=after )
377
378        if self.inplace:
379            self.df[self.columns] = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
380            logger.info('Converted scientific notation to readable numbers in place.')
381            return None
382        else:
383            df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
384            logger.info('Converted scientific notation to readable numbers.')
385            return df

Converts scientific notation like (4.67e01 or 4,67e01 or 1.04e+05) to readable numbers like 104000.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this method to convert scientific notation into numbers, during numerical cleaning.

Considerations

1. Use this method only on numerical data.
2. This method keeps a track of values that cannot be cleaned.

Example

>>>    NumericalCleaner(df).convert_scientific_notation_into_numbers()
def convert_text_to_numbers( self, text_to_number: dict[str, str] = None) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
387    def convert_text_to_numbers(self, text_to_number:dict[str, str]=None)-> pd.DataFrame:
388        """
389        Converts text to numbers in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
390
391        E.g: 'five' ->  5, 'one' -> 1, 'thirty' -> 30 etc.
392
393        Parameters
394        -----------
395        text_to_number : dict
396            A dictionary of text you wish to replace and its replacement number.
397
398        Returns
399        --------
400        pd.DataFrame
401            A pandas DataFrame
402        
403        Usage Recommendation
404        ---------------------
405            Use this method to convert textual numbers 'one', 'two' to numbers like 1, 2, during numerical cleaning.
406        
407        Considerations
408        ---------------
409            1. This method keeps the converted number as string instead of a numerical datatype like int or float.
410            2. Use this method only on numerical data.
411            3. This method keeps a track of values that cannot be cleaned.
412
413        Example
414        --------
415        >>>    NumericalCleaner(df).convert_text_to_numbers({'five': 5, 'two': 2, 'one': 1})
416        """
417        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
418
419        if not isinstance(text_to_number, (dict,type(None))):
420            raise TypeError(f'text to number must be a dictionary of text and its replacement number, got {type(text_to_number).__name__}')
421
422        if text_to_number is None:
423            logger.info('No text-to-number mapping received, hence, no changes made!')
424            return self.df
425
426        for col in polars_df.columns:
427            for text, number in text_to_number.items():
428
429                before = polars_df.select(pl.col(col)).to_series()
430                mask = polars_df.select(pl.col(col).str.contains(text)).to_series()
431                polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(
432                    pl.when(pl.col(col).str.contains(text))
433                    .then(pl.col(col).str.replace_all(text, number))
434                    .otherwise(pl.col(col))
435                )
436
437                after = polars_df.select(pl.col(col)).to_series()
438
439                self.track_not_cleaned(col=col, method = 'convert_text_to_numbers', before = before, mask = mask, after = after)
440
441        if self.inplace:
442            self.df[self.columns] = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
443            logger.info(f"Converted text to numbers in place.")
444            return None
445
446        else:
447            df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas(array_type = self.array_type, conversion_threshold=self.conversion_threshold)
448            logger.info(f"Converted text to numbers.")
449            return df

Converts text to numbers in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.

E.g: 'five' -> 5, 'one' -> 1, 'thirty' -> 30 etc.

Parameters

text_to_number : dict A dictionary of text you wish to replace and its replacement number.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use this method to convert textual numbers 'one', 'two' to numbers like 1, 2, during numerical cleaning.

Considerations

1. This method keeps the converted number as string instead of a numerical datatype like int or float.
2. Use this method only on numerical data.
3. This method keeps a track of values that cannot be cleaned.

Example

>>>    NumericalCleaner(df).convert_text_to_numbers({'five': 5, 'two': 2, 'one': 1})
class MissingHandler: 
  7class MissingHandler():
  8    """
  9    Initializing Missing Handler.
 10
 11    Parameters
 12    -----------
 13    df : pd.DataFrame
 14        A pandas DataFrame containing missing data.
 15
 16    columns : list, optional
 17        List of columns you wish to convert, by default None.
 18    """
 19    def __init__(self, df, columns: list=None, extra_placeholders: list = None):
 20
 21        self.df = df
 22        
 23        if columns is None:
 24            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
 25        else:
 26            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 27
 28        if extra_placeholders is None:
 29            self.extra_placeholders = []
 30    
 31    def replace_missing(self, to_replace: list[str| float| type(np.nan)], replace_with: str|float|int, **kwargs: dict) -> pd.DataFrame:
 32
 33        """Replace missing values like 'ERROR','MISSING', 'UNKNOWN' etc. with any value of choice.
 34
 35        Parameters
 36        ----------
 37
 38        to_replace  :list[str, float]
 39            List of values you wish to replace. Example: ['NA', 'ERROR', 'MISSING', np.nan]
 40
 41        replace_with: str, float or int
 42            Value you wish to replace with
 43
 44        kwargs: dict, optional
 45            A dictionary of extra keyword arguments you wish to pass in pandas ``df.replace()`` method, like regex=True
 46
 47        Returns
 48        -------
 49        pd.DataFrame
 50            A pandas DataFrame
 51
 52        Usage Recommendation
 53        --------------------
 54            Use this function when you want to replace missing values (NA) across multiple columns, that are not just np.nan. 
 55            Missing values could include values like ['ERROR', 'UNKNOWN', 'MISSING', 'NA', 'Null', None]
 56
 57        Considerations
 58        --------------
 59            This function is intended to replace missing values with 1 single value. 
 60            If you wish to apply methods like mean, median or mode or other imputation methods, use ``fill_with_mean()``, ``fill_with_median()`` etc.
 61
 62
 63        Example:
 64        >>>    MissingHandler(df).replace_missing(to_replace=['UNKNOWN', 'MISSING', None], replace_with = np.nan) 
 65
 66        >>>    MissingHandler(df).replace_missing(to_replace=['UNKNOWN', 'MISSING', np.nan], replace_with = 'MISSING') 
 67        """
 68        if not isinstance(to_replace, (list, (float, int, str))):
 69            raise TypeError(f'to_replace must be a list of strings or np.nan, got {type(to_replace).__name__}')
 70
 71        if not isinstance(replace_with, (pd.Series, str, type(None), float, int)):
 72            raise TypeError(f'replace_with must be a string, None, float or int, got {type(replace_with).__name__}')
 73
 74        self.df[self.columns] = self.df[self.columns].replace(to_replace, replace_with, **kwargs)
 75
 76        return self.df
 77
 78    def drop_missing_columns(self, **kwargs)-> pd.DataFrame:
 79        """
 80        Drops columns that have missing data in a DataFrame
 81
 82        Parameters
 83        ----------
 84
 85        kwargs: dict, optional
 86            A dictionary of extra keyword arguments you wish to pass in pandas ``df.drop_na()`` method
 87
 88        Returns
 89        --------
 90        pd.DataFrame
 91            A pandas DataFrame
 92
 93        Usage Recommendation
 94        ---------------------
 95            1. Use this function when a high number of missing values exist in a particular column
 96            2. Use this function when the column is irrelevant for your analysis or modeling 
 97            3. DO NOT USE this function to drop columns that are important but may have a high number of missing values, E.g: [Salary, Income Tax].
 98        
 99        Considerations
100        ---------------
101            Be careful while dropping columns since we do not want to lose data that is important in one row even if irrelevant in another.
102
103        Example
104        --------
105        >>> MissingHandler(df, columns=['credit_score']).drop_missing_columns()
106
107        """
108        return self.df[self.columns].dropna(axis=1, **kwargs)
109
110    def drop_missing_rows(self, **kwargs)-> pd.DataFrame:
111        """
112        Drops rows that have missing data in a DataFrame
113
114        Parameters
115        -----------
116        kwargs: dict, optional
117            A dictionary of extra keyword arguments you wish to pass in pandas ``df.drop_na()`` method
118
119        Returns
120        --------
121        pd.DataFrame
122            A pandas DataFrame
123
124        Usage Recommendation
125        ---------------------
126            1. Use this function when a low number of missing values exist in rows of a particular column.
127            3. DO NOT USE this function to drop rows that are important but may have a high number of missing values, E.g: [Salary, Income Tax].
128        
129        Considerations
130        ---------------
131            Be careful while dropping rows since we do not want to lose data that is important in a particular column even if irrelevant in another.
132
133        Example
134        --------
135        >>> MissingHandler(df, columns=['credit_score']).drop_missing_rows()
136        """
137        return self.df[self.columns].dropna(**kwargs)
138
139    def fill_with_mean(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
140        """
141        Replaces missing values with mean (average) value of that particular column, in one or multiple columns of a DataFrame.
142
143        Returns
144        --------
145        pd.DataFrame
146            A pandas DataFrame
147
148        Usage Recommendation
149        ----------------------
150            1. Use this function if distribution of the numerical column is roughly normal (bell-curve) and missingness is low (5 - 10 %).
151            2. DO NOT USE this function if your data is highly skewed or has strong outliers.
152
153        Considerations
154        ---------------
155            Since mean is sensitive to outliers, use ``fill_with_median()`` method if your data is skewed.
156
157        Example
158        --------
159        >>> df['credit_score'] = [734.97, 734.78, np.nan, 712.21, 686.13]
160
161        >>> MissingHandler(df, columns=['credit_score']).fill_with_mean()
162
163        >>> df['credit_score'] = [734.97, 734.78, 717.02, 712.21, 686.13]
164        """
165        return self.df[self.columns].fillna(self.df[self.columns].mean())
166
167    def fill_with_median(self):
168        """
169        Replaces missing values with median (middle) value of that particular column, in one or multiple columns of a DataFrame.
170
171        Returns
172        --------
173        pd.DataFrame
174            A pandas DataFrame
175
176        Usage Recommendation
177        ---------------------
178            1. Use this function if distribution of the numerical column is skewed.
179            2. Use this function if your data has strong outliers.
180            3. Use this function for continous numbers.
181
182        Considerations
183        ---------------
184            If your data has normal distribution or does not have outliers, use ``fill_with_mean()`` instead.
185
186        Example
187        -------
188
189        >>> df['savings'] = [14173.3,37970.2,24008.95,np.nan,17063.67,57161.76,np.nan,5927.63,28954.98,5553.7]
190
191        >>> MissingHandler(df, columns=['savings']).fill_with_median()
192
193        >>> df['savings'] = [14173.3, 37970.2, 24008.95, 20536.30, 17063.67, 57161.76, 20536.30, 5927.63, 28954.98, 5553.7]
194        """
195        return self.df[self.columns].fillna(self.df[self.columns].median())

Initializing Missing Handler.

Parameters

df : pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame containing missing data.

columns : list, optional List of columns you wish to convert, by default None.

MissingHandler(df, columns: list = None, extra_placeholders: list = None) 
19    def __init__(self, df, columns: list=None, extra_placeholders: list = None):
20
21        self.df = df
22        
23        if columns is None:
24            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
25        else:
26            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
27
28        if extra_placeholders is None:
29            self.extra_placeholders = []
df
def replace_missing( self, to_replace: list[str | float], replace_with: str | float | int, **kwargs: dict) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
31    def replace_missing(self, to_replace: list[str| float| type(np.nan)], replace_with: str|float|int, **kwargs: dict) -> pd.DataFrame:
32
33        """Replace missing values like 'ERROR','MISSING', 'UNKNOWN' etc. with any value of choice.
34
35        Parameters
36        ----------
37
38        to_replace  :list[str, float]
39            List of values you wish to replace. Example: ['NA', 'ERROR', 'MISSING', np.nan]
40
41        replace_with: str, float or int
42            Value you wish to replace with
43
44        kwargs: dict, optional
45            A dictionary of extra keyword arguments you wish to pass in pandas ``df.replace()`` method, like regex=True
46
47        Returns
48        -------
49        pd.DataFrame
50            A pandas DataFrame
51
52        Usage Recommendation
53        --------------------
54            Use this function when you want to replace missing values (NA) across multiple columns, that are not just np.nan. 
55            Missing values could include values like ['ERROR', 'UNKNOWN', 'MISSING', 'NA', 'Null', None]
56
57        Considerations
58        --------------
59            This function is intended to replace missing values with 1 single value. 
60            If you wish to apply methods like mean, median or mode or other imputation methods, use ``fill_with_mean()``, ``fill_with_median()`` etc.
61
62
63        Example:
64        >>>    MissingHandler(df).replace_missing(to_replace=['UNKNOWN', 'MISSING', None], replace_with = np.nan) 
65
66        >>>    MissingHandler(df).replace_missing(to_replace=['UNKNOWN', 'MISSING', np.nan], replace_with = 'MISSING') 
67        """
68        if not isinstance(to_replace, (list, (float, int, str))):
69            raise TypeError(f'to_replace must be a list of strings or np.nan, got {type(to_replace).__name__}')
70
71        if not isinstance(replace_with, (pd.Series, str, type(None), float, int)):
72            raise TypeError(f'replace_with must be a string, None, float or int, got {type(replace_with).__name__}')
73
74        self.df[self.columns] = self.df[self.columns].replace(to_replace, replace_with, **kwargs)
75
76        return self.df

Replace missing values like 'ERROR','MISSING', 'UNKNOWN' etc. with any value of choice.

Parameters

to_replace :list[str, float] List of values you wish to replace. Example: ['NA', 'ERROR', 'MISSING', np.nan]

replace_with: str, float or int Value you wish to replace with

kwargs: dict, optional A dictionary of extra keyword arguments you wish to pass in pandas df.replace() method, like regex=True

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when you want to replace missing values (NA) across multiple columns, that are not just np.nan. 
Missing values could include values like ['ERROR', 'UNKNOWN', 'MISSING', 'NA', 'Null', None]

Considerations

This function is intended to replace missing values with 1 single value. 
If you wish to apply methods like mean, median or mode or other imputation methods, use ``fill_with_mean()``, ``fill_with_median()`` etc.

Example:

>>>    MissingHandler(df).replace_missing(to_replace=['UNKNOWN', 'MISSING', None], replace_with = np.nan) 

>>>    MissingHandler(df).replace_missing(to_replace=['UNKNOWN', 'MISSING', np.nan], replace_with = 'MISSING')
def drop_missing_columns(self, **kwargs) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
 78    def drop_missing_columns(self, **kwargs)-> pd.DataFrame:
 79        """
 80        Drops columns that have missing data in a DataFrame
 81
 82        Parameters
 83        ----------
 84
 85        kwargs: dict, optional
 86            A dictionary of extra keyword arguments you wish to pass in pandas ``df.drop_na()`` method
 87
 88        Returns
 89        --------
 90        pd.DataFrame
 91            A pandas DataFrame
 92
 93        Usage Recommendation
 94        ---------------------
 95            1. Use this function when a high number of missing values exist in a particular column
 96            2. Use this function when the column is irrelevant for your analysis or modeling 
 97            3. DO NOT USE this function to drop columns that are important but may have a high number of missing values, E.g: [Salary, Income Tax].
 98        
 99        Considerations
100        ---------------
101            Be careful while dropping columns since we do not want to lose data that is important in one row even if irrelevant in another.
102
103        Example
104        --------
105        >>> MissingHandler(df, columns=['credit_score']).drop_missing_columns()
106
107        """
108        return self.df[self.columns].dropna(axis=1, **kwargs)

Drops columns that have missing data in a DataFrame

Parameters

kwargs: dict, optional A dictionary of extra keyword arguments you wish to pass in pandas df.drop_na() method

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when a high number of missing values exist in a particular column
2. Use this function when the column is irrelevant for your analysis or modeling 
3. DO NOT USE this function to drop columns that are important but may have a high number of missing values, E.g: [Salary, Income Tax].

Considerations

Be careful while dropping columns since we do not want to lose data that is important in one row even if irrelevant in another.

Example

>>> MissingHandler(df, columns=['credit_score']).drop_missing_columns()

112        Drops rows that have missing data in a DataFrame
113

118
119        Returns

122            A pandas DataFrame
123
124        Usage Recommendation
125        ---------------------
126            1. Use this function when a low number of missing values exist in rows of a particular column.
127            3. DO NOT USE this function to drop rows that are important but may have a high number of missing values, E.g: [Salary, Income Tax].
128        
129        Considerations
130        ---------------
131            Be careful while dropping rows since we do not want to lose data that is important in a particular column even if irrelevant in another.
132
133        Example
134        --------
135        >>> MissingHandler(df, columns=['credit_score']).drop_missing_rows()
136        """
