def fill_with_mean(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
139    def fill_with_mean(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
140        """
141        Replaces missing values with mean (average) value of that particular column, in one or multiple columns of a DataFrame.
142
143        Returns
144        --------
145        pd.DataFrame
146            A pandas DataFrame
147
148        Usage Recommendation
149        ----------------------
150            1. Use this function if distribution of the numerical column is roughly normal (bell-curve) and missingness is low (5 - 10 %).
151            2. DO NOT USE this function if your data is highly skewed or has strong outliers.
152
153        Considerations
154        ---------------
155            Since mean is sensitive to outliers, use ``fill_with_median()`` method if your data is skewed.
156
157        Example
158        --------
159        >>> df['credit_score'] = [734.97, 734.78, np.nan, 712.21, 686.13]
160
161        >>> MissingHandler(df, columns=['credit_score']).fill_with_mean()
162
163        >>> df['credit_score'] = [734.97, 734.78, 717.02, 712.21, 686.13]
164        """
165        return self.df[self.columns].fillna(self.df[self.columns].mean())

Replaces missing values with mean (average) value of that particular column, in one or multiple columns of a DataFrame.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function if distribution of the numerical column is roughly normal (bell-curve) and missingness is low (5 - 10 %).
2. DO NOT USE this function if your data is highly skewed or has strong outliers.

Considerations

Since mean is sensitive to outliers, use ``fill_with_median()`` method if your data is skewed.

Example

>>> df['credit_score'] = [734.97, 734.78, np.nan, 712.21, 686.13]

>>> MissingHandler(df, columns=['credit_score']).fill_with_mean()

>>> df['credit_score'] = [734.97, 734.78, 717.02, 712.21, 686.13]
def fill_with_median(self): 
167    def fill_with_median(self):
168        """
169        Replaces missing values with median (middle) value of that particular column, in one or multiple columns of a DataFrame.
170
171        Returns
172        --------
173        pd.DataFrame
174            A pandas DataFrame
175
176        Usage Recommendation
177        ---------------------
178            1. Use this function if distribution of the numerical column is skewed.
179            2. Use this function if your data has strong outliers.
180            3. Use this function for continous numbers.
181
182        Considerations
183        ---------------
184            If your data has normal distribution or does not have outliers, use ``fill_with_mean()`` instead.
185
186        Example
187        -------
188
189        >>> df['savings'] = [14173.3,37970.2,24008.95,np.nan,17063.67,57161.76,np.nan,5927.63,28954.98,5553.7]
190
191        >>> MissingHandler(df, columns=['savings']).fill_with_median()
192
193        >>> df['savings'] = [14173.3, 37970.2, 24008.95, 20536.30, 17063.67, 57161.76, 20536.30, 5927.63, 28954.98, 5553.7]
194        """
195        return self.df[self.columns].fillna(self.df[self.columns].median())

Replaces missing values with median (middle) value of that particular column, in one or multiple columns of a DataFrame.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function if distribution of the numerical column is skewed.
2. Use this function if your data has strong outliers.
3. Use this function for continous numbers.

Considerations

If your data has normal distribution or does not have outliers, use ``fill_with_mean()`` instead.

Example

>>> df['savings'] = [14173.3,37970.2,24008.95,np.nan,17063.67,57161.76,np.nan,5927.63,28954.98,5553.7]

>>> MissingHandler(df, columns=['savings']).fill_with_median()

>>> df['savings'] = [14173.3, 37970.2, 24008.95, 20536.30, 17063.67, 57161.76, 20536.30, 5927.63, 28954.98, 5553.7]
class TextCleaner(datalab.tabular.data_cleaner.BaseCleaner.DataCleaner): 
 15class TextCleaner(DataCleaner):
 16    """
 17    Initializing Text Cleaner.
 18
 19    Parameters
 20    -----------
 21    df: pd.DataFrame
 22        A pandas DataFrame
 23    
 24    columns: list, optional
 25        List of columns you wish to apply cleaning on, by default None.
 26    """
 27    
 28    def __init__(self, df:pd.DataFrame, columns:list=None):
 29        
 30        if not isinstance(df, (pd.DataFrame, pd.Series)):
 31            raise TypeError(f'df must be a pandas DataFrame or pandas Series, got {type(df).__name__}')
 32
 33        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
 34            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list of strings or type None, got {type(columns).__name__}')
 35            
 36        # ensuring only text based datatypes are selected
 37        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include = ['object', 'string', 'category']) 
 38        
 39        if columns is None: 
 40            self.columns = self.df.columns.to_list()
 41        else:
 42            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 43
 44        logger.info('Text Cleaner initialized.')
 45
 46    def to_lowercase(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
 47        """
 48        Converts text to uppercase in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
 49
 50        Returns
 51        --------
 52        pd.DataFrame
 53            A pandas DataFrame
 54
 55        Usage Recommendation
 56        ---------------------
 57            Use this function when you have mixed values and want to convert strings to lowercase
 58
 59        Consideration
 60        --------------
 61            1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
 62            2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame
 63
 64        Example
 65        --------
 66        >>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status']).to_lowercase()
 67        """
 68        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
 69
 70        polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(
 71            cs.string()
 72            .str.to_lowercase())
 73        
 74        self.df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas()
 75
 76        logger.info('Converted to lowercase!')
 77
 78        return self.df
 79
 80    def to_uppercase(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
 81        """
 82        Converts text to lowercase in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
 83
 84        Returns
 85        --------
 86        pd.DataFrame
 87            A pandas DataFrame
 88
 89        Usage Recommendation
 90        ---------------------
 91            Use this function when you have mixed values and want to convert strings to uppercase
 92
 93        Consideration
 94        --------------
 95            1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
 96            2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame
 97
 98        Example:
 99        --------
100        >>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status']).to_uppercase()
101        """
102        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
103
104        polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(
105            cs.string().str.to_uppercase()
106        )
107
108        self.df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas()
109
110        logger.info('Converted to uppercase!')
111
112        return self.df
113
114    def remove_multiple_spaces(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
115        """
116        Removes multiple spaces within characters or words for one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
117
118        Returns
119        --------
120        pd.DataFrame
121            A pandas DataFrame
122
123        Usage Recommendation
124        ---------------------
125            Use this function when you want to remove multiple spaces within text values.
126
127        Considerations
128        --------------
129            1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
130            2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame
131
132        Example
133        --------
134        >>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['gender']).remove_multiple_spaces()
135        """
136        multiple_spaces_pattern = r'\s+'
137
138        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
139
140        polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(cs.string().str.replace_all(multiple_spaces_pattern, ""))
141
142        self.df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas()
143
144        logger.info('Removed multiple spaces!')
145
146        return self.df
147
148    def replace_splitters(self, splitters_and_replacements: dict[str, str]=None):
149        """
150        Replaces different kinds of splitters present in data with the desired value, in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
151
152        E.g: 'active/member' -> 'active-member', 'masters/ male' -> 'masters, male'.
153
154        Parameters
155        -----------
156        splitters_and_replacements: dict 
157            A dictionary of splitters and their replacements
158
159        Returns
160        --------
161        pd.DataFrame
162            A pandas DataFrame
163
164        Usage Recommendation
165        ---------------------
166            Use this function when you want to normalize multiple splitters with one kind of splitter
167
168        Considerations
169        ---------------
170            1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
171            2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame
172
173        Example
174        --------
175        >>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status]).replace_splitters({',': ''})
176        """
177        from ..utils.BackendConverter import BackendConverter
178        import re
179        
180        if splitters_and_replacements is None:
181            splitters_and_replacements={'':''}
182
183        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
184
185        for column in polars_df.columns:
186            
187            for splitter, replacement in splitters_and_replacements.items():
188                
189                # using re.escape to make values as literal
190                polars_df=polars_df.with_columns(
191                    pl.when(pl.col(column).str.contains(re.escape(splitter)))
192                    .then(pl.col(column).str.replace_all(re.escape(splitter), replacement))
193                    .otherwise(pl.col(column))
194                )
195                
196        self.df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas()
197
198        return self.df
199
200    def replace_symbols(self, symbols_and_replacements: dict[str, str]=None):
201        """
202        Replaces different kinds of symbols present in data, with the desired value in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
203
204        Example: 'Germ@any' -> 'Germany', 'Empl0y3d' -> 'Employed' or '<<active>>' -> 'active'
205
206        Parameters
207        -----------
208        symbols_and_replacements: dict 
209            A dictionary of symbols and their replacements, by default None
210
211        Returns
212        --------
213            pd.DataFrame
214                A pandas DataFrame
215
216        Usage Recommendation
217        ----------------------
218            1. Use this function when you want to replace symbols with text or other symbols
219
220        Consideration
221        ---------------
222            1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
223            2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame
224
225        Example
226        --------
227        >>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status]).replace_symbols({'@':'a', '0':'o'})
228        """
229        import re
230
231        # if symbols and replacements are not passed, they default to empty strings 
232        if symbols_and_replacements is None:
233            symbols_and_replacements = {"":""} 
234
235        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
236
237        for col in polars_df.columns:
238
239            for symbol, replacement in symbols_and_replacements.items():
240                
241                polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(
242                    # using re.escape to ensure symbols passed are used as literal characters
243                    pl.when(pl.col(col).str.contains(re.escape(symbol)))
244                    .then(pl.col(col).str.replace_all(re.escape(symbol), replacement))
245                    .otherwise(pl.col(col))
246                )
247    
248        self.df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas()
249
250        return self.df

Initializing Text Cleaner.

Parameters

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

columns: list, optional List of columns you wish to apply cleaning on, by default None.

TextCleaner(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None) 
28    def __init__(self, df:pd.DataFrame, columns:list=None):
29        
30        if not isinstance(df, (pd.DataFrame, pd.Series)):
31            raise TypeError(f'df must be a pandas DataFrame or pandas Series, got {type(df).__name__}')
32
33        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
34            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list of strings or type None, got {type(columns).__name__}')
35            
36        # ensuring only text based datatypes are selected
37        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include = ['object', 'string', 'category']) 
38        
39        if columns is None: 
40            self.columns = self.df.columns.to_list()
41        else:
42            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
43
44        logger.info('Text Cleaner initialized.')
df
def to_lowercase(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
46    def to_lowercase(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
47        """
48        Converts text to uppercase in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
49
50        Returns
51        --------
52        pd.DataFrame
53            A pandas DataFrame
54
55        Usage Recommendation
56        ---------------------
57            Use this function when you have mixed values and want to convert strings to lowercase
58
59        Consideration
60        --------------
61            1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
62            2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame
63
64        Example
65        --------
66        >>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status']).to_lowercase()
67        """
68        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
69
70        polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(
71            cs.string()
72            .str.to_lowercase())
73        
74        self.df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas()
75
76        logger.info('Converted to lowercase!')
77
78        return self.df

Converts text to uppercase in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when you have mixed values and want to convert strings to lowercase

Consideration

1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame

Example

>>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status']).to_lowercase()
def to_uppercase(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
 80    def to_uppercase(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
 81        """
 82        Converts text to lowercase in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
 83
 84        Returns
 85        --------
 86        pd.DataFrame
 87            A pandas DataFrame
 88
 89        Usage Recommendation
 90        ---------------------
 91            Use this function when you have mixed values and want to convert strings to uppercase
 92
 93        Consideration
 94        --------------
 95            1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
 96            2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame
 97
 98        Example:
 99        --------
100        >>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status']).to_uppercase()
101        """
102        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
103
104        polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(
105            cs.string().str.to_uppercase()
106        )
107
108        self.df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas()
109
110        logger.info('Converted to uppercase!')
111
112        return self.df

Converts text to lowercase in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when you have mixed values and want to convert strings to uppercase

Consideration

1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame

Example:

>>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status']).to_uppercase()
def remove_multiple_spaces(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
114    def remove_multiple_spaces(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
115        """
116        Removes multiple spaces within characters or words for one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
117
118        Returns
119        --------
120        pd.DataFrame
121            A pandas DataFrame
122
123        Usage Recommendation
124        ---------------------
125            Use this function when you want to remove multiple spaces within text values.
126
127        Considerations
128        --------------
129            1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
130            2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame
131
132        Example
133        --------
134        >>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['gender']).remove_multiple_spaces()
135        """
136        multiple_spaces_pattern = r'\s+'
137
138        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
139
140        polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(cs.string().str.replace_all(multiple_spaces_pattern, ""))
141
142        self.df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas()
143
144        logger.info('Removed multiple spaces!')
145
146        return self.df

Removes multiple spaces within characters or words for one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when you want to remove multiple spaces within text values.

Considerations

1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame

Example

>>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['gender']).remove_multiple_spaces()
def replace_splitters(self, splitters_and_replacements: dict[str, str] = None): 
148    def replace_splitters(self, splitters_and_replacements: dict[str, str]=None):
149        """
150        Replaces different kinds of splitters present in data with the desired value, in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
151
152        E.g: 'active/member' -> 'active-member', 'masters/ male' -> 'masters, male'.
153
154        Parameters
155        -----------
156        splitters_and_replacements: dict 
157            A dictionary of splitters and their replacements
158
159        Returns
160        --------
161        pd.DataFrame
162            A pandas DataFrame
163
164        Usage Recommendation
165        ---------------------
166            Use this function when you want to normalize multiple splitters with one kind of splitter
167
168        Considerations
169        ---------------
170            1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
171            2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame
172
173        Example
174        --------
175        >>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status]).replace_splitters({',': ''})
176        """
177        from ..utils.BackendConverter import BackendConverter
178        import re
179        
180        if splitters_and_replacements is None:
181            splitters_and_replacements={'':''}
182
183        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
184
185        for column in polars_df.columns:
186            
187            for splitter, replacement in splitters_and_replacements.items():
188                
189                # using re.escape to make values as literal
190                polars_df=polars_df.with_columns(
191                    pl.when(pl.col(column).str.contains(re.escape(splitter)))
192                    .then(pl.col(column).str.replace_all(re.escape(splitter), replacement))
193                    .otherwise(pl.col(column))
194                )
195                
196        self.df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas()
197
198        return self.df

Replaces different kinds of splitters present in data with the desired value, in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.

E.g: 'active/member' -> 'active-member', 'masters/ male' -> 'masters, male'.

Parameters

splitters_and_replacements: dict A dictionary of splitters and their replacements

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when you want to normalize multiple splitters with one kind of splitter

Considerations

1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame

Example

>>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status]).replace_splitters({',': ''})
def replace_symbols(self, symbols_and_replacements: dict[str, str] = None): 
200    def replace_symbols(self, symbols_and_replacements: dict[str, str]=None):
201        """
202        Replaces different kinds of symbols present in data, with the desired value in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
203
204        Example: 'Germ@any' -> 'Germany', 'Empl0y3d' -> 'Employed' or '<<active>>' -> 'active'
205
206        Parameters
207        -----------
208        symbols_and_replacements: dict 
209            A dictionary of symbols and their replacements, by default None
210
211        Returns
212        --------
213            pd.DataFrame
214                A pandas DataFrame
215
216        Usage Recommendation
217        ----------------------
218            1. Use this function when you want to replace symbols with text or other symbols
219
220        Consideration
221        ---------------
222            1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
223            2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame
224
225        Example
226        --------
227        >>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status]).replace_symbols({'@':'a', '0':'o'})
228        """
229        import re
230
231        # if symbols and replacements are not passed, they default to empty strings 
232        if symbols_and_replacements is None:
233            symbols_and_replacements = {"":""} 
234
235        polars_df = BackendConverter(self.df[self.columns]).pandas_to_polars()
236
237        for col in polars_df.columns:
238
239            for symbol, replacement in symbols_and_replacements.items():
240                
241                polars_df = polars_df.with_columns(
242                    # using re.escape to ensure symbols passed are used as literal characters
243                    pl.when(pl.col(col).str.contains(re.escape(symbol)))
244                    .then(pl.col(col).str.replace_all(re.escape(symbol), replacement))
245                    .otherwise(pl.col(col))
246                )
247    
248        self.df = BackendConverter(polars_df).polars_to_pandas()
249
250        return self.df

Replaces different kinds of symbols present in data, with the desired value in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.

Example: 'Germ@any' -> 'Germany', 'Empl0y3d' -> 'Employed' or '<>' -> 'active'

Parameters

symbols_and_replacements: dict A dictionary of symbols and their replacements, by default None

Returns

pd.DataFrame
    A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you want to replace symbols with text or other symbols

Consideration

1. Uses polars with_columns to apply regex to all string columns
2. However, it still takes and returns a pandas DataFrame

Example

>>>    TextCleaner(df, columns=['user_status]).replace_symbols({'@':'a', '0':'o'})
class CategoricalPreprocessor(datalab.tabular.data_preprocessor.DataPreprocessor.DataPreprocessor): 
 10class CategoricalPreprocessor(DataPreprocessor):
 11    """
 12    Initializing the Categorical Preprocessor.
 13
 14    Parameters
 15    -----------
 16    df: pd.DataFrame
 17        A pandas Dataframe you wish to diagnose.
 18
 19    columns: list, optional
 20        A list of columns you wish to preprocess, by default None.
 21    """
 22
 23    def __init__(self, df:pd.DataFrame, columns: list|type(None) = None):
 24
 25        super().__init__(df, columns)
 26
 27        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include= ['object', 'string', 'category'])
 28
 29        if columns is None:
 30            self.columns = df.columns.tolist()
 31        else:
 32            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 33
 34        logger.info('Categorical Preprocessor initialized.')
 35
 36    def one_hot_encoding(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
 37        """
 38        Applies One-Hot Encoding (1 for category that exist, 0 for category that does not exist).
 39
 40        Returns:
 41        -------
 42        pd.DataFrame
 43            A pandas DataFrame
 44
 45        Usage Recommendation
 46        ---------------------
 47            1. Use this function when your categorical data does not have an order.
 48
 49                E.g. Gender: [''Male', 'Female', 'Other'] does not have an order
 50                E.g. Categories: ['Clothing', 'Sports', 'Cosmetics', 'Electronics'] do not have an order
 51
 52            2. Use this function when your column does not have more than 100 unique categories.
 53                That is because this function creates a separate column for each category.
 54
 55        Considerations
 56        ---------------
 57            This function converts values to binary integer datatype (0 or 1)
 58
 59        Example
 60        --------
 61        >>>  CategoricalPreprocessor(df, ['gender', 'city']).one_hot_encoding()
 62        """
 63
 64        return pd.get_dummies(self.df[self.columns], dtype=int)
 65
 66    def label_encoding(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
 67        """
 68        Applies Label Encoding (converts each category to a unique integer).
 69
 70        Returns
 71        -------
 72        pd.DataFrame
 73            A pandas DataFrame
 74
 75        Usage Recommendation
 76        ---------------------
 77            Use this function when your categorical data **DOES NOT HAVE AN ORDER**.
 78
 79            E.g. Gender: ['Male', 'Female', 'Other'] does not have an order
 80            E.g. Categories: ['Clothing', 'Sports', 'Cosmetics', 'Electronics'] do not have an order
 81
 82        Considerations
 83        ---------------
 84            1. This method is NOT recommended for linear models if the numbers might be treated as ordinal.
 85            2. Always keep track of the mapping to decode back if needed.
 86
 87        Example
 88        --------
 89        >>> CategoricalPreprocessor(df, ['gender', 'city']).label_encoding()
 90        """
 91        from sklearn.preprocessing import LabelEncoder
 92
 93        label_encoder = LabelEncoder()
 94
 95        encodings= {}
 96
 97        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
 98
 99            encodings[col] = label_encoder.fit_transform(self.df[col])
100
101        return pd.DataFrame(encodings)
102
103    def ordinal_encoding(self, order_map: dict)-> pd.DataFrame:
104        """
105        Applies Ordinal Encoding (converts each category to a unique integer with an order).
106
107        Parameters
108        -----------
109        order_map : dict
110
111            A dictionary specifying the desired order for each categorical column.
112
113            Example: 
114
115            order_map = {
116            'size': ['Small', 'Medium', 'Large'],
117            'rating': ['Poor', 'Average', 'Good', 'Excellent']
118            }
119
120        Returns:
121        -------
122        pd.DataFrame
123            A pandas DataFrame
124
125        Usage Recommendation
126        ---------------------
127            1. Use this function when your categorical data **has a natural order**.
128
129                E.g. Sizes: ['Small', 'Medium', 'Large']
130                E.g. Ratings: ['Poor', 'Average', 'Good', 'Excellent']
131
132            2. DO NOT USE this function for Columns that do not have an order.
133            3. You must define the **order of categories** when using this function to preserve meaning by using order map.
134
135        Considerations
136        ---------------
137            1. The numeric values **imply order**, so models or analysis treats them as ranked.
138            2. Columns without meaningful order should not use this encoding.
139            3. Keep track of the mapping if you need to revert back to original labels.
140
141        Example
142        --------
143        >>> CategoricalPreprocessor(df, ['size']).ordinal_encoding(order_map={'size':['Small','Medium','Large']})
144        """
145
146        from sklearn.preprocessing import OrdinalEncoder
147
148        encoder = OrdinalEncoder()
149
150        df = pd.DataFrame(encoder.fit_transform(self.df[self.columns], order_map=order_map))
151
152        df.columns = self.columns
153
154        return df

Initializing the Categorical Preprocessor.

Parameters

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas Dataframe you wish to diagnose.

columns: list, optional A list of columns you wish to preprocess, by default None.

CategoricalPreprocessor(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list | None = None) 
23    def __init__(self, df:pd.DataFrame, columns: list|type(None) = None):
24
25        super().__init__(df, columns)
26
27        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include= ['object', 'string', 'category'])
28
29        if columns is None:
30            self.columns = df.columns.tolist()
31        else:
32            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
33
34        logger.info('Categorical Preprocessor initialized.')
df
def one_hot_encoding(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
36    def one_hot_encoding(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
37        """
38        Applies One-Hot Encoding (1 for category that exist, 0 for category that does not exist).
39
40        Returns:
41        -------
42        pd.DataFrame
43            A pandas DataFrame
44
45        Usage Recommendation
46        ---------------------
47            1. Use this function when your categorical data does not have an order.
48
49                E.g. Gender: [''Male', 'Female', 'Other'] does not have an order
50                E.g. Categories: ['Clothing', 'Sports', 'Cosmetics', 'Electronics'] do not have an order
51
52            2. Use this function when your column does not have more than 100 unique categories.
53                That is because this function creates a separate column for each category.
54
55        Considerations
56        ---------------
57            This function converts values to binary integer datatype (0 or 1)
58
59        Example
60        --------
61        >>>  CategoricalPreprocessor(df, ['gender', 'city']).one_hot_encoding()
62        """
63
64        return pd.get_dummies(self.df[self.columns], dtype=int)

Applies One-Hot Encoding (1 for category that exist, 0 for category that does not exist).

Returns:

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when your categorical data does not have an order.

    E.g. Gender: [''Male', 'Female', 'Other'] does not have an order
    E.g. Categories: ['Clothing', 'Sports', 'Cosmetics', 'Electronics'] do not have an order

2. Use this function when your column does not have more than 100 unique categories.
    That is because this function creates a separate column for each category.

Considerations

This function converts values to binary integer datatype (0 or 1)

Example

>>>  CategoricalPreprocessor(df, ['gender', 'city']).one_hot_encoding()
def label_encoding(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
 66    def label_encoding(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
 67        """
 68        Applies Label Encoding (converts each category to a unique integer).
 69
 70        Returns
 71        -------
 72        pd.DataFrame
 73            A pandas DataFrame
 74
 75        Usage Recommendation
 76        ---------------------
 77            Use this function when your categorical data **DOES NOT HAVE AN ORDER**.
 78
 79            E.g. Gender: ['Male', 'Female', 'Other'] does not have an order
 80            E.g. Categories: ['Clothing', 'Sports', 'Cosmetics', 'Electronics'] do not have an order
 81
 82        Considerations
 83        ---------------
 84            1. This method is NOT recommended for linear models if the numbers might be treated as ordinal.
 85            2. Always keep track of the mapping to decode back if needed.
 86
 87        Example
 88        --------
 89        >>> CategoricalPreprocessor(df, ['gender', 'city']).label_encoding()
 90        """
 91        from sklearn.preprocessing import LabelEncoder
 92
 93        label_encoder = LabelEncoder()
 94
 95        encodings= {}
 96
 97        for col in self.df[self.columns]:
 98
 99            encodings[col] = label_encoder.fit_transform(self.df[col])
100
101        return pd.DataFrame(encodings)

Applies Label Encoding (converts each category to a unique integer).

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use this function when your categorical data **DOES NOT HAVE AN ORDER**.

E.g. Gender: ['Male', 'Female', 'Other'] does not have an order
E.g. Categories: ['Clothing', 'Sports', 'Cosmetics', 'Electronics'] do not have an order

Considerations

1. This method is NOT recommended for linear models if the numbers might be treated as ordinal.
2. Always keep track of the mapping to decode back if needed.

Example

>>> CategoricalPreprocessor(df, ['gender', 'city']).label_encoding()
def ordinal_encoding(self, order_map: dict) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
103    def ordinal_encoding(self, order_map: dict)-> pd.DataFrame:
104        """
105        Applies Ordinal Encoding (converts each category to a unique integer with an order).
106
107        Parameters
108        -----------
109        order_map : dict
110
111            A dictionary specifying the desired order for each categorical column.
112
113            Example: 
114
115            order_map = {
116            'size': ['Small', 'Medium', 'Large'],
117            'rating': ['Poor', 'Average', 'Good', 'Excellent']
118            }
119
120        Returns:
121        -------
122        pd.DataFrame
123            A pandas DataFrame
124
125        Usage Recommendation
126        ---------------------
127            1. Use this function when your categorical data **has a natural order**.
128
129                E.g. Sizes: ['Small', 'Medium', 'Large']
130                E.g. Ratings: ['Poor', 'Average', 'Good', 'Excellent']
131
132            2. DO NOT USE this function for Columns that do not have an order.
133            3. You must define the **order of categories** when using this function to preserve meaning by using order map.
134
135        Considerations
136        ---------------
137            1. The numeric values **imply order**, so models or analysis treats them as ranked.
138            2. Columns without meaningful order should not use this encoding.
139            3. Keep track of the mapping if you need to revert back to original labels.
140
141        Example
142        --------
143        >>> CategoricalPreprocessor(df, ['size']).ordinal_encoding(order_map={'size':['Small','Medium','Large']})
144        """
145
146        from sklearn.preprocessing import OrdinalEncoder
147
148        encoder = OrdinalEncoder()
149
150        df = pd.DataFrame(encoder.fit_transform(self.df[self.columns], order_map=order_map))
151
152        df.columns = self.columns
153
154        return df

Applies Ordinal Encoding (converts each category to a unique integer with an order).

Parameters

order_map : dict

A dictionary specifying the desired order for each categorical column.

Example: 

order_map = {
'size': ['Small', 'Medium', 'Large'],
'rating': ['Poor', 'Average', 'Good', 'Excellent']
}

Returns:

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when your categorical data **has a natural order**.

    E.g. Sizes: ['Small', 'Medium', 'Large']
    E.g. Ratings: ['Poor', 'Average', 'Good', 'Excellent']

2. DO NOT USE this function for Columns that do not have an order.
3. You must define the **order of categories** when using this function to preserve meaning by using order map.

Considerations

1. The numeric values **imply order**, so models or analysis treats them as ranked.
2. Columns without meaningful order should not use this encoding.
3. Keep track of the mapping if you need to revert back to original labels.

Example

>>> CategoricalPreprocessor(df, ['size']).ordinal_encoding(order_map={'size':['Small','Medium','Large']})
class Normalization(datalab.tabular.data_preprocessor.DataPreprocessor.DataPreprocessor): 
  8class Normalization(DataPreprocessor):
  9    """
 10    Initializing Normalization.
 11
 12    Parameters
 13    -----------
 14    df: pd.DataFrame
 15        A pandas dataframe you wish to normalize
 16
 17    columns: list, optional
 18        A list of numerical columns you want to apply normalization on, default is None.
 19    """
 20
 21    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns: list = None):
 22        super().__init__(df, columns)
 23      
 24        self.df = self.df.select_dtypes(include='number')
 25        
 26        if columns is None:
 27            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
 28        else:
 29            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 30
 31    def max_normalization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
 32        """
 33        Normalizes your data by dividing each value with the maximum value of that column.
 34
 35        Formula
 36        --------
 37                    X
 38            X' =  -----
 39                   max
 40
 41        Returns
 42        --------
 43        pd.DataFrame
 44            A pandas DataFrame
 45
 46        Usage Recommendation
 47        ---------------------
 48            1. Use this function when you do not have negative values in your data.
 49            2. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
 50               Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)
 51
 52            3. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.
 53
 54        Considerations
 55        ---------------
 56            1. This function scales your data by squeezing it between 0 and 1 without changing the shape of your data.
 57            2. It does not mean that the mean of your data will be 0, or 1 standard deviation away from the mean.
 58            3. For making your data zero-centered (mean = 0, std=1), use ``Standardization()``
 59
 60        Example
 61        -------
 62        >>>    Normalization(df).max_normalization()
 63        """
 64        normalized_data = {}
 65
 66        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
 67            
 68            data = np.array(self.df[column]) 
 69
 70            maximum_absolute_value = np.abs(data.max())
 71
 72            normalized_data[column] = (data/maximum_absolute_value)
 73            
 74            normalized_df = pd.DataFrame(normalized_data) 
 75
 76        return normalized_df
 77        
 78    def minmax_normalization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
 79        """
 80        Normalizes your data to a range [0, 1] based on the minimum and maximum values.
 81
 82        Formula
 83        -------
 84                  (X - min)
 85            X' =  ---------
 86                 (max - min)
 87
 88        Returns
 89        --------
 90        pd.DataFrame
 91            A pandas DataFrame
 92
 93        Usage Recommendation
 94        ---------------------
 95            1. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
 96               Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)
 97
 98            2. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.
 99
100        Considerations
101        ---------------
102            1. This function scales your data by squeezing it between 0 and 1 without changing the shape of your data.
103            2. It does not mean that the mean of your data will be 0, or 1 standard deviation away from the mean.
104            3. For making your data zero-centered (mean = 0, std=1), use Standardization()
105
106        Example
107        --------
108        >>>    Normalization(df).minmax_normalization()
109        """
110        minmax_normalized_data ={}
111
112        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
113            
114            data = np.array(self.df[column])
115
116            minmax_normalized_data[column] = (data - data.min()) / (data.max() - data.min())
117
118        minmax_normalized_df = pd.DataFrame(minmax_normalized_data)
119            
120        return minmax_normalized_df
121
122    def feature_range_normalization(self, range:tuple = (0, 1)) -> pd.DataFrame:
123        """
124        Normalizes your data to a specified range based on the minimum and maximum values.
125
126        Formula
127        --------
128                   (X - min)
129            X' =  -----------
130                  (max - min)
131
132        Parameters
133        -----------
134        range: tuple, optional
135            A tuple of minimum and maximum value you wish to scale your data between, default is (0,1).
136
137        Returns
138        --------
139        pd.DataFrame
140            A pandas DataFrame
141
142        Usage Recommendation
143        ---------------------
144            1. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
145               Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)
146
147            2. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.
148
149        Considerations
150        ---------------
151            1. This function scales your data by squeezing it between 0 and 1 without changing the shape of your data.
152            2. It does not mean that the mean of your data will be 0, or 1 standard deviation away from the mean.
153            3. For making your data zero-centered (mean = 0, std=1), use Standardization()
154
155        Example
156        --------
157        >>>    Normalization(df).feature_range_normalization()
158        """
159        minmax_normalized_data = Normalization(self.df).minmax_normalization()
160
161        r_min, r_max = range
162
163        featurerange_normalized_df = minmax_normalized_data * (r_max - r_min) + r_min
164
165        return featurerange_normalized_df
166
167    def mean_normalization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
168        """
169        Normalizes your data by subtracting the mean and dividing by the range (max-min)..
170
171        Formula:
172
173                  (X - mean)
174            X' =  ----------
175                  (max - min)
176
177        Returns
178        --------
179        pd.DataFrame
180            A pandas DataFrame
181
182        Usage Recommendation
183        ---------------------
184            1. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
185               Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)
186
187            2. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.
188
189        Considerations
190        ---------------
191            1. This function scales your data within a limited range, usually [-1, 1]
192            2. It also centers your data around 0 (the mean).
193            3. If you want unit variance, use z_score standardization
194
195        Example
196        -------
197        >>>    Normalization(df).mean_normalization()
198        """
199        normalized_data ={}
200
201        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
202            
203            data = np.array(self.df[column])
204
205            data_mean = data.mean()
206
207            normalized_data[column] = (data - data_mean) / (data.max() - data.min())
208
209        return pd.DataFrame(normalized_data)
210
211    def l1_normalization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
212        """
213        Normalizes your data by dividing each value with the sum of absolute values.
214
215        Formula
216        --------
217                      X
218            X' =  ---------
219                    | X |
220
221        Returns
222        --------
223        pd.DataFrame
224            A pandas DataFrame
225
226        Usage Recommendation
227        ---------------------
228            1. Use this function when ratio (proportions) of values matter more than than the size (magnitude) of value.
229            2. Use this function if your data is sparse (have a lot of zeroes)
230
231            3. DO NOT USE this function if your data is negative since L1 Normalization uses absolute values.
232
233        Considerations
234        ---------------
235            1. This function scales your data to proportions that sum up to a value of 1
236            2. It does not affect the shape of your data.
237
238        Example
239        -------
240            Normalization(df).l1_normalization()
241        """
242        l1_norm = {}
243
244        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
245            data = np.array(self.df[column])
246
247            l1_norm[column] = data / np.abs(data.sum())
248
249        l1_df = pd.DataFrame(l1_norm)
250
251        return l1_df
252
253    def l2_normalization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
254        """
255        Normalizes your data by dividing each value with the square root of the sum of squared values.
256
257        Formula
258        --------
259                             X
260            X' =     ------------------
261                    square root of ( (X^2))
262
263        Returns
264        --------
265        pd.DataFrame
266            A pandas DataFrame
267
268        Usage Recommendation
269        ---------------------
270            1. Use this function when direction (pattern) or shape of data matter more than how big the numbers are.
271            2. Use this function if your data is sparse (have a lot of zeroes)
272
273            3. DO NOT USE if magnitude (size) of your data matters more than the direction of data.
274            4. DO NOT USE if you want to keep a lot of zeroes in your data since this function spreads values around.
275            5. DO NOT USE if your features have a lot of outliers.
276
277        Considerations
278        ---------------
279            1. This function does not affect the shape or direction of your data.
280
281        Example
282        --------
283            Normalization(df).l2_normalization()
284        """
285        l2_norm = {}
286
287        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
288            data = np.array(self.df[column])
289
290            l2_norm[column] = data / (np.sqrt(((data)**2).sum()))
291
292        l2_df = pd.DataFrame(l2_norm)
293
294        return l2_df
295
296    def lmax_normalization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
297        """
298        Normalizes your data by dividing each value with the maximum absolute value.
299
300        Formula
301        --------
302                        X
303            X' =    ----------
304                    max(| X |)
305
306        Returns
307        --------
308        pd.DataFrame
309            A pandas DataFrame
310
311        Usage Recommendation
312        ---------------------
313            1. Use this function when direction (pattern) or shape of data matter more than how big the numbers are.
314            2. Use this function if your data is sparse (have a lot of zeroes)
315
316            3. DO NOT USE if magnitude (size) of your data matters more than the direction of data.
317            4. DO NOT USE if you want to keep a lot of zeroes in your data since this function spreads values around.
318            5. DO NOT USE if your features have a lot of outliers.
319
320        Considerations
321        ---------------
322            1. This function does not affect the shape or direction of your data.
323
324        Example
325        --------
326        >>>    Normalization(df).lmax_normalization()
327        """
328        l_max_normalization = {}
329
330        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
331            data = np.array(self.df[column])
332
333            l_max_normalization[column] = data / (np.abs(data).max())
334
335        l_max_df = pd.DataFrame(l_max_normalization)
336
337        return l_max_df

Initializing Normalization.

Parameters

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas dataframe you wish to normalize

columns: list, optional A list of numerical columns you want to apply normalization on, default is None.

Normalization(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None) 
21    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns: list = None):
22        super().__init__(df, columns)
23      
24        self.df = self.df.select_dtypes(include='number')
25        
26        if columns is None:
27            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
28        else:
29            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
df
def max_normalization(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
31    def max_normalization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
32        """
33        Normalizes your data by dividing each value with the maximum value of that column.
34
35        Formula
36        --------
37                    X
38            X' =  -----
39                   max
40
41        Returns
42        --------
43        pd.DataFrame
44            A pandas DataFrame
45
46        Usage Recommendation
47        ---------------------
48            1. Use this function when you do not have negative values in your data.
49            2. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
50               Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)
51
52            3. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.
53
54        Considerations
55        ---------------
56            1. This function scales your data by squeezing it between 0 and 1 without changing the shape of your data.
57            2. It does not mean that the mean of your data will be 0, or 1 standard deviation away from the mean.
58            3. For making your data zero-centered (mean = 0, std=1), use ``Standardization()``
59
60        Example
61        -------
62        >>>    Normalization(df).max_normalization()
63        """
64        normalized_data = {}
65
66        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
67            
68            data = np.array(self.df[column]) 
69
70            maximum_absolute_value = np.abs(data.max())
71
72            normalized_data[column] = (data/maximum_absolute_value)
73            
74            normalized_df = pd.DataFrame(normalized_data) 
75
76        return normalized_df

Normalizes your data by dividing each value with the maximum value of that column.

Formula

        X
X' =  -----
       max

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when you do not have negative values in your data.
2. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
   Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)

3. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.

Considerations

1. This function scales your data by squeezing it between 0 and 1 without changing the shape of your data.
2. It does not mean that the mean of your data will be 0, or 1 standard deviation away from the mean.
3. For making your data zero-centered (mean = 0, std=1), use ``Standardization()``

Example

>>>    Normalization(df).max_normalization()
def minmax_normalization(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
 78    def minmax_normalization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
 79        """
 80        Normalizes your data to a range [0, 1] based on the minimum and maximum values.
 81
 82        Formula
 83        -------
 84                  (X - min)
 85            X' =  ---------
 86                 (max - min)
 87
 88        Returns
 89        --------
 90        pd.DataFrame
 91            A pandas DataFrame
 92
 93        Usage Recommendation
 94        ---------------------
 95            1. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
 96               Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)
 97
 98            2. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.
 99
100        Considerations
101        ---------------
102            1. This function scales your data by squeezing it between 0 and 1 without changing the shape of your data.
103            2. It does not mean that the mean of your data will be 0, or 1 standard deviation away from the mean.
104            3. For making your data zero-centered (mean = 0, std=1), use Standardization()
105
106        Example
107        --------
108        >>>    Normalization(df).minmax_normalization()
109        """
110        minmax_normalized_data ={}
111
112        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
113            
114            data = np.array(self.df[column])
115
116            minmax_normalized_data[column] = (data - data.min()) / (data.max() - data.min())
117
118        minmax_normalized_df = pd.DataFrame(minmax_normalized_data)
119            
120        return minmax_normalized_df

Normalizes your data to a range [0, 1] based on the minimum and maximum values.

Formula

      (X - min)
X' =  ---------
     (max - min)

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
   Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)

2. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.

Considerations

1. This function scales your data by squeezing it between 0 and 1 without changing the shape of your data.
2. It does not mean that the mean of your data will be 0, or 1 standard deviation away from the mean.
3. For making your data zero-centered (mean = 0, std=1), use Standardization()

Example

>>>    Normalization(df).minmax_normalization()
def feature_range_normalization(self, range: tuple = (0, 1)) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
122    def feature_range_normalization(self, range:tuple = (0, 1)) -> pd.DataFrame:
123        """
124        Normalizes your data to a specified range based on the minimum and maximum values.
125
126        Formula
127        --------
128                   (X - min)
129            X' =  -----------
130                  (max - min)
131
132        Parameters
133        -----------
134        range: tuple, optional
135            A tuple of minimum and maximum value you wish to scale your data between, default is (0,1).
136
137        Returns
138        --------
139        pd.DataFrame
140            A pandas DataFrame
141
142        Usage Recommendation
143        ---------------------
144            1. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
145               Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)
146
147            2. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.
148
149        Considerations
150        ---------------
151            1. This function scales your data by squeezing it between 0 and 1 without changing the shape of your data.
152            2. It does not mean that the mean of your data will be 0, or 1 standard deviation away from the mean.
153            3. For making your data zero-centered (mean = 0, std=1), use Standardization()
154
155        Example
156        --------
157        >>>    Normalization(df).feature_range_normalization()
158        """
159        minmax_normalized_data = Normalization(self.df).minmax_normalization()
160
161        r_min, r_max = range
162
163        featurerange_normalized_df = minmax_normalized_data * (r_max - r_min) + r_min
164
165        return featurerange_normalized_df

Normalizes your data to a specified range based on the minimum and maximum values.

Formula

       (X - min)
X' =  -----------
      (max - min)

Parameters

range: tuple, optional A tuple of minimum and maximum value you wish to scale your data between, default is (0,1).

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
   Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)

2. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.

Considerations

1. This function scales your data by squeezing it between 0 and 1 without changing the shape of your data.
2. It does not mean that the mean of your data will be 0, or 1 standard deviation away from the mean.
3. For making your data zero-centered (mean = 0, std=1), use Standardization()

Example

>>>    Normalization(df).feature_range_normalization()
def mean_normalization(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
167    def mean_normalization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
168        """
169        Normalizes your data by subtracting the mean and dividing by the range (max-min)..
170
171        Formula:
172
173                  (X - mean)
174            X' =  ----------
175                  (max - min)
176
177        Returns
178        --------
179        pd.DataFrame
180            A pandas DataFrame
181
182        Usage Recommendation
183        ---------------------
184            1. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
185               Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)
186
187            2. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.
188
189        Considerations
190        ---------------
191            1. This function scales your data within a limited range, usually [-1, 1]
192            2. It also centers your data around 0 (the mean).
193            3. If you want unit variance, use z_score standardization
194
195        Example
196        -------
197        >>>    Normalization(df).mean_normalization()
198        """
199        normalized_data ={}
200
201        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
202            
203            data = np.array(self.df[column])
204
205            data_mean = data.mean()
206
207            normalized_data[column] = (data - data_mean) / (data.max() - data.min())
208
209        return pd.DataFrame(normalized_data)

Normalizes your data by subtracting the mean and dividing by the range (max-min)..

Formula:

      (X - mean)
X' =  ----------
      (max - min)

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when your models are sensitive to feature scaling.
   Examples: KNN, Neural Networks, k-means, DBSCAN, or Gradient based (Adam, SGD)

2. DO NOT USE this function if your maximum value is an outlier. It will distort scaling.

Considerations

1. This function scales your data within a limited range, usually [-1, 1]
2. It also centers your data around 0 (the mean).
3. If you want unit variance, use z_score standardization

Example

>>>    Normalization(df).mean_normalization()
def l1_normalization(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
211    def l1_normalization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
212        """
213        Normalizes your data by dividing each value with the sum of absolute values.
214
215        Formula
216        --------
217                      X
218            X' =  ---------
219                    | X |
220
221        Returns
222        --------
223        pd.DataFrame
224            A pandas DataFrame
225
226        Usage Recommendation
227        ---------------------
228            1. Use this function when ratio (proportions) of values matter more than than the size (magnitude) of value.
229            2. Use this function if your data is sparse (have a lot of zeroes)
230
231            3. DO NOT USE this function if your data is negative since L1 Normalization uses absolute values.
232
233        Considerations
234        ---------------
235            1. This function scales your data to proportions that sum up to a value of 1
236            2. It does not affect the shape of your data.
237
238        Example
239        -------
240            Normalization(df).l1_normalization()
241        """
242        l1_norm = {}
243
244        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
245            data = np.array(self.df[column])
246
247            l1_norm[column] = data / np.abs(data.sum())
248
249        l1_df = pd.DataFrame(l1_norm)
250
251        return l1_df

Normalizes your data by dividing each value with the sum of absolute values.

Formula

          X
X' =  ---------
        | X |

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

1. Use this function when ratio (proportions) of values matter more than than the size (magnitude) of value.
2. Use this function if your data is sparse (have a lot of zeroes)

3. DO NOT USE this function if your data is negative since L1 Normalization uses absolute values.

Considerations

1. This function scales your data to proportions that sum up to a value of 1
2. It does not affect the shape of your data.

Example

Normalization(df).l1_normalization()
def l2_normalization(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame:

254        """
255        Normalizes your data by dividing each value with the square root of the sum of squared values.
256
257        Formula
258        --------
259                             X
260            X' =     ------------------
261                    square root of ( (X^2))
262
263        Returns
264        --------
265        pd.DataFrame
266            A pandas DataFrame
267
268        Usage Recommendation
269        ---------------------
270            1. Use this function when direction (pattern) or shape of data matter more than how big the numbers are.
271            2. Use this function if your data is sparse (have a lot of zeroes)
272
273            3. DO NOT USE if magnitude (size) of your data matters more than the direction of data.
274            4. DO NOT USE if you want to keep a lot of zeroes in your data since this function spreads values around.
275            5. DO NOT USE if your features have a lot of outliers.
276
277        Considerations

279            1. This function does not affect the shape or direction of your data.

289
290            l2_norm[column] = data / (np.sqrt(((data)**2).sum()))
291
292        l2_df = pd.DataFrame(l2_norm)

317            4. DO NOT USE if you want to keep a lot of zeroes in your data since this function spreads values around.

class Standardization(datalab.tabular.data_preprocessor.DataPreprocessor.DataPreprocessor): 
10class Standardization(DataPreprocessor):
11    """
12    Initializing Standardization.
13
14    Parameters:
15    -----------
16    df: pd.DataFrame
17        A pandas dataframe you wish to standardize.
18
19    columns: list, optional
20        A list of numerical columns you want to apply standardization on, default is None.
21    """
22
23    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns: list = None):
24        super().__init__(df, columns)
25
26        self.df = self.df.select_dtypes(include='number')
27        
28        if columns is None:
29            self.columns = self.df.columns
30        else:
31            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
32
33        logger.info('Standardization initialized.')
34
35    def z_score_standardization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
36        """Also known as StandardScaler()."""
37        import numpy as np
38
39        z_scores = np.abs((self.df - self.df.mean())/self.df.std())
40
41        standardized_data = self.df / z_scores
42
43        logger.info('Standardized data using z-score method.')
44
45        return standardized_data
46
47    def robust_iqr_standardization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
48        """Standardizes data by centering data at the median and scales by IQR(Inter-Quartile Range)."""
49
50        from ..computations import Statistics
51
52        standardized_data = (self.df - self.df.median())/ Statistics(self.df).iqr()
53
54        logger.info('Standardized data using iqr method.')
55
56        return standardized_data
57
58    def robust_mad_standardization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
59        """Standardizes data by centering data at the median and scales by scaled-MAD(Median Absolute Deviation)."""
60
61        from ..computations import Statistics
62
63        robust_standardized_data = (self.df - self.df.median())/Statistics(self.df).scaled_median_absolute_deviation()
64
65        logger.info('Standardized data using median absolute deviation.')
66
67        return robust_standardized_data
68
69    def unit_variance(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
70        """Standardizes data by scaling the numbers so they are 1 standard deviation away from each other."""
71        from ..computations import Statistics
72
73        standardized_data = self.df / Statistics(self.df).standard_deviation()
74
75        logger.info('Standardized data by spreading data 1 standard deviation away.')
76
77        return standardized_data
78
79    def mean_centering(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
80        """Standardizes data by centering data around the mean."""
81        mean_centered_data = self.df - self.df.mean()
82
83        logger.info('Standardized data by centering it around the mean.')
84        return mean_centered_data

Initializing Standardization.

Parameters:

df: pd.DataFrame A pandas dataframe you wish to standardize.

columns: list, optional A list of numerical columns you want to apply standardization on, default is None.

Standardization(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None) 
23    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns: list = None):
24        super().__init__(df, columns)
25
26        self.df = self.df.select_dtypes(include='number')
27        
28        if columns is None:
29            self.columns = self.df.columns
30        else:
31            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
32
33        logger.info('Standardization initialized.')
df
def z_score_standardization(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
35    def z_score_standardization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
36        """Also known as StandardScaler()."""
37        import numpy as np
38
39        z_scores = np.abs((self.df - self.df.mean())/self.df.std())
40
41        standardized_data = self.df / z_scores
42
43        logger.info('Standardized data using z-score method.')
44
45        return standardized_data

Also known as StandardScaler().

def robust_iqr_standardization(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
47    def robust_iqr_standardization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
48        """Standardizes data by centering data at the median and scales by IQR(Inter-Quartile Range)."""
49
50        from ..computations import Statistics
51
52        standardized_data = (self.df - self.df.median())/ Statistics(self.df).iqr()
53
54        logger.info('Standardized data using iqr method.')
55
56        return standardized_data
