def robust_mad_standardization(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
58    def robust_mad_standardization(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
59        """Standardizes data by centering data at the median and scales by scaled-MAD(Median Absolute Deviation)."""
60
61        from ..computations import Statistics
62
63        robust_standardized_data = (self.df - self.df.median())/Statistics(self.df).scaled_median_absolute_deviation()
64
65        logger.info('Standardized data using median absolute deviation.')
66
67        return robust_standardized_data

Standardizes data by centering data at the median and scales by scaled-MAD(Median Absolute Deviation).

def unit_variance(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
69    def unit_variance(self) -> pd.DataFrame:
70        """Standardizes data by scaling the numbers so they are 1 standard deviation away from each other."""
71        from ..computations import Statistics
72
73        standardized_data = self.df / Statistics(self.df).standard_deviation()
74
75        logger.info('Standardized data by spreading data 1 standard deviation away.')
76
77        return standardized_data

Standardizes data by scaling the numbers so they are 1 standard deviation away from each other.

def mean_centering(self) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
79    def mean_centering(self)-> pd.DataFrame:
80        """Standardizes data by centering data around the mean."""
81        mean_centered_data = self.df - self.df.mean()
82
83        logger.info('Standardized data by centering it around the mean.')
84        return mean_centered_data

Standardizes data by centering data around the mean.

class CategoricalVisualizer: 
  8class CategoricalVisualizer():
  9    """
 10    Initializing Categorical Visualizer.
 11    
 12    Parameters
 13    -----------
 14    df : pd.DataFrame
 15        A pandas DataFrame.
 16
 17    columns : list, optional
 18        List of columns you wish to visualize, by default None.
 19    """
 20
 21    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns: list|type(None) = None):
 22    
 23        self.df.select_dtypes(include = ['string', 'object', 'category'])
 24        
 25        if columns is None:
 26            self.columns = df.columns
 27
 28        else: 
 29            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 30
 31    def visualize_frequency(self,
 32                            method:str ='count',
 33                            viz_type: str = 'bar',
 34                            title: str=None,
 35                            xlabel: str=None,
 36                            ylabel: str=None,
 37                            figsize: tuple =(6, 4)):
 38        """
 39        Visualize frequency for each column of Categorical DataFrame.
 40
 41        Parameters
 42        -----------
 43        method : str, optional
 44            Whether you would like to visualize count or percentage of frequency, default is 'count'.
 45
 46            Available methods:
 47
 48            - 'count': Visualizes the count of unique values in each category (default).
 49            - 'percent': Visualizes the percentage of values in each category.
 50
 51        viz_type : str, optional
 52            Type of visualization, default is 'bar'.
 53
 54            Available viz types:
 55
 56            - 'bar'   : Vertical bar chart (default)
 57            - 'line'  : Line plot
 58            - 'barh'  : Horizontal bar chart
 59            - 'hist'  : Histogram
 60            - 'box'   : Boxplot
 61            - 'kde'   : Kernel density estimate
 62            - 'area'  : Area plot
 63            - 'pie"   : Pie chart
 64
 65        xlabel : str, optional
 66            Label for x-axis, default is None.
 67
 68        ylabel : str, optional
 69            Label for y-axis, default is None.
 70
 71        title : str, optional
 72            Title of the plot, default is None.
 73
 74        figsize : tuple, optional
 75            Size of the figure (width, height) in inches, default is (6, 4)
 76
 77        Returns
 78        --------
 79        None
 80                This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.
 81
 82        Usage Recommendation
 83        ----------------------
 84            Use this method of visualization only for categorical data.
 85
 86        Considerations
 87        ---------------
 88            1. Do not use the default settings, if there are many unique categories.
 89
 90            2. Use viz_type as 'hist' if you have many-many unique categories, otherwise processing may be slower.
 91        """
 92        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
 93
 94            (CategoricalDiagnosis(self.df).show_frequency(method=method)[column]).plot(kind=viz_type)
 95
 96            if title:
 97                plt.title(f'{title}: {column}')
 98            else:
 99                plt.title(f'{viz_type} of {column}')
100
101            if xlabel:
102                plt.xlabel(xlabel)
103            else:
104                plt.xlabel(column)
105
106            if ylabel:
107                plt.ylabel(ylabel)
108            else:
109                plt.ylabel(f'{method} of {column}')
110
111            plt.show()

Initializing Categorical Visualizer.

Parameters

df : pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame.

columns : list, optional List of columns you wish to visualize, by default None.

CategoricalVisualizer(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list | None = None) 
21    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns: list|type(None) = None):
22    
23        self.df.select_dtypes(include = ['string', 'object', 'category'])
24        
25        if columns is None:
26            self.columns = df.columns
27
28        else: 
29            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
def visualize_frequency( self, method: str = 'count', viz_type: str = 'bar', title: str = None, xlabel: str = None, ylabel: str = None, figsize: tuple = (6, 4)): 
 31    def visualize_frequency(self,
 32                            method:str ='count',
 33                            viz_type: str = 'bar',
 34                            title: str=None,
 35                            xlabel: str=None,
 36                            ylabel: str=None,
 37                            figsize: tuple =(6, 4)):
 38        """
 39        Visualize frequency for each column of Categorical DataFrame.
 40
 41        Parameters
 42        -----------
 43        method : str, optional
 44            Whether you would like to visualize count or percentage of frequency, default is 'count'.
 45
 46            Available methods:
 47
 48            - 'count': Visualizes the count of unique values in each category (default).
 49            - 'percent': Visualizes the percentage of values in each category.
 50
 51        viz_type : str, optional
 52            Type of visualization, default is 'bar'.
 53
 54            Available viz types:
 55
 56            - 'bar'   : Vertical bar chart (default)
 57            - 'line'  : Line plot
 58            - 'barh'  : Horizontal bar chart
 59            - 'hist'  : Histogram
 60            - 'box'   : Boxplot
 61            - 'kde'   : Kernel density estimate
 62            - 'area'  : Area plot
 63            - 'pie"   : Pie chart
 64
 65        xlabel : str, optional
 66            Label for x-axis, default is None.
 67
 68        ylabel : str, optional
 69            Label for y-axis, default is None.
 70
 71        title : str, optional
 72            Title of the plot, default is None.
 73
 74        figsize : tuple, optional
 75            Size of the figure (width, height) in inches, default is (6, 4)
 76
 77        Returns
 78        --------
 79        None
 80                This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.
 81
 82        Usage Recommendation
 83        ----------------------
 84            Use this method of visualization only for categorical data.
 85
 86        Considerations
 87        ---------------
 88            1. Do not use the default settings, if there are many unique categories.
 89
 90            2. Use viz_type as 'hist' if you have many-many unique categories, otherwise processing may be slower.
 91        """
 92        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
 93
 94            (CategoricalDiagnosis(self.df).show_frequency(method=method)[column]).plot(kind=viz_type)
 95
 96            if title:
 97                plt.title(f'{title}: {column}')
 98            else:
 99                plt.title(f'{viz_type} of {column}')
100
101            if xlabel:
102                plt.xlabel(xlabel)
103            else:
104                plt.xlabel(column)
105
106            if ylabel:
107                plt.ylabel(ylabel)
108            else:
109                plt.ylabel(f'{method} of {column}')
110
111            plt.show()

Visualize frequency for each column of Categorical DataFrame.

Parameters

method : str, optional Whether you would like to visualize count or percentage of frequency, default is 'count'.

Available methods:

- 'count': Visualizes the count of unique values in each category (default).
- 'percent': Visualizes the percentage of values in each category.

viz_type : str, optional Type of visualization, default is 'bar'.

Available viz types:

- 'bar'   : Vertical bar chart (default)
- 'line'  : Line plot
- 'barh'  : Horizontal bar chart
- 'hist'  : Histogram
- 'box'   : Boxplot
- 'kde'   : Kernel density estimate
- 'area'  : Area plot
- 'pie"   : Pie chart

xlabel : str, optional Label for x-axis, default is None.

ylabel : str, optional Label for y-axis, default is None.

title : str, optional Title of the plot, default is None.

figsize : tuple, optional Size of the figure (width, height) in inches, default is (6, 4)

Returns

None This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.

Usage Recommendation

Use this method of visualization only for categorical data.

Considerations

1. Do not use the default settings, if there are many unique categories.

2. Use viz_type as 'hist' if you have many-many unique categories, otherwise processing may be slower.
class NumericalVisualizer: 
 18class NumericalVisualizer():
 19
 20    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns: list|type(None) = None):
 21        """Initializing Numerical Visualizer.
 22        
 23        Parameters
 24        -----------
 25        df : pd.DataFrame
 26            A pandas DataFrame.
 27
 28        columns : list, optional
 29            List of columns you wish to visualize, by default None.
 30        
 31        """
 32        # getting the elements of parent DataVisualizer class
 33
 34        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include = 'number')
 35        
 36        if columns is None:
 37            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
 38        else: 
 39            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in df.columns]
 40
 41        logger.info(f'Numerical Visualizer initialized.')
 42        
 43    def plot_histogram(self,
 44                  bins: int=30,
 45                  title: str=None,
 46                  xlabel: str=None,
 47                  ylabel: str=None,
 48                  figsize: tuple =(6, 4),
 49                  **kwargs):
 50        """
 51        Visualize histogram for one or multiple columns of Numerical DataFrame.
 52
 53        Parameters
 54        -----------
 55        bins : int , optional
 56            Number of bins you wish to visualize, default is 30.
 57
 58        xlabel : str, optional
 59            Label for x-axis, default is None.
 60
 61        ylabel : str, optional 
 62            Label for y-axis, default is None.
 63
 64        title : str, optional
 65            Title of the plot, default is None.
 66
 67        figsize : tuple, optional 
 68            Size of the figure (width, height) in inches, default is (6,4)
 69
 70        **kwargs : dict
 71            Dictionary of keyword arguments passed to ``matplotlib.pyplot.hist``.
 72
 73        Returns
 74        --------
 75        None        
 76            This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything. 
 77
 78        Usage Recommendation
 79        ----------------------
 80            Use this method of visualization only for numerical data.
 81        
 82        Example
 83        -------
 84        >>> NumericalVisualizer(df).plot_box()
 85        """
 86        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 87
 88        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
 89
 90            fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=figsize)
 91
 92            ax.hist(self.df[column],bins=bins, edgecolor='black', **kwargs)
 93
 94            if title:
 95                ax.set_title(f'{title}')
 96            else:
 97                ax.set_title(f'Histogram of {remove_underscores(column)}')
 98
 99            if xlabel:
100                ax.set_xlabel(xlabel)
101            else:
102                ax.set_xlabel(column)
103
104            if ylabel:
105                ax.set_ylabel(ylabel)
106            else:
107                ax.set_ylabel(f'Number of values')
108
109            plt.show()
110
111    def plot_box(self, 
112                orientation : str = 'vertical',
113                xlabel:str|type(None) = None,
114                ylabel:str|type(None) = None,
115                title:str|type(None) = None,
116                figsize:tuple = (6, 4),
117                **kwargs):
118
119        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
120        """
121        Visualize box plot for one or multiple columns of Numerical DataFrame.
122
123        Parameters
124        ----------
125        orientation : str , optional
126            Orientation of the boxplots, default is 'v'.
127
128            Options are:
129
130            - 'vertical' or 'v'
131            - 'horizontal' or 'h'
132
133        xlabel : str, optional
134            Label for x-axis, default is None.
135
136        ylabel : str
137            Label for y-axis, default is None.
138
139        title : str, optional
140            Title of the plot, default is None.
141
142        figsize : tuple, optional
143            Size of the figure (width, height) in inches, default is (6, 4).
144
145        **kwargs : dict
146            Dictionary of keyword arguments passed to ``matplotlib.pyplot.boxplot``.
147
148        Returns
149        --------
150        None
151            This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.
152
153        Usage Recommendation
154        ----------------------
155            Use this method of visualization only for numerical data.
156
157        Example
158        -------
159        >>> NumericalVisualizer(df).plot_box()
160        """
161
162        if orientation not in ('horizontal', 'vertical', 'h', 'v'):
163            raise ValueError(f"orientation must be horizontal or 'h' OR vertical or 'v', got {orientation}")
164
165        # making sure that the orientation starts with vertical or 'v' by default.
166        # if it will be anything other than vertical, it will default to horizontal
167        vert = (orientation.lower().startswith('v'))
168
169        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
170
171            fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=figsize) # defauls to figsize of (6, 4) inches. (6 X 4)
172        
173            # keeping it simple by 
174            ax.boxplot(self.df[column], vert=vert, **kwargs)
175
176            if title:
177                ax.set_title(f'{title}: {column}')
178            else:
179                ax.set_title(f'Boxplot of {remove_underscores(column)}')
180
181            if vert:
182                ax.set_xticks([1])
183                ax.set_xticklabels([column])
184
185                if xlabel:
186                    ax.set_xlabel(xlabel)
187
188                if ylabel:
189                    ax.set_ylabel(ylabel)
190
191            else:
192                ax.set_yticks([1])
193                ax.set_yticklabels([column])
194
195                if xlabel:
196                    ax.set_xlabel(xlabel)
197                
198                if ylabel:
199                    ax.set_ylabel(ylabel)
200
201            plt.show()
202
203    def plot_kde(self, bandwidth_method: str ='robust',
204                  title: str=None,
205                  xlabel: str=None,
206                  ylabel: str=None,
207                  figsize: tuple =(6, 4),
208                  **kwargs):
209        """
210        Visualize Kernel Density Estimation plot (curves, including bell curve) for one or multiple columns of DataFrame.
211
212        Parameters:
213        -----------
214        bandwidth_method: 'str' 
215            The method you wish to use for computing KDE, default is 'robust'.
216
217            Methods available:
218
219            For Normal Distribution:
220
221                - 'silverman'
222                - 'scott'
223
224            For Skewed Distribution:
225
226                - 'robust' (uses robust scott)
227
228        xlabel : str, optional
229            Label for x-axis, default is None.
230
231        ylabel : str
232            Label for y-axis, default is None.
233
234        title : str, optional
235            Title of the plot, default is None.
236
237        figsize : tuple, optional
238            Size of the figure (width, height) in inches, default is (6, 4).
239
240        **kwargs : dict
241            Dictionary of keyword arguments passed to ``matplotlib.pyplot.plot``.
242
243        Returns
244        --------
245        None
246            This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.
247
248        Usage Recommendation
249        ----------------------
250            Use this method of visualization only of numerical data.
251
252        Considerations:
253        ---------------
254            This function uses ``compute_KDE()`` and ``compute_histogram()`` from Distribution class of the Computation Package
255
256        Example
257        -------
258        >>> NumericalVisualizer(df).plot_kde()
259        """
260        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
261
262        # compute_KDE() returns a DataFrame
263        kde_df= Distribution(self.df).compute_kde(bandwidth_method=bandwidth_method)
264
265        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
266            # using bin_centers from histogram computation as values for x-axis.
267            x= Distribution(self.df).compute_histogram()['bin_centers'][column].dropna()
268
269            # using KDE values for y-axis.
270            y = kde_df[column]
271
272            fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=figsize)
273            # plotting using plot 		
274            ax.plot(x, y, label=column, **kwargs)
275            
276            if title:
277                ax.set_title(f'{title}: {column}')
278            else:
279                ax.set_title(f'Kernel Density Estimation plot of {remove_underscores(column)}')
280
281            if xlabel:
282                ax.set_xlabel(xlabel)
283            else:
284                ax.set_xlabel(column)
285
286            if ylabel:
287                ax.set_ylabel(ylabel)
288            else:
289                ax.set_ylabel('Count')
290
291            ax.legend()
292
293            plt.show()
294
295    def plot_qq(self, distribution_type: str = 'norm', title: str =None, points_color: str = 'green'):
296        """
297        Visualize Quantile-Quantile plot (QQ plot) for one or multiple columns of Numerical DataFrame.
298
299        Parameters:
300        -----------
301
302        distribution_type: str (default is 'norm')
303            Type of Distribution you would like to see.
304
305        title : str, optional
306            Title of the plot, default is None. 
307
308        points_color : str, optional
309            Color of data points, default is 'green'.
310
311        Returns
312        --------
313        None
314            This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.
315
316        Usage Recommendation
317        ----------------------
318            Use this method of visualization only of numerical data.
319
320        Example
321        --------
322        >>> NumericalVisualizer(df).plot_qq()
323        """
324        from scipy import stats
325        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
326
327        if distribution_type is None:
328            raise ValueError(f'Unknown distribution: {distribution_type}')
329            
330        distribution_name = getattr(stats, distribution_type, None)
331
332        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
333
334            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
335            
336            # using probplot to create a QQ plot
337            stats.probplot(self.df[column], dist=distribution_name, plot=ax)
338
339            if title:
340                ax.set_title(title)
341            else:
342                ax.set_title(f'QQ plot of {remove_underscores(column)}')
343            
344            # setting color of data points
345
346            ax.get_lines()[0].set_color(points_color)   # points
347            
348            plt.show()
NumericalVisualizer(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list | None = None) 
20    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns: list|type(None) = None):
21        """Initializing Numerical Visualizer.
22        
23        Parameters
24        -----------
25        df : pd.DataFrame
26            A pandas DataFrame.
27
28        columns : list, optional
29            List of columns you wish to visualize, by default None.
30        
31        """
32        # getting the elements of parent DataVisualizer class
33
34        self.df = df.select_dtypes(include = 'number')
35        
36        if columns is None:
37            self.columns = self.df.columns.tolist()
38        else: 
39            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in df.columns]
40
41        logger.info(f'Numerical Visualizer initialized.')

Initializing Numerical Visualizer.

Parameters

df : pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame.

columns : list, optional List of columns you wish to visualize, by default None.

df
def plot_histogram( self, bins: int = 30, title: str = None, xlabel: str = None, ylabel: str = None, figsize: tuple = (6, 4), **kwargs): 
 43    def plot_histogram(self,
 44                  bins: int=30,
 45                  title: str=None,
 46                  xlabel: str=None,
 47                  ylabel: str=None,
 48                  figsize: tuple =(6, 4),
 49                  **kwargs):
 50        """
 51        Visualize histogram for one or multiple columns of Numerical DataFrame.
 52
 53        Parameters
 54        -----------
 55        bins : int , optional
 56            Number of bins you wish to visualize, default is 30.
 57
 58        xlabel : str, optional
 59            Label for x-axis, default is None.
 60
 61        ylabel : str, optional 
 62            Label for y-axis, default is None.
 63
 64        title : str, optional
 65            Title of the plot, default is None.
 66
 67        figsize : tuple, optional 
 68            Size of the figure (width, height) in inches, default is (6,4)
 69
 70        **kwargs : dict
 71            Dictionary of keyword arguments passed to ``matplotlib.pyplot.hist``.
 72
 73        Returns
 74        --------
 75        None        
 76            This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything. 
 77
 78        Usage Recommendation
 79        ----------------------
 80            Use this method of visualization only for numerical data.
 81        
 82        Example
 83        -------
 84        >>> NumericalVisualizer(df).plot_box()
 85        """
 86        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 87
 88        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
 89
 90            fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=figsize)
 91
 92            ax.hist(self.df[column],bins=bins, edgecolor='black', **kwargs)
 93
 94            if title:
 95                ax.set_title(f'{title}')
 96            else:
 97                ax.set_title(f'Histogram of {remove_underscores(column)}')
 98
 99            if xlabel:
100                ax.set_xlabel(xlabel)
101            else:
102                ax.set_xlabel(column)
103
104            if ylabel:
105                ax.set_ylabel(ylabel)
106            else:
107                ax.set_ylabel(f'Number of values')
108
109            plt.show()

Visualize histogram for one or multiple columns of Numerical DataFrame.

Parameters

bins : int , optional Number of bins you wish to visualize, default is 30.

xlabel : str, optional Label for x-axis, default is None.

ylabel : str, optional Label for y-axis, default is None.

title : str, optional Title of the plot, default is None.

figsize : tuple, optional Size of the figure (width, height) in inches, default is (6,4)

**kwargs : dict Dictionary of keyword arguments passed to matplotlib.pyplot.hist.

Returns

None
This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.

Usage Recommendation

Use this method of visualization only for numerical data.

Example

>>> NumericalVisualizer(df).plot_box()
def plot_box( self, orientation: str = 'vertical', xlabel: str | None = None, ylabel: str | None = None, title: str | None = None, figsize: tuple = (6, 4), **kwargs): 
111    def plot_box(self, 
112                orientation : str = 'vertical',
113                xlabel:str|type(None) = None,
114                ylabel:str|type(None) = None,
115                title:str|type(None) = None,
116                figsize:tuple = (6, 4),
117                **kwargs):
118
119        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
120        """
121        Visualize box plot for one or multiple columns of Numerical DataFrame.
122
123        Parameters
124        ----------
125        orientation : str , optional
126            Orientation of the boxplots, default is 'v'.
127
128            Options are:
129
130            - 'vertical' or 'v'
131            - 'horizontal' or 'h'
132
133        xlabel : str, optional
134            Label for x-axis, default is None.
135
136        ylabel : str
137            Label for y-axis, default is None.
138
139        title : str, optional
140            Title of the plot, default is None.
141
142        figsize : tuple, optional
143            Size of the figure (width, height) in inches, default is (6, 4).
144
145        **kwargs : dict
146            Dictionary of keyword arguments passed to ``matplotlib.pyplot.boxplot``.
147
148        Returns
149        --------
150        None
151            This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.
152
153        Usage Recommendation
154        ----------------------
155            Use this method of visualization only for numerical data.
156
157        Example
158        -------
159        >>> NumericalVisualizer(df).plot_box()
160        """
161
162        if orientation not in ('horizontal', 'vertical', 'h', 'v'):
163            raise ValueError(f"orientation must be horizontal or 'h' OR vertical or 'v', got {orientation}")
164
165        # making sure that the orientation starts with vertical or 'v' by default.
166        # if it will be anything other than vertical, it will default to horizontal
167        vert = (orientation.lower().startswith('v'))
168
169        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
170
171            fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=figsize) # defauls to figsize of (6, 4) inches. (6 X 4)
172        
173            # keeping it simple by 
174            ax.boxplot(self.df[column], vert=vert, **kwargs)
175
176            if title:
177                ax.set_title(f'{title}: {column}')
178            else:
179                ax.set_title(f'Boxplot of {remove_underscores(column)}')
180
181            if vert:
182                ax.set_xticks([1])
183                ax.set_xticklabels([column])
184
185                if xlabel:
186                    ax.set_xlabel(xlabel)
187
188                if ylabel:
189                    ax.set_ylabel(ylabel)
190
191            else:
192                ax.set_yticks([1])
193                ax.set_yticklabels([column])
194
195                if xlabel:
196                    ax.set_xlabel(xlabel)
197                
198                if ylabel:
199                    ax.set_ylabel(ylabel)
200
201            plt.show()
def plot_kde( self, bandwidth_method: str = 'robust', title: str = None, xlabel: str = None, ylabel: str = None, figsize: tuple = (6, 4), **kwargs): 
203    def plot_kde(self, bandwidth_method: str ='robust',
204                  title: str=None,
205                  xlabel: str=None,
206                  ylabel: str=None,
207                  figsize: tuple =(6, 4),
208                  **kwargs):
209        """
210        Visualize Kernel Density Estimation plot (curves, including bell curve) for one or multiple columns of DataFrame.
211
212        Parameters:
213        -----------
214        bandwidth_method: 'str' 
215            The method you wish to use for computing KDE, default is 'robust'.
216
217            Methods available:
218
219            For Normal Distribution:
220
221                - 'silverman'
222                - 'scott'
223
224            For Skewed Distribution:
225
226                - 'robust' (uses robust scott)
227
228        xlabel : str, optional
229            Label for x-axis, default is None.
230
231        ylabel : str
232            Label for y-axis, default is None.
233
234        title : str, optional
235            Title of the plot, default is None.
236
237        figsize : tuple, optional
238            Size of the figure (width, height) in inches, default is (6, 4).
239
240        **kwargs : dict
241            Dictionary of keyword arguments passed to ``matplotlib.pyplot.plot``.
242
243        Returns
244        --------
245        None
246            This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.
247
248        Usage Recommendation
249        ----------------------
250            Use this method of visualization only of numerical data.
251
252        Considerations:
253        ---------------
254            This function uses ``compute_KDE()`` and ``compute_histogram()`` from Distribution class of the Computation Package
255
256        Example
257        -------
258        >>> NumericalVisualizer(df).plot_kde()
259        """
260        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
261
262        # compute_KDE() returns a DataFrame
263        kde_df= Distribution(self.df).compute_kde(bandwidth_method=bandwidth_method)
264
265        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
266            # using bin_centers from histogram computation as values for x-axis.
267            x= Distribution(self.df).compute_histogram()['bin_centers'][column].dropna()
268
269            # using KDE values for y-axis.
270            y = kde_df[column]
271
272            fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=figsize)
273            # plotting using plot 		
274            ax.plot(x, y, label=column, **kwargs)
275            
276            if title:
277                ax.set_title(f'{title}: {column}')
278            else:
279                ax.set_title(f'Kernel Density Estimation plot of {remove_underscores(column)}')
280
281            if xlabel:
282                ax.set_xlabel(xlabel)
283            else:
284                ax.set_xlabel(column)
285
286            if ylabel:
287                ax.set_ylabel(ylabel)
288            else:
289                ax.set_ylabel('Count')
290
291            ax.legend()
292
293            plt.show()

Visualize Kernel Density Estimation plot (curves, including bell curve) for one or multiple columns of DataFrame.

Parameters:

bandwidth_method: 'str' The method you wish to use for computing KDE, default is 'robust'.

Methods available:

For Normal Distribution:

    - 'silverman'
    - 'scott'

For Skewed Distribution:

    - 'robust' (uses robust scott)

xlabel : str, optional Label for x-axis, default is None.

ylabel : str Label for y-axis, default is None.

title : str, optional Title of the plot, default is None.

figsize : tuple, optional Size of the figure (width, height) in inches, default is (6, 4).

**kwargs : dict Dictionary of keyword arguments passed to matplotlib.pyplot.plot.

Returns

None This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.

Usage Recommendation

Use this method of visualization only of numerical data.

Considerations:

This function uses ``compute_KDE()`` and ``compute_histogram()`` from Distribution class of the Computation Package

Example

>>> NumericalVisualizer(df).plot_kde()
def plot_qq( self, distribution_type: str = 'norm', title: str = None, points_color: str = 'green'): 
295    def plot_qq(self, distribution_type: str = 'norm', title: str =None, points_color: str = 'green'):
296        """
297        Visualize Quantile-Quantile plot (QQ plot) for one or multiple columns of Numerical DataFrame.
298
299        Parameters:
300        -----------
301
302        distribution_type: str (default is 'norm')
303            Type of Distribution you would like to see.
304
305        title : str, optional
306            Title of the plot, default is None. 
307
308        points_color : str, optional
309            Color of data points, default is 'green'.
310
311        Returns
312        --------
313        None
314            This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.
315
316        Usage Recommendation
317        ----------------------
318            Use this method of visualization only of numerical data.
319
320        Example
321        --------
322        >>> NumericalVisualizer(df).plot_qq()
323        """
324        from scipy import stats
325        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
326
327        if distribution_type is None:
328            raise ValueError(f'Unknown distribution: {distribution_type}')
329            
330        distribution_name = getattr(stats, distribution_type, None)
331
332        for column in self.df[self.columns]:
333
334            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
335            
336            # using probplot to create a QQ plot
337            stats.probplot(self.df[column], dist=distribution_name, plot=ax)
338
339            if title:
340                ax.set_title(title)
341            else:
342                ax.set_title(f'QQ plot of {remove_underscores(column)}')
343            
344            # setting color of data points
345
346            ax.get_lines()[0].set_color(points_color)   # points
347            
348            plt.show()

Visualize Quantile-Quantile plot (QQ plot) for one or multiple columns of Numerical DataFrame.

Parameters:

distribution_type: str (default is 'norm') Type of Distribution you would like to see.

title : str, optional Title of the plot, default is None.

points_color : str, optional Color of data points, default is 'green'.

Returns

None This function is intended for visualization only and does not return anything.

Usage Recommendation

Use this method of visualization only of numerical data.

Example

>>> NumericalVisualizer(df).plot_qq()
class MissingnessVisualizer: 
  9class MissingnessVisualizer():
 10    """
 11    Initializing Missingness Visualizer.
 12    
 13    Parameters
 14    -----------
 15    df : pd.DataFrame
 16        A pandas DataFrame.
 17
 18    columns : list, optional
 19        List of columns you wish to visualize, by default None.
 20    """
 21
 22    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None):
 23
 24        self.df = df
 25
 26        if columns is None:
 27            self.columns = self.df.columns.to_list()
 28        # ensuring that the columns passed are in a list
 29        else:
 30            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 31
 32    def plot_missing(self,
 33                viz_type: str = 'bar',
 34                extra_placeholders: list | None =None,
 35                title: str = None,
 36                xlabel: str = None,
 37                ylabel: str = None,
 38                title_fontsize: int = 24,
 39                title_padding: int = 20,
 40                xlabel_fontsize: int = 15,
 41                xlabel_padding: int = 15,
 42                ylabel_fontsize: int = 15,
 43                ylabel_padding: int = 15):
 44        """
 45        Visualize missing values in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
 46
 47        Parameters
 48        -----------
 49        viz_type : str
 50            Type of visualization you would like to see for missing data, default is 'bar'.
 51
 52            Visualizations available are:
 53
 54                - 'bar'        : Displays a bar chart of missing vs non-missing values for each column
 55                - 'heatmap'    : Creates a correlation heatmap showing how missing values present in one column relate with missing values in another.
 56                - 'matrix'     : Displays a matrix plot where each row is a record in the DataFrame, and the column represents a column of the DataFrame
 57                - 'dendrogram' : Displays a hierarchical clustering plot that groups columns in the DataFrame based on similar patterns of missing values
 58
 59        title : str, optional
 60            Title of the plot, default is None.
 61
 62        title_fontsize: int, optional
 63            Font size of Title of the plot, default is 24.
 64
 65        title_padding : int, optional
 66            This means how much space must be allowed around the title, default is 20.
 67
 68        xlabel : str, optional
 69            Label for x-axis, default is None.
 70
 71        xlabel_fontsize: int, optional
 72            Font size of x-axis label, default is 15.
 73
 74        xlabel_padding : int, optional
 75            This means how much space must be free around x-axis label, default is 15.
 76
 77        ylabel : str, optional
 78            Label for y-axis, default is None.
 79
 80        ylabel_fontsize: int, optional
 81            Font size of y-axis label, default is 15.
 82
 83        ylabel_padding : int, optional
 84            This means how much space must be free around y-axis label, default is 15.
 85
 86        Returns
 87        --------
 88        None
 89            This function is meant for visualization only and does not return anything.
 90
 91        Usage Recommendation
 92        ----------------------
 93            1. Use 'bar' for plotting the volume of missing data vs non-missing data, before filling/dropping rows or columns with null values.
 94            2. Use 'matrix' to identify patterns to see if missing data is missing randomly or in a structured manner
 95            3. Use 'heatmap' for revealing relationships between missing values (if missingness is linked across columns).
 96            4. Use 'dendrogram' for identifying columns grouped together by similarity of missingness
 97
 98        Considerations:
 99        ---------------
100            1. This function uses missingno library under the hood, Just make sure you have it installed or use **pip install missingno**.
101        """
102        import missingno as msno
103        import numpy as np
104
105        visualization_df = self.df.copy()
106        
107        if extra_placeholders is None:
108            extra_placeholders = []
109
110        # getting pandas truly missing values
111        pandas_mask = visualization_df.isna()
112
113        # getting placeholder missing values
114        placeholder_mask = visualization_df.isin(extra_placeholders)
115
116        # getting both the missing types
117        mask = pandas_mask | placeholder_mask
118
119        # since missingno does not have separate support for placeholder values, converting all missing types to np.nan
120        visualization_df[mask] = np.nan
121
122        # missingo functions return a matplotlib axes object, so we can modify it like normal matplotlib plots.
123
124        if viz_type == 'heatmap':
125            ax =  msno.heatmap(visualization_df)
126        
127        elif viz_type == 'bar':
128            ax = msno.bar(visualization_df)
129    
130        elif viz_type == 'matrix':
131            ax = msno.matrix(visualization_df)
132        
133        elif viz_type == 'dendrogram':
134            ax = msno.dendrogram(visualization_df)
135
136        # if user passes a title, it would be user selected title.abs
137        # However, if user does not pass a title, it would default back to viz_type of plot as the title
138
139        if title:
140            ax.set_title(title, fontsize = title_fontsize, pad=title_padding)
141        else:
142            ax.set_title(f'{viz_type} plot of missing data', fontsize = title_fontsize, pad=title_padding)
143
144        if xlabel:
145            ax.set_xlabel(xlabel, fontsize = xlabel_fontsize, labelpad = xlabel_padding)
146        
147        if ylabel:
148            ax.set_ylabel(ylabel, fontsize = ylabel_fontsize, labelpad = ylabel_padding)
149
150        # this function does not return anything anymore.
151        plt.show()

Initializing Missingness Visualizer.

Parameters

df : pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame.

columns : list, optional List of columns you wish to visualize, by default None.

MissingnessVisualizer(df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None) 
22    def __init__(self, df: pd.DataFrame, columns:list = None):
23
24        self.df = df
25
26        if columns is None:
27            self.columns = self.df.columns.to_list()
28        # ensuring that the columns passed are in a list
29        else:
30            self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
df
def plot_missing( self, viz_type: str = 'bar', extra_placeholders: list | None = None, title: str = None, xlabel: str = None, ylabel: str = None, title_fontsize: int = 24, title_padding: int = 20, xlabel_fontsize: int = 15, xlabel_padding: int = 15, ylabel_fontsize: int = 15, ylabel_padding: int = 15): 
 32    def plot_missing(self,
 33                viz_type: str = 'bar',
 34                extra_placeholders: list | None =None,
 35                title: str = None,
 36                xlabel: str = None,
 37                ylabel: str = None,
 38                title_fontsize: int = 24,
 39                title_padding: int = 20,
 40                xlabel_fontsize: int = 15,
 41                xlabel_padding: int = 15,
 42                ylabel_fontsize: int = 15,
 43                ylabel_padding: int = 15):
 44        """
 45        Visualize missing values in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.
 46
 47        Parameters
 48        -----------
 49        viz_type : str
 50            Type of visualization you would like to see for missing data, default is 'bar'.
 51
 52            Visualizations available are:
 53
 54                - 'bar'        : Displays a bar chart of missing vs non-missing values for each column
 55                - 'heatmap'    : Creates a correlation heatmap showing how missing values present in one column relate with missing values in another.
 56                - 'matrix'     : Displays a matrix plot where each row is a record in the DataFrame, and the column represents a column of the DataFrame
 57                - 'dendrogram' : Displays a hierarchical clustering plot that groups columns in the DataFrame based on similar patterns of missing values
 58
 59        title : str, optional
 60            Title of the plot, default is None.
 61
 62        title_fontsize: int, optional
 63            Font size of Title of the plot, default is 24.
 64
 65        title_padding : int, optional
 66            This means how much space must be allowed around the title, default is 20.
 67
 68        xlabel : str, optional
 69            Label for x-axis, default is None.
 70
 71        xlabel_fontsize: int, optional
 72            Font size of x-axis label, default is 15.
 73
 74        xlabel_padding : int, optional
 75            This means how much space must be free around x-axis label, default is 15.
 76
 77        ylabel : str, optional
 78            Label for y-axis, default is None.
 79
 80        ylabel_fontsize: int, optional
 81            Font size of y-axis label, default is 15.
 82
 83        ylabel_padding : int, optional
 84            This means how much space must be free around y-axis label, default is 15.
 85
 86        Returns
 87        --------
 88        None
 89            This function is meant for visualization only and does not return anything.
 90
 91        Usage Recommendation
 92        ----------------------
 93            1. Use 'bar' for plotting the volume of missing data vs non-missing data, before filling/dropping rows or columns with null values.
 94            2. Use 'matrix' to identify patterns to see if missing data is missing randomly or in a structured manner
 95            3. Use 'heatmap' for revealing relationships between missing values (if missingness is linked across columns).
 96            4. Use 'dendrogram' for identifying columns grouped together by similarity of missingness
 97
 98        Considerations:
 99        ---------------
100            1. This function uses missingno library under the hood, Just make sure you have it installed or use **pip install missingno**.
101        """
102        import missingno as msno
103        import numpy as np
104
105        visualization_df = self.df.copy()
106        
107        if extra_placeholders is None:
108            extra_placeholders = []
109
110        # getting pandas truly missing values
111        pandas_mask = visualization_df.isna()
112
113        # getting placeholder missing values
114        placeholder_mask = visualization_df.isin(extra_placeholders)
115
116        # getting both the missing types
117        mask = pandas_mask | placeholder_mask
118
119        # since missingno does not have separate support for placeholder values, converting all missing types to np.nan
120        visualization_df[mask] = np.nan
121
122        # missingo functions return a matplotlib axes object, so we can modify it like normal matplotlib plots.
123
124        if viz_type == 'heatmap':
125            ax =  msno.heatmap(visualization_df)
126        
127        elif viz_type == 'bar':
128            ax = msno.bar(visualization_df)
129    
130        elif viz_type == 'matrix':
131            ax = msno.matrix(visualization_df)
132        
133        elif viz_type == 'dendrogram':
134            ax = msno.dendrogram(visualization_df)
135
136        # if user passes a title, it would be user selected title.abs
137        # However, if user does not pass a title, it would default back to viz_type of plot as the title
138
139        if title:
140            ax.set_title(title, fontsize = title_fontsize, pad=title_padding)
141        else:
142            ax.set_title(f'{viz_type} plot of missing data', fontsize = title_fontsize, pad=title_padding)
143
144        if xlabel:
145            ax.set_xlabel(xlabel, fontsize = xlabel_fontsize, labelpad = xlabel_padding)
146        
147        if ylabel:
148            ax.set_ylabel(ylabel, fontsize = ylabel_fontsize, labelpad = ylabel_padding)
149
150        # this function does not return anything anymore.
151        plt.show()

Visualize missing values in one or multiple columns of the DataFrame.

Parameters

viz_type : str Type of visualization you would like to see for missing data, default is 'bar'.

Visualizations available are:

    - 'bar'        : Displays a bar chart of missing vs non-missing values for each column
    - 'heatmap'    : Creates a correlation heatmap showing how missing values present in one column relate with missing values in another.
    - 'matrix'     : Displays a matrix plot where each row is a record in the DataFrame, and the column represents a column of the DataFrame
    - 'dendrogram' : Displays a hierarchical clustering plot that groups columns in the DataFrame based on similar patterns of missing values

title : str, optional Title of the plot, default is None.

title_fontsize: int, optional Font size of Title of the plot, default is 24.

title_padding : int, optional This means how much space must be allowed around the title, default is 20.

xlabel : str, optional Label for x-axis, default is None.

xlabel_fontsize: int, optional Font size of x-axis label, default is 15.

xlabel_padding : int, optional This means how much space must be free around x-axis label, default is 15.

ylabel : str, optional Label for y-axis, default is None.

ylabel_fontsize: int, optional Font size of y-axis label, default is 15.

ylabel_padding : int, optional This means how much space must be free around y-axis label, default is 15.

Returns

None This function is meant for visualization only and does not return anything.

Usage Recommendation

1. Use 'bar' for plotting the volume of missing data vs non-missing data, before filling/dropping rows or columns with null values.
2. Use 'matrix' to identify patterns to see if missing data is missing randomly or in a structured manner
3. Use 'heatmap' for revealing relationships between missing values (if missingness is linked across columns).
4. Use 'dendrogram' for identifying columns grouped together by similarity of missingness

Considerations:

1. This function uses missingno library under the hood, Just make sure you have it installed or use **pip install missingno**.
class BackendConverter: 
  7class BackendConverter:
  8    """
  9    Initializing the Backend Converter.
 10
 11    Parameters
 12    -----------
 13    df: pd.DataFrame or pl.DataFrame
 14        A pandas DataFrame or a polars DataFrame.
 15
 16    columns: list, optional
 17        A list of columns you wish to convert, default is None.
 18
 19    """
 20
 21    def __init__(self, df:pd.DataFrame|pl.DataFrame, columns:list=None):
 22
 23        if not isinstance(df, (pd.DataFrame, pl.DataFrame)):
 24            raise TypeError(f'Backend Converter expects a pandas DataFrame or a polars DataFrame, got {type(df).__name__}')
 25
 26        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
 27            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list or type None, got {type(df).__name__}')
 28
 29        if isinstance(df, pd.DataFrame):
 30
 31            self.df = df.copy()
 32
 33            if columns is None:
 34                self.columns = self.df.columns.to_list()
 35            else:
 36                self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 37
 38        elif isinstance (df, pl.DataFrame):
 39            
 40            self.df = df.clone()
 41
 42            if columns is None:
 43                self.columns = self.df.columns
 44
 45            else:
 46                self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
 47
 48    def polars_to_pandas(self, array_type: str='auto', conversion_threshold: int=None)-> pd.DataFrame:
 49        """
 50        Converts a polars DataFrame to a pandas DataFrame
 51
 52        Parameters
 53        -----------
 54        array_type: str
 55    
 56            Determines the array/backend type used in pandas operations, by default 'auto'.
 57
 58            Options are:
 59
 60            - 'numpy' -> usual NumPy backend (slower for very large datasets with object types)
 61            - 'pyarrow' -> PyArrow backend for better performance on large datasets
 62            - 'auto' -> automatically selects backend based on input and dataset size 
 63
 64        conversion_threshold: int
 65            The number of rows at which the conversion from Polars to pandas switches to Arrow-backed pandas arrays for performance, default is 100000.
 66            Users can increase or decrease this threshold depending on their dataset size and memory availability.
 67        
 68        Returns
 69        -------
 70        pd.DataFrame
 71            A pandas DataFrame
 72
 73        Usage Recommendation
 74        ---------------------
 75            Use this function to convert datasets quickly without having to do manual conversions and remembering parameters.
 76            Polars -> pandas conversion ensures efficient memory usage and stability, even on low-RAM systems.
 77
 78        Considerations
 79        ---------------
 80            Adjust array_type and conversion_threshold for very large datasets to optimize performance and memory usage.
 81        """
 82
 83        if not isinstance(self.df, pl.DataFrame):
 84            raise TypeError(f'Expected a polars DataFrame, got {type(self.df).__name__}')
 85
 86        if not isinstance(array_type, str):
 87            raise TypeError(f'array type must be a string, got {type(array_type).__name__}')
 88        
 89        if not isinstance(conversion_threshold, (int, type(None))):
 90            raise TypeError(f'conversion threshold must be an integer or type None, got {type(conversion_threshold).__name__}')
 91
 92        if conversion_threshold is None:
 93            conversion_threshold = 100_000
 94
 95        df_size = self.df.height
 96
 97        if array_type == 'auto':
 98            # if rows more than or equal to conversion threshold
 99            if df_size >= conversion_threshold:
100                return self.df.to_pandas(use_pyarrow_extension_array=True)
101            else:
102                return self.df.to_pandas()
103
104        if array_type == 'numpy':
105            
106            pandas_df = self.df.to_pandas()
107            return pandas_df
108
109        elif array_type == 'pyarrow':
110
111            pandas_df = self.df.to_pandas(use_pyarrow_extension_array=True)
112
113            return pandas_df 
114
115    def pandas_to_polars(self, include_index:bool=False)-> pl.DataFrame:
116        """
117        Converts a pandas DataFrame to a polars DataFrame
118
119        Parameters
120        -----------
121        include_index: bool, optional
122            Whether you would like to include index during conversion from pandas to polars, by default False
123        
124        Returns
125        -------
126        pl.DataFrame
127            A polars DataFrame
128            
129        Considerations
130        ---------------
131            Polars do not have the concept of index like pandas does, hence, you can adjust include_index depending on your requirement.
132        """
133        
134        if not isinstance(include_index, bool):
135            raise TypeError(f'include_index must be either True or False, got {type(include_index).__name__}')
136
137        polars_df = pl.from_pandas(self.df, include_index = include_index)
138
139        return polars_df

Initializing the Backend Converter.

Parameters

df: pd.DataFrame or pl.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame or a polars DataFrame.

columns: list, optional A list of columns you wish to convert, default is None.

BackendConverter( df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame | polars.dataframe.frame.DataFrame, columns: list = None) 
21    def __init__(self, df:pd.DataFrame|pl.DataFrame, columns:list=None):
22
23        if not isinstance(df, (pd.DataFrame, pl.DataFrame)):
24            raise TypeError(f'Backend Converter expects a pandas DataFrame or a polars DataFrame, got {type(df).__name__}')
25
26        if not isinstance(columns, (list, type(None))):
27            raise TypeError(f'columns must be a list or type None, got {type(df).__name__}')
28
29        if isinstance(df, pd.DataFrame):
30
31            self.df = df.copy()
32
33            if columns is None:
34                self.columns = self.df.columns.to_list()
35            else:
36                self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
37
38        elif isinstance (df, pl.DataFrame):
39            
40            self.df = df.clone()
41
42            if columns is None:
43                self.columns = self.df.columns
44
45            else:
46                self.columns = [column for column in columns if column in self.df.columns]
def polars_to_pandas( self, array_type: str = 'auto', conversion_threshold: int = None) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
 48    def polars_to_pandas(self, array_type: str='auto', conversion_threshold: int=None)-> pd.DataFrame:
 49        """
 50        Converts a polars DataFrame to a pandas DataFrame
 51
 52        Parameters
 53        -----------
 54        array_type: str
 55    
 56            Determines the array/backend type used in pandas operations, by default 'auto'.
 57
 58            Options are:
 59
 60            - 'numpy' -> usual NumPy backend (slower for very large datasets with object types)
 61            - 'pyarrow' -> PyArrow backend for better performance on large datasets
 62            - 'auto' -> automatically selects backend based on input and dataset size 
 63
 64        conversion_threshold: int
 65            The number of rows at which the conversion from Polars to pandas switches to Arrow-backed pandas arrays for performance, default is 100000.
 66            Users can increase or decrease this threshold depending on their dataset size and memory availability.
 67        
 68        Returns
 69        -------
 70        pd.DataFrame
 71            A pandas DataFrame
 72
 73        Usage Recommendation
 74        ---------------------
 75            Use this function to convert datasets quickly without having to do manual conversions and remembering parameters.
 76            Polars -> pandas conversion ensures efficient memory usage and stability, even on low-RAM systems.
 77
 78        Considerations
 79        ---------------
 80            Adjust array_type and conversion_threshold for very large datasets to optimize performance and memory usage.
 81        """
 82
 83        if not isinstance(self.df, pl.DataFrame):
 84            raise TypeError(f'Expected a polars DataFrame, got {type(self.df).__name__}')
 85
 86        if not isinstance(array_type, str):
 87            raise TypeError(f'array type must be a string, got {type(array_type).__name__}')
 88        
 89        if not isinstance(conversion_threshold, (int, type(None))):
 90            raise TypeError(f'conversion threshold must be an integer or type None, got {type(conversion_threshold).__name__}')
 91
 92        if conversion_threshold is None:
 93            conversion_threshold = 100_000
 94
 95        df_size = self.df.height
 96
 97        if array_type == 'auto':
 98            # if rows more than or equal to conversion threshold
 99            if df_size >= conversion_threshold:
100                return self.df.to_pandas(use_pyarrow_extension_array=True)
101            else:
102                return self.df.to_pandas()
103
104        if array_type == 'numpy':
105            
106            pandas_df = self.df.to_pandas()
107            return pandas_df
108
109        elif array_type == 'pyarrow':
110
111            pandas_df = self.df.to_pandas(use_pyarrow_extension_array=True)
112
113            return pandas_df

Converts a polars DataFrame to a pandas DataFrame

Parameters

array_type: str

Determines the array/backend type used in pandas operations, by default 'auto'.

Options are:

- 'numpy' -> usual NumPy backend (slower for very large datasets with object types)
- 'pyarrow' -> PyArrow backend for better performance on large datasets
- 'auto' -> automatically selects backend based on input and dataset size

conversion_threshold: int The number of rows at which the conversion from Polars to pandas switches to Arrow-backed pandas arrays for performance, default is 100000. Users can increase or decrease this threshold depending on their dataset size and memory availability.

Returns

pd.DataFrame A pandas DataFrame

Usage Recommendation

Use this function to convert datasets quickly without having to do manual conversions and remembering parameters.
Polars -> pandas conversion ensures efficient memory usage and stability, even on low-RAM systems.

Considerations

Adjust array_type and conversion_threshold for very large datasets to optimize performance and memory usage.
def pandas_to_polars(self, include_index: bool = False) -> polars.dataframe.frame.DataFrame: 
115    def pandas_to_polars(self, include_index:bool=False)-> pl.DataFrame:
116        """
117        Converts a pandas DataFrame to a polars DataFrame
118
119        Parameters
120        -----------
121        include_index: bool, optional
122            Whether you would like to include index during conversion from pandas to polars, by default False
123        
124        Returns
125        -------
126        pl.DataFrame
127            A polars DataFrame
128            
129        Considerations
130        ---------------
131            Polars do not have the concept of index like pandas does, hence, you can adjust include_index depending on your requirement.
132        """
133        
134        if not isinstance(include_index, bool):
135            raise TypeError(f'include_index must be either True or False, got {type(include_index).__name__}')
136
137        polars_df = pl.from_pandas(self.df, include_index = include_index)
138
139        return polars_df

Converts a pandas DataFrame to a polars DataFrame

Parameters

include_index: bool, optional Whether you would like to include index during conversion from pandas to polars, by default False

Returns

pl.DataFrame A polars DataFrame

Considerations

Polars do not have the concept of index like pandas does, hence, you can adjust include_index depending on your requirement.
